PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 19 citizens) and Senator Brownhill (from 42 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worst extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bell (from 125 citizens) and Senator Coulter (from 2,411 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Quarrying at Exit Cave
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, noting the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee concludes that `even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values', respectfully call upon the Federal Government to take all necessary measures to prevent further quarrying at Exit Cave.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Senate call on the Australian Labor Party to return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that the new rates for registered articles under Australia Post's Print Post arrangements are unfair and discriminate against rural residents. The new arrangements will significantly increase the cost of magazines and newspapers for those who wish to receive them by mail and has the potential to threaten the viability of country newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating should be condemned for his disgraceful public attack on our national flag in a foreign country. The petitioners note that his public remarks
discredited our proud history and unique culture
degraded the efforts of all servicemen and women
insulted and embarrassed proud Australians
damaged our international reputation as a united and patriotic democratic nation
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Mr Keating apologise to the Australian people for his demeaning behaviour in a foreign country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to last night, I now call on General Business order of the day No. 1091 relating to the resumed debate on the motion of Senator Bishop to take note of the letter from the United States Ambassador to Australia which responded to the resolution of the Senate concerning agricultural subsidies.

—Last night I was highlighting the concern that all members of both this chamber and the other chamber felt about the impact of EEP and the common agricultural policy upon the primary producers in this country, especially our wheat growers. I have previously mentioned what was estimated by the OECD to be the subsidy to Australian primary producers and wheat growers.

PARA.TAB: What people often fail to recognise is that any assistance we give is decoupled. That means that it does not distort production. It is assistance to farmers such as the rural adjustment scheme—the RAS scheme—which not all farmers have access to or utilise. It is not utilised by all wheat growers. It is assistance that the Government may give in matching finance with marketing and research and development. This scheme is very different from any of the sorts of schemes through which farmers are actually paid money to produce or, in some cases within the CAP, not to produce products.

It is very important that Australia continue to lead the way as we have done by taking the recent EEP moves to the GATT and requesting the GATT to further investigate and work upon this issue. We must continue our work to be the leaders, as we have been in the Uruguay Round of GATT as part of the Cairns Group. We must continue this work to make sure that agriculture stays as it has now been placed under the GATT regime and that we actually get these countries looking at how they can wean their producers off the subsidies which are not decoupled. They are definitely coupled and they definitely distort the production.

As I have said, our schemes do not distort production. Our schemes provide assistance in things like marketing. They provide assistance for those farmers who have to leave the land or they provide assistance with interest rates. The assistance is not distorting the production. It is very important that we continue the work of ensuring that changes are made at an international level through the GATT.

It is a falsehood to say that our Ministers have not been active on this. It was in fact Australia that forced this particular EEP decision to be taken to GATT with the support of other GATT members who are affected. It is also a falsehood on the part of the United States to say that it is not interfering with our markets, that EEP is not having an impact. Everybody in this country knows that that is not true. Everybody in this country knows that the United States putting its red wheat into India when we wish to put our white wheat there—our harvest is about to commence in some areas—must have an impact on world prices to some extent. It has an impact because there is so much more wheat floating around, but EEP is providing US farmers with a subsidy, a price and an income which is not able to be matched by many other places.

We need to remember that this is an election year in the United States. I guess there are many things being said for the consumption of the local voters in that country. The election could also well be distorting the statements that are being made. One gets concerned when one hears other statements being made that the United States has large deficits and it has to do something about that because it does not appear that it is prepared to face the particular issue that EEP payments is adding towards those sorts of monetary problems it is experiencing.

I notice with some concern that the letter from the ambassador says that the United States will continue to operate the EEP in a manner which will, to the extent possible, protect the interests of non-subsidising exporters such as Australia. One wonders, when clauses like `to the extent possible' are included, just how committed the United States is to its claim that it will protect the interests of non-subsidising exporters. I find it a little alarming to find that phrase in this particular letter.

I would stand by everything that has been said in this and the other chamber in support of our agricultural industry and all of our endeavours to ensure that international trade ceases to be corrupted in the manner it is by two very large and powerful groups which can `afford' to assist their farmers. But when one looks at their economic situations one begins to wonder about their capacity to continue to do this.

I want to make sure it is known to everybody in this country that everybody in this Parliament is alarmed about the EEP proposals and about the EEP actions that have taken place. Nobody in this place has the right to moral indignation on his or her own. Everyone here is concerned and it is important that that is recognised. I would like to associate myself with the previous resolution that came from this chamber and I hope that a miracle could happen in the United States taking a great deal of notice of our resolution.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are experiencing one of those very rare occasions when the whole of the Senate is supporting the wheat industry and expressing extreme disappointment with the actions of the American President and the American Department of Agriculture. It is important that we debate this issue. It is ironic that yesterday, on the very day the letter from the American Embassy was tabled, the Americans announced an EEP payment to India for the sale of one million tonnes of wheat at $100m with a subsidy of $47 a tonne.

PARA.TAB: I want the chamber to debate this matter and I want this debate to be forwarded to the American Ambassador. I want him then to forward it to the appropriate authorities in America to show that there is unanimous disappointment in one chamber in Australia—by the Liberals, Nationals, Democrats, Independents, Greens and members of the left and right factions of the Labor Party—with the actions of the Americans.

We can take a lot from a lot of people. But one of the disappointing things that I have had to experience is the total feeling of disillusionment of the Australian farmers. They can understand the EC doing it to them and they can understand the hardships of a trade war. But what they cannot understand and what is completely frustrating to them is that their friends, the Americans, would do this to them. There is no-one more loyal to the American alliance than Australian farmers and primary producers. This is why they find it totally unacceptable that a friend could stab them in the back. They cannot understand it. I want the American Ambassador, Mr Sembler, to pass back to the appropriate authorities in America the sentiment that this chamber unanimously disagrees with the actions that the Americans have taken on wheat subsidies.

On 16 September the US announced that it was going to offer $32.56 a tonne subsidy for 220,000 tonnes of grain that was to be sold to Pakistan. The Americans traditionally had 1.1 million tonnes of that market. Australia had 600,000 tonnes and Canada had 600,000 tonnes. We shared that market which was not EEPed or subsidised. The Americans then came in and EEPed our 600,000 tonnes. They took 220,000 tonnes at a subsidy of $32 a tonne, despite the fact that there was never any indication that the EC was going to target that market. The Australian Wheat Board, with its market forces on the ground and its intelligence operation—it does an excellent job—said that there was never any chance of the EC attacking that market. Yet we have lost 220,000 tonnes.

In September, President Bush announced an EEP increase of $1.4 billion. He was going to subsidise almost the entire US export crop, that is, 30 million tonnes, to 28 different countries—30 million tonnes of wheat equates to one-third of the world's wheat trade—and the US added countries such as South Africa, India, Yemen, Brazil and Poland. That total package was worth $4.19 billion.

The ironic part of this is that the Americans are cutting their own throats. They are subsidising other countries with their taxpayers' money when they would have had those markets anyhow. The US would have sold into both the Indian and the Pakistani markets at commercial prices, but it has effectively EEPed its own taxpayers. It never achieved a higher market; it undercut its own market. Who had to pick up the bill? The American taxpayer. The Americans never got one extra sale. They cut their own price. An elementary lesson of selling is that anyone can give a product away.

Ninety per cent of EEP sales have displaced US commercial sales. The USA has spent $3.4 billion up to September 1992 on EEP sales and recovered 2 per cent of the world market share for the US. The EC market share has gone up from 14.3 per cent to 20.5 per cent. After spending $3.4 billion, all the US has done is recover 2 per cent of the market. But it has had a terrible effect on the Australian price. I will come to that later.

It has been acknowledged as a fact by the US General Accounting Office that Australian wheat farmers were more exposed to international wheat policies and received less government support than wheat farmers in any other major wheat exporting country. That is not a finding by any organisation in Australia; that is a finding by the US General Accounting Office. So that puts paid to any statements by the US farmers that the Wheat Board is some sort of communist supplied, centrally organised market and that the Wheat Board subsidises Australian farmers. That is not right and it is condemned through the mouth of that American organisation.

What effect has EEP sales had on Australian wheat? In 1991, pool prices were depressed by some $30 to $40 a tonne. In 1980, Australia had 16 per cent of the world market. In 1984 or 1985, when the American farm bill started to EEP American wheat, Australia had 19 per cent of the world market. At the start of 1991, that 19 per cent was reduced to 13 per cent. In 1991-92, our share of the world market fell to 7 per cent. Our area and production are down.

Several years ago—Senator Panizza and Senator Crane, two of the many wheat growers we know in this area, will back this up—we produced 20 million tonnes of wheat. Last season, our areas were down by 2 million hectares, production was down by 6 million tonnes to 9.4 million tonnes, and the loss of 1.5 million tonnes only was attributable to the drought.

This year we will harvest an estimated 12.9 million tonnes of wheat, down from 20 million tonnes a couple of years ago, before the EEP program started. That explains very dramatically what the EEP sales have done to Australian wheat growers; but it does not explain the loss of price by the Australian wheat growers. Madam Acting Deputy President, I know that you come from a wheat growing area and you are very concerned. You have seen, as have Senator Crane and Senator Panizza, the hardship that is being experienced by our wheat growers in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about me?

—And Senator Brownhill, who is a very prominent wheat grower in his area. Later we will be hearing from Senator Brownhill, who will give his own experiences of what is happening. I have heard him say that fewer and fewer people are growing more and more for less and less. Those few short words explain the plight of the Australian primary producer.

PARA.TAB: Some of the wheat growers in Queensland are recipients of food parcels from the Uniting Church. That is a terrible indictment of what is happening and what the CAP and the EEP programs are doing to Australian primary industry. We have reduced our proud farmers to taking handouts, and there is nothing they can do about it. It does not matter how efficient they become; they cannot get a price that allows them to grow wheat commercially and make a profit. There is less and less wheat grown as the EEP subsidies take hold and reduce the price, thus reducing the planting and the size of the wheat industry.

Senator West indicated that the saviour of this was the GATT Round. I am afraid that Senator West has more faith in the GATT Round than I have. I was one of its supporters two or three years ago. I was told by some very experienced ex-politicians that it would never work, and I decried that. In an answer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) gave me yesterday, he said that the window of opportunity is about three weeks, and that if the Uruguay Round is not concluded in that three weeks the window of opportunity will be lost. If that window of opportunity is lost, Australia will have to decide what it is going to do with its wheat growers. It cannot leave them out there on a limb undefended and unprotected, at the whim of these two mighty superpowers, and unilaterally disarm our farmers. If that happens, we will not have a wheat industry in the future. None except a few of the bigger farmers can withstand this attack on their industry, on their living standards, and on the industries the Australian wheat growers supply, such as the milling industry.

Some hard decisions have to be taken. For five and a half years we have put all our support, all our hopes and all our faith in the Uruguay Round. We have three weeks to bring it off. I hope with all the sincerity I can muster that Senator Evans, Mr Kerin, the Prime Minister, and anyone else who has some influence on this debate will pull it off.

There is nothing I would rather see happen than a successful conclusion to the GATT Round. But if it does not happen, then we have to be able to say to these farmers, `You can't stand out there alone, unprotected'. They will go down like dominoes, one after another, until they are faced with that dreaded part D of the RAS which says, `Take the handout and get off your farm in 12 months, and if you don't get off your farm in 12 months, we are going to take the handout back'. There are a great number of farmers out there who are terrified of signing that part D agreement. Yet for many, the dreaded part D is their only way out. It gives them $55,000 to buy a new home and move to the metropolitan area, where they are not trained to do anything, where they do not know where they will get a job and where they will join the unemployment queues.

Again, I appeal to Mr Sembler, because I believe he knows the problem in Australia, to make representations to the US Department of Agriculture and the President and tell them the damage they are doing to their friends. It is going to be a race to see which happens first: whether we get the American election over with or whether the wheat industry stays. We cannot continue to take one hammering after another, losing one market and then the next market, with the price going down every time an EEP sale is made.

This is one of those rare occasions where the whole of the Senate is united in support of the Australian farmer and in disagreement with the actions the American Government has taken which are affecting our farmers. I hope the appropriate Senate authorities here will send a copy of this debate to the American Ambassador so that he can forward the sentiments of this chamber to the American Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long because a number of my colleagues also wish to contribute to this debate. The debate has come about as a result of a resolution of this Senate protesting at increases in the US EEP, which is basically a subsidy, at the expense of Australian producers. The American Ambassador has responded to the Senate's protest and in effect has asked us to be patient, saying that the purpose of the EEP is to bring the Europeans to heel. He has also stressed in his letter to us that the United States will do what it can to avoid hurting innocent producers, that is, fair traders—Australian traders, Australian producers—in the course of its program. In other words, he argues that it is not directed against us; it is directed against the Europeans because it is part of the Americans' tactic to try to reduce international subsidies by applying pressure to the Europeans.

PARA.TAB: I do not dispute that motive. Certainly it is the original purpose of the export enhancement program. There is no doubt that the European subsidisation of agriculture is at extremely high levels and there is no doubt that it has done international damage to fair traders. I understand the original motive of the United States in a program to try to apply pressure to Europe.

The trouble is, however, that in doing that they are—whether it is their purpose or not—severely damaging fair traders, that is, producers such as Australia. They are doing that by forcing down the price of product. The further restructuring of EEP, the new announcements regarding the expansion of the program—certainly to the degree to which the product is subsidising the United States—will have that effect in this country also. The consequence will be, therefore, to hurt Australian producers. The Senate is certainly acting properly in protesting to the United States about that development, and it should continue to do so.

That is the point I wish to make. It is vital that, despite the fact that we have such an important relationship in all respects with the United States, we continue to protest this policy it has which is having a detrimental effect upon our producers. We should do so as a Senate; the Australian Government should do so; and we as an Opposition should do so. In that light, I have to say how disappointed I was that when the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) quite reasonably protested at the extent of protectionist policies in the United States and the EEP in particular, and he was condemned by the Australian Prime Minister, Mr Keating, for doing so. How that can be in the best interests of Australia is impossible to see. Mr Keating should have commended the Leader of the Opposition for taking this issue up to the Americans, for bringing it before them. Dr Hewson made the point that, despite the fact that we have such an important relationship with the United States, in this instance, the US has a policy which is harming our producers and we protest that policy. Quite contrary to the action taken by the Prime Minister, what he should have been doing was supporting Dr Hewson in protesting this protectionist policy of the United States that is harming Australian wheat producers.

Realising that he got it wrong, what did the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Keating, do? He went to Japan and protested American policy. I cannot think of anything more diplomatically improper than the Australian Prime Minister going to Japan protesting the policies of a third nation. That is not the place to do it. The place to do it is in this country and through our mission in the United States. I regret that action by the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Keating, which does not help Australia's interests at all. In fact, it will be counterproductive. It makes it even more difficult for us to effectively protest these policies that are harming our producers.

Last week I was in Washington and I met with the honourable Michael Moskow, the deputy US trade representative who is responsible for this region, and also with the officials from the agriculture department, in particular, Mr Censky who was in Australia recently and heard first hand the views of Australian producers in relation to US policies. I was doing what all Australian politicians should be doing and what the Senate was doing and that was protesting these policies and the harm they cause our producers.

What I also sought to do with these US bureaucrats was start talking through with them whether there are not alternative policies that the US could adopt that might have a greater effect upon Europe in the way that the US claims that the program is designed. In other words, the subsidisation of the US wheat crop is not, in my view, a way that is effectively going to bring Europe to heel. I said to Mr Censky that if his argument is right, surely the logical progression of that argument is that the US should further increase its subsidies. I asked, `Should it double it? Should it treble it?' Of course, the answer I got was that, no, they did not think that would be desirable. I am pleased to hear that. But that really means that they, in effect, acknowledge that it is not working. There is no suggestion that the US EEP has had any effect upon European policies and European subsidies at all.

There is some hope in Europe, particularly in the announcements last year of reform to the CAP. But there is no suggestion that that has been as a result of pressure from the United States through the EEP. Rather it is as a result of Europe very slowly realising the extent to which it is disadvantaging its community as a whole by paying these enormous subsidies to a minority of that community. Therefore, I said to the Americans, `This policy or argument, as you put it, is not working and therefore you should be looking for alternatives'.

I discussed with them the Australian initiative last year to seek to publicise in Europe to Europeans the cost to them of subsidies. This was a program the Australian Government commenced but abandoned almost as quickly as it started because a bit of pressure was applied from Europe. Nevertheless, the US has the capacity to put in a lot more resources. Looking at the extent of resources it is putting into subsidies, it could be putting those resources into a program to communicate the damaging effect of subsidies within Europe. That is an alternative they could be considering. I raised that with them and discussed it with them. I also raised with the United States whether more programs might be developed to retaliate more directly against specific subsidies in Europe, something that can give the effect of these subsidies greater focus.

There are other options that our Government—Mr Keating, his Ministers and his bureaucrats—should be putting to the US Government. That is what we want. We want some action. It is no good the Government simply coming in here and saying, as Senator Evans did yesterday, that our only hope is the GATT, our only hope is the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round, and that we will keep moving along that path. The Uruguay Round started in 1986 and still has not been successfully concluded. If it is, that will be to our advantage; I do not dispute that.

In the meantime, there were other tactics that could have been adopted and other pressures that could have been applied. The Australian Government should have been applying these pressures; it should have been looking for new and more imaginative ways to apply pressure both to the United States and to Europe and, therefore, doing something positive for the benefit of Australian wheat growers, rather than simply putting all our eggs in the GATT basket, which so far has failed to reach a successful conclusion.

Even at this late stage, I urge the Australian Government, which has not done enough in this area for the benefit of Australian producers, to get out there and pursue some of these other options, to be seen to be doing something positive for the benefit of Australian producers, rather than what it has done to date, and that is simply to rely upon the GATT and the Uruguay Round, which to date has not succeeded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak on this motion relating to the letter received from the American Ambassador, Mr Mel Sembler. I shall make a number of points that I think are relevant to the debate. I particularly support Senator Hill's concluding comments about other actions the Government could take to help overcome the problem we have now, which I intend to address myself.

PARA.TAB: Much is being made, quite correctly, of the fact that this part of the EEP is directly related to the current American presidential election. However, I well remember putting to Jim Parker, the American Agricultural Attache—I think it was in 1987-88, when the EEP was in place—exactly the same arguments we went through the other day with Mr Steven Censky about what the Americans were doing to the Australian wheat industry.

I do not excuse what the Europeans have done; however, I think there are other methods, as Senator Hill has mentioned, by which we can attack them to get them to change their policy, other than using GATT on its own. What the Americans did then and what they are doing now by their actions is depressing world wheat prices by approximately $30 a tonne. They depressed them then by up to $50 a tonne and they are doing it again now.

Australia will sell all its wheat. We learnt in the years from 1969 to 1971, when we tried to introduce quotas and store wheat in Australia, that those measures did not work. Firstly, it was impossible to get equity between growers with quotas; but, more importantly, with Australian climatic conditions, we could not successfully store wheat because of problems with moisture and weevils in storage. Since then, Australia has met the market price and we have sold our wheat. As far as our wheat industry is concerned and the types of wheat we produce—whether it be the hard wheats or the soft wheats—in meeting the world markets we also have a quality advantage that other countries do not have. That has always put us in a favourable position for clearing our stocks.

The actions of the Americans in this case have left us in a very vulnerable position as far as price is concerned. The Americans have to recognise that they are not going to pinch Australian market share because we will meet the price. We have done that previously; we sell most of our wheat through international contracts which have been in place for many years.

It is worth noting that on a year-in year-out average, approximately 80 per cent of Australian wheat is sold government agency to government agency—in our case, Australian Wheat Board contracts. Very little trading of Australian wheat is done by private grain traders. That is the nature of the Australian wheat industry and that is how it has operated very successfully for a long time. That is the first point the Americans have to understand, and it is a point that a number of us have tried to make in previous debates and discussions we have had on this matter.
Looking further at the letter from Mr Sembler, the last paragraph particularly annoys me because I have heard the point made so often:

You may be assured that we will continue to operate our Export Enhancement Program in a manner which will, to the extent possible, protect the interests of non-subsidising exporters such as Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: If America, Europe or any other country is going to dump product, in this case wheat, into the world markets which effectively depresses the price, there is nothing that can be done to protect anybody from that drop in price. That comment of Mr Sembler's is an absolute nonsense, as I said before. I spoke about this to Mr Jim Parker and others in 1987 and I made those points to President Bush when he was here. He answered me by saying, in effect, `I now understand the problem you have. It is not a case of us pinching Australian markets. It is a case of us depressing the price and affecting Australian growers in that way'.

PARA.TAB: The other tragedy—and Senator Boswell mentioned it very succinctly—is the hardship and the poverty this action has caused many Australian wheat growers, particularly in parts of New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia. There is a flow-on effect to the machinery dealers, the local storekeepers and so on. It also affects the Australian economy as a whole in our endeavours to balance our current account.

If I could talk for a moment about some of the recent programs, the Indian sale is very disturbing. The Pakistan situation is also disturbing, but for very different reasons. Since this latest program has been put in place wheat has been sold to Bangladesh, Pakistan and Egypt—598,000 tonnes to Egypt, 10,000 tonnes to Bangladesh and 220,000 tonnes to Pakistan. Under the Indian program it is envisaged that the Americans will sell 1.5 million tonnes. There has been a subsidisation of approximately $US30 a tonne, which is almost the direct impact on the world wheat price. One has to understand—I am sure it is something the current Australian Government does not understand—that approximately 100 million tonnes per annum of wheat is traded in the world. About 15 million tonnes of that is white wheat and the remainder, approximately 85 million tonnes, is red wheat.

Australia produces about 10 million tonnes or two-thirds of the traded white wheat in the world. Europe does not produce any traded white wheat, America produces a small percentage of it, and the rest is spread around a number of countries. When America moved into Pakistan, Mr Censky tried to justify this by saying that the Europeans might go into Pakistan. It was not that they would go into Pakistan, or that they were in Pakistan, but that they might go into Pakistan with their red wheat. It is a well known fact—and this is where I believe the Australian Government failed in terms of the announcements on EEP and the additional countries it was said were being targeted—that on that day our people, at ministerial and prime ministerial level, should have been making the right noises, letting the Americans know quite clearly before the action had been taken that, in terms of the Pakistan market, it was not a market that had been under threat or was traditionally under threat, nor was there much potential for it to be under threat by the actions of the Europeans, because of the very nature of the product that is grown. That, of course, is the difference between red and white wheats.

Of course, the argument that has been put to us over the years related to the regaining of the market share that the United States alleged had been taken from it by the Europeans and that its action was to regain that market share by subsidising into those markets. That market, in the words of Jim Parker in 1987, had been taken from it, and those words have been reiterated time and again.

So the position which exists in terms of this letter and the position that has been put to us by the United States is no longer valid in terms of what it said with regard to its original intention which it has repeated consistently as far as EEP is concerned.

The other point that needs to be made is that while the US share, as a percentage of the traded world wheat market, has decreased, its actual tonnage of world traded wheat has marginally increased. While it says that it has had markets taken from it, the world traded wheat market has expanded over recent years. As I said—and I repeat this; this is the message that needs to be spelt out very clearly by the Government to the Americans—its tonnage of world traded wheat has increased, not decreased.

I now turn to the Indian situation. The Indian situation is quite tragic in terms of the further development and expansion of EEP. India is not a traditional market for wheat for anybody, or has not been in recent years. India has been basically self-sufficient and has in fact been a net exporter of wheat. So any claim that the Americans were regaining part of their share of what the Europeans may have taken in terms of the Indian market is absolutely and totally false. Had the Americans, as the Australians and others have done, gone in there under the same market conditions without subsidising the product into India and further depressing world market prices, they would have been able to obtain their fair share of that market, as it is an opportunistic market in terms of wheat that can be sold to India.

It is worth noting that there is a very significant difference between the markets in Pakistan and India. Pakistan is a traditional white wheat market; India is not a traditional market for anybody. It just so happens that, because of seasonal conditions which have occurred in India and the fact that it has not had its normal levels of production and its stockpiles have been run down, it is rebuilding those particular stockpiles. If America or any other country wishes to give aid to a particular country at a particular time because it has had harsh seasonal conditions, then it should be done in such a way that does not distort world trade and does not depress world prices.

We have not had one word from the Government about the intricacies of these two markets. The Government, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have failed dismally the Australian wheat growers, their service industries and the Australian economy in not spelling out the correct position.

As Senator Hill said in his speech, when Dr Hewson made some comments and was critical of the American position, was there support for the position he adopted? The answer is no. Instead, the Prime Minister got stuck into Dr Hewson. Of course, Dr Hewson was absolutely correct, and that was borne out once again by our `offshore' Prime Minister when he chose to attack America from Japan in the same way as he denigrated our flag when he was in Papua New Guinea. There was much that could have been done by the Australian Government about those two markets in particular and the relationship between the European position and the American position.

I want to go a little further and talk about the GATT Round and what can be done and achieved. Nobody in this place, or in the other place for that matter, would not want us to pursue the GATT Round as hard as we can, but there are more ways than one to skin a cat. We have to look at options and alternatives in overcoming our problems with our trading position.

As Senator Hill mentioned, there is potential in Europe through its program for some high-powered publicity of the cost of the subsidisation of the program to the consumer. This is not very far different to some of the debate which has occurred in Australia in recent years concerning the cost of various programs, particularly relevant to protection, and what it has cost individuals within Australia. That is just one way by which it can be pursued. While we all support the development of multilateral trading arrangements, there is also potential for bilateral trading arrangements which will sit quite comfortably alongside multilateral trading arrangements.

I conclude my remarks by saying that the other thing that can be done here in Australia to overcome the difficulty that this has caused Australian wheat growers is for the Government itself to get the Government monkey off the back of grain growers and others. I refer in particular to the cost of protection to grain growers, the cost of transport, the impact of the fuel excise, the flow-on effects of payroll tax, many of the problems we have in the meat industry, for example, the lack of reform in our abattoirs in this country. There is a whole range of things that can be done internally that have nothing to do with the Americans, the Europeans, or anybody else for that matter, but us. Those are actions that can be taken here and now. I put it to the Government that it really is an opportune time to move on some of these add-on costs that grain growers and others in the community bear.

This letter is very disappointing in its content. It is no different from what was being said five or six years ago. The American position on EEP and what it was supposed to do has not won back part of the so-called loss of market share that they lost to the Europeans, although one has to question that having regard to the fact that American sales in tonnes have not fallen on world markets. Australia has to look at every option in bringing pressure to bear both on the Europeans and on the Americans for the injustice that they have perpetuated on Australian wheat growers, who, as I said in my earlier comments, do meet the market and sell their grain but take the depressed price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the motion moved by Senator Bishop to take note of the letter from the United States Ambassador to Australia responding to a resolution of the Senate concerning agricultural subsidies. That letter from the American Ambassador, which was written on 25 September, firstly acknowledged the receipt of the letter sent by the Senate and then went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: We have transmitted a text of the resolution to Washington.
It continued:

PARA.TAB: I would like to take this opportunity to point out that the United States and Australia have entered into frequent bilateral agricultural technical consultations. One spin off from those was the meeting in Parliament House, hosted by the Australian-American Parliamentary Friendship Group, on September 16.

SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to that in a little while. The letter went on to state:

At that meeting the leader of the U.S. delegation, Mr. Steven Censky, responded to questions from interested Parliamentarians for over one and a half hours. These questions were quite pointed regarding the use of export subsidies by the United States and the closeness of the relationship between the United States and Australia.
The second last paragraph of the letter from the Ambassador states:

PARA.TAB: We note that the Senate Resolution also calls on the European Community to exercise moderation in the use of its export subsidies. As you are aware, the U.S. Export Enhancement Program is designed to force that outcome in the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round.

SPEECH.PARA: The last paragraph, which Senator Crane has already referred to, states:

PARA.TAB: You may be assured that we will continue to operate our Export Enhancement Program in a manner which will, to the extent possible, protect the interests of non-subsidizing exporters such as Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to refresh the memory of the chamber, the resolution, which began as a motion by Senator Panizza, urged:

1. the US Administration and Congress, in the spirit of the long-standing and close alliance relationship between Australia and the US (reaffirmed by President Bush when he visited Australia and addressed the joint sitting of Parliament), to ensure that frequent and effective dialogue is conducted between the two countries to minimise the adverse effects of the EEP on Australia, a non-subsidising exporter;
2. the European Community to exercise moderation in the use of its own export subsidies and to resist the temptation to escalate further the price subsidy war; and
3. the European Community and the US to give the highest possible priority to reaching agreement in the Uruguay Round, most particularly on the use of agricultural export subsidies.

This has gone on for a long time. It started even further back than that. On 5 September I led a group of National Party parliamentarians and others to the American Embassy to protest what was happening. I took a letter from Tim Fischer, the Leader of the National Party, carrying a formal resolution to the Embassy to say that we were very concerned at what was happening. At our conference in Canberra on 5 September, we were worried about the dramatic extension of the export enhancement program for wheat, which had the potential to corrupt world trade to the same extent that it had in 1986 and in 1990 and which would further depress the prices received by Australian wheat growers. That point has already been very clearly made by Senator Crane and others in this debate; indeed, it was made by Senator Bishop when she led the debate last night.

PARA.TAB: Other parts of American programs have also concerned Australian primary producers for quite a long time. They include the increased use of export subsidy programs for dairy products, the extension of the EEP to canned fruit and possibly to other grains and agricultural exports from America, and the further reduction of Australia's access to the US sugar market. We export to America some 97,000 tonnes, which is down from 168,000 tonnes two years ago and 800,000 tonnes 10 years ago.

I have a pecuniary interest in that I am a wheat and beef producer. Being a beef producer, I am also concerned about the imposition of restrictive meat quotas which were voluntarily imposed halfway through this year. We are told that there is going to be quite a lot of beef in bond by the end of the year. That is another problem for our primary producers in Australia.

But where did all this start? It started with the humbug from Humboldt's speech on Wednesday, 2 September. As an Australian who is very friendly with the United States, I have cause for concern. In that speech, President Bush said:

Let me make this comment to those friends of ours overseas also. Let me be clear. This action is aimed at those who subsidize, not at those such as Australia and others who do not subsidize. And today's wheat EEP initiatives will give farmers, exporters, and buyers more certainty about market opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be all right for the Americans, but it is not too good for Australian export industries. As Senator Crane made quite clear, we export a great proportion of wheat. About 100 million tonnes of wheat is traded around the world. If America through its EEP subsidises 30 million tonnes, which is about a third of that, it is obviously going to cause problems even to our white wheat exports. If nothing else, this will depress the price.

PARA.TAB: I think it is important for us all to address why America is doing this. The Office of the Press Secretary of the White House said on 2 September that the problem that the US wheat producers face is the highly subsidised competition from the EC. The European Community's wheat export subsidies average about $125 a tonne; the export subsidies from the United States are only going to average about $40 a tonne. But I wonder whether two wrongs make a right. I wonder whether this is going to bring a quicker resolution to the GATT Uruguay Round. If it does not, all it is going to do in the meantime is further corrupt our world trade, and that is something that I believe will cause further problems down the line.

A lot of people do not understand what EEP is. We know that the Americans are doing this because they want to have a crack at the Europeans. As I have been saying for the last few years, there is no doubt that the Europeans are the baddies. But just because the United States has a crack at them does not mean that the Americans are the goodies. The United States is just as bad as the Europeans if it wants to corrupt the world trade as well.

But what does the export enhancement program do? It enables the US exporters to meet prevailing world prices for targeted commodities and destinations. Under the program the USDA pays cash bonuses to US exporters. The bonuses make up the difference between the US domestic price and the world price, which is often lower because the European Economic Community and other subsidising exporters dump surplus production into the world markets. Australia, a good trader, trades into those markets. Obviously this will distort the market and cause problems for the Australian wheat growers.

Let us have a quick look at the problems for the Australian wheat growers. In 1970, a tonne of Australian wheat bought 2,200 litres of fuel. By 1991, a tonne of wheat bought only 200 litres of fuel, and it buys approximately that amount at the moment. It is well for this chamber to note that a recent study by ABARE suggests that, over this period, the agricultural sector has increased productivity in Australia at double the rate of the other economic sectors, which is great for our farmers. In the last two decades, the annual productivity growth in the broadacre industries has increased 2.2 per cent compared to 1.3 per cent in the manufacturing sector.

The farmers of Australia have bust their guts and done everything they can to increase productivity and to work more efficiently. This article by the National Australia Bank makes it very clear that the long term trends imply that technical progress in the rural industries will continue at a satisfactory level. However, more recent trends, particularly in the cropping industry, point to an alarming decline in inputs over a prolonged period from 1982 to the present. This is mirrored by a sharp fall in some of the outputs since 1986.

In a survey of 106 farmers in southern New South Wales, 72 per cent reported static or declining crop yields and 67 per cent claimed static or declining livestock production. We now have the problem of having to be leaner than lean and meaner than mean to try to compete against these countries that are distorting trade around the world, of which America is one. That will cause horrific problems to the Australian wheat growers in the next year or so while we try to compete against an American coffer which will continue its EEP program.

In conclusion, this chamber is angry and cranky about America's actions because Australia sold 500,000 tonnes of wheat to India just recently and had been hoping to pick up some more sales there. Senator Crane made it quite clear what happened: the Americans have now put one million tonnes of heavily subsidised wheat into India. With that assault on our market there, it does not look like there will be much left for us to be able to sell to India. The bottom line of all that is that the European Community has hardly put a load of wheat—it might have put one—into India in the last few years. So this action will not hurt the European Community; it will hurt only the traditional allies of the United States of America, one of which is Australia. That is where my anger lies.

If President Bush was fair dinkum when he said that he would not hurt Australia, being an ally of the United States and a country that did not subsidise—he spelt it out in his speech in Humboldt—surely he would say to the Americans, `Why don't we target some of the markets that the European Community is putting its wheat into and not the markets that the Australians are putting their wheat into'. I support the motion moved by Senator Bishop yesterday to take note of the reply of the United States Ambassador. I hope that this Senate very clearly sends another message to the Embassy that gets sent back to Washington which says, `Listen here, fellows. Do not hit the Australians with the back swing of your baseball bat. Go back and play in your own league. Hit the Europeans over the head, because they are the real culprits'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is a considerable time constraint so the fact that I will speak for three or four minutes is not a reflection of my interest in this matter, but rather an interest in ensuring that we make some progress today.
—Very well said.

—I thank Senator Patterson. The response to the resolution of the Senate really manifests all the problems of this issue. This issue is brought to us by the recent US sales to India and by the fact that the President of the United States is 20 points behind in the polls and fears that he will not be re-elected. He has gone to the mid-west of the United States trying to buy votes. The tragedy is that it does not seem to be working. Ultimately, we are paying an awful price for his endeavours. Without wishing to preach to the Americans, every dollar that subsidises the US wheat growers is either another dollar onto the American deficit or another dollar taken away from appropriate budget outlays.

PARA.TAB: Putting aside the immediate sales into India, the truth of the matter is that the Americans are not the primary enemy in this matter. The Americans did not start this war and George Bush is doing little more than responding to the gross and obscene politics of the European nations. That is driven not by economic judgments but again by political judgments. Because the French farmers have such enormous muscle, along with the Germans and, to a lesser degree, the British, they are able to drive the political agenda for the EEC. That has been the exclusive reason that we have not had any breakthroughs in GATT or the Uruguay Round or any other negotiations.

The tragedy for Australia is that we have highly efficient, effective and unsubsidised farmers who are now having their markets tainted by the United States retaliation against the Europeans. It is related to both politics with the EEC and domestic politics with George Bush. There is no sensible, logical or good reason why the Australian markets should suffer collateral damage as a result of the conflict between the EEC and the United States. The United States could wage its war with the EEC without visiting any of our markets. However, for political reasons, it has chosen not to.

This conflict shows one thing—that is, that the words proffered by George Bush when he visited Australia were thoroughly hollow. But that comes as no surprise because this Government believes that its foreign affairs policies can be driven on friendship and goodwill and little Bob Hawke slapping George Bush on the back, or whoever his friend for the day is, or Paul Keating developing a new-found friendship. The truth is that foreign affairs is driven by self-interest. What is in the interests of one nation will reflect in its attitude towards its allies and its enemies.

I conclude by saying that I do not agree with anybody who argues that there ought to be any linkage on economic or political grounds between this matter and the matter of US bases on Australian shores. If it is wrong for defence reasons and if it is wrong because it creates a threat or a perceived threat in the minds of some, that does not change because of an economic dispute between Australia and the United States.

I am appalled that John Malcolm Fraser or anybody else would now seek to make that linkage on the basis of economic arguments. If economic arguments were ever capable of influencing whether the bases ought to be on Australian soil, surely they ought not ever have been here. If the bases are here for our security, for world peace, as is properly argued by all of us, that premise cannot be shifted simply because there is a dispute between the American farmers and the Australian farmers. If we can say that the bases are negotiable now, it means that they are negotiable on any term, and if they are negotiable on any term, save for defence and security arrangements, it was the wrong judgment to have them here in the first place. It is obscene to make that linkage.

I can understand the Democrats making that linkage. They have argued all along, with some purity in their argument, that the bases should never have been here. All they are doing now is using this argument to reinforce their earlier argument. But for anybody to now say that they ought to come into the equation as a political element is simply destroying the fundamental argument upon which the bases have previously been founded. It adds nothing to our relationship with the United States, it adds nothing to the economic debate and it adds nothing to the defence and security arrangements debate to somehow argue that because the Americans are dumping wheat in traditional Australian markets we no longer need security and defence arrangements with the United States in our own interests. I support the motion to take note of the response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to pick up the point that Senator Crichton-Browne made a moment ago. I thank him for raising the issue of the Democrats and the bases, stressing that we have always opposed the bases. But he is slightly wrong in drawing the conclusion that, if the argument for the bases originally was valid, it remains valid today. Circumstances have changed considerably. We have seen the end of the Cold War. The need for the bases has shifted quite substantially. Given those circumstances, and given the fact that many of us believe that the bases were more to do with American defence than with Australian defence, they are more negotiable today than they ever were. It is in that context that we have argued that perhaps one should reconsider the position of the bases. Indeed, a number of farmers around Australia have been making those suggestions. In Western Australia, where I was the week before last, there is very considerable hardship among the farming community, not least because of the activities of the Americans and the Europeans in relation to support for exports. The additional EEP scheme is simply the latest blow to Australian farmers.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the Australian Government has been tardy in offering support to Australian farmers. We have argued very considerably that there should be a guaranteed minimum price for wheat which should underpin the wheat price when the price falls—not that we want to return to the sort of support which was given to the wool industry, where the minimum price did not remain a minimum price but followed the world price up as it increased, leaving us with considerable stockpiles of wool. We support a minimum price which guarantees to farmers in times of depressed world prices a price which returns to the farmer the cost of planting the wheat and which at least guarantees that there will be a crop next year so that during those troughs in the market farmers are not wiped out. We strongly urge on the Government the reintroduction of such a scheme.

The third point I make very briefly is that one thing which this present debacle does show is that Australia is manifestly stupid in pursuing a policy of zero tariffs, of stripping away all protection, all support, for our own industry, while other countries are supporting their industries. We need to learn a lesson—the Opposition certainly needs to learn a lesson—from the damage being done to Australian wheat producers by this scheme, damage which they have very strongly attested to in the debate this morning. It needs to learn that in a world where there is still very substantial protection—indeed, where most of the OECD countries have increased protection for their industry—it is really stupid for Australia to pursue the alternative path.

It is our view that zero tariffs in Australia would really equate with zero jobs, with zero industry; that Australia, being a small country, needs protection of its industry. Again we would urge the Government to take a lesson from what is happening to our wheat farmers and apply it more generally to industry

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation under standing order 191.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to clarify one point in respect of comments I made earlier which were responded to by Senator Coulter. I was not and I do not argue that the justification for the bases being in Australia has not changed or cannot change.
—This is not a personal explanation; it is continuing the debate.
—Yes, it is.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—You are claiming to be misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am.
—In that case, you are in order.

—The justification and the grounds can change if the perceived threat changes, if security arrangements change, if alliances change and if relationships change. They could all be reasons for changing our defence arrangements. What does not change the original premise is the dispute between two trading partners or an economic dispute between allies. That corrupts the original argument. I accept that there is an argument to be had that we may not need bases in certain circumstances, such as where the Americans have pulled out of Subic Bay. They are pulling out of a number of their foreign bases around the world because of changing circumstances in the world, changing perceptions of threats. But one cannot mount an argument that the premise upon which—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We have been extraordinarily tolerant with this personal explanation where Senator Crichton-Browne claims to have been misrepresented. But, surely, he is now canvassing very widely issues in the substantive debate and he is not outlining, and never has throughout this personal explanation, in any sense any area where he claims to have been misrepresented.
—I understood you were just finishing.
—I was, but for the benefit of Senator Faulkner let me read the Standing Order:

PARA.TAB: A Senator who has spoken to a question may again be heard, to explain some material part of the Senator's speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood, but shall not introduce any new matter, or interrupt any Senator speaking, and no debatable matter shall be brought forward . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I am simply saying, for the benefit of those who do not know the Standing Orders, that I was misunderstood, in my view, by Senator Coulter and I was seeking to make that point. I trust I have now made it.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In exercising my right of reply in the debate on the motion I moved last evening, I take the opportunity to answer one or two of the points made by Senator Coulter in his last intervention and then to perhaps restate some of the salient points of the debate as it relates to a motion that was passed by the entire Senate.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, in my view, the bases question is a stand-alone question and is not related to a trade question. Secondly, however, Senator Coulter used this debate as an opportunity to advance his Party's high taxing policy—and, to the other taxes that he would impose upon the Australian people, he adds an additional tariff tax. He wishes to see tariff taxes, which he talked about in connection with the general issue of so-called `protectionism'—a word that I choose not to use because it is a warm and fuzzy word, when what we are really talking about is tariff tax where we tax that group of people over there and give it to this group of people over here because they are special.

Indeed, our farmers, about whose plight we are all concerned, are people who are forced to pay tariffs; but, as tariffs will be reduced to the 5 per cent level under our policy, they will benefit enormously. When we couple that with micro-economic reform in terms of transportation costs, the farmers will again benefit. Until Senator Coulter's intervention, none of the arguments canvassed in the debate had dealt at all with the question of a minimum price, such as the Democrats wish to impose, except for Senator Crane, who dealt with the question most adequately when he explained that the attempted quota system which had been used previously penalised the farmers themselves. In other words, if we have giants fighting, as would be the case with a large dispute between the United States and the European Community, it is not an area where we can compete with subsidies in any way, shape or form.

The whole strength of our argument is that we are efficient farmers. We want the right to compete internationally in the market where we have a competitive edge. Indeed, we still will sell our wheat, which is a point that has been made again and again by speakers in the debate. But the issue is this: the United States action in extending its export enhancement program will mean that our farmers' profit, which they were entitled to earn by diligence of hard work, effort and efficiency, will be denied them because the price that the international community will pay will be lowered by the action of the United States Government.

Very simply, as I said right at the beginning in moving the motion, we do not accept that the reason for the extension of the EEP is to attempt to bring the economic community to the GATT table to bring about a satisfactory resolution of the Uruguay Round. We all aim at seeing the Europeans come to the sensible conclusion that the CAP, the common agricultural policy, has to alter; that there has to be room for people who are efficient agricultural traders to see the benefit and seek rewards for their effort.

If the Europeans wish to implement a system of subsidies for their farmers, which in fact is a virtual social welfare policy to maintain certain populations in different parts of their countries, then they should please not ask us to pay for it. If George Bush wants to attract votes from the mid-west, with Governor Clinton appearing even more anxious to use the same technique, they should please not ask us to pay for it. If there are policies of subsidies which countries wish to use, then they must bear the cost of that subsidy themselves and must not impose it upon the international trading system, as it distorts not only the trade in that particular area but all trade.

The message that we give to the United States concerning the extension of the EEP is the same message that we take to the European Community concerning the CAP; it is the same message we take to Japan concerning its refusal to allow the importation to Japan of rice; and it is the same message that we use when we say that we are committed in Australia to a multilateral trading system with room for bilaterals which are consistent with that multilateral structure.

We are a nation that says the whole world benefits when there is free trade among nations. The post-World War II period has shown that the bringing down of tariff levels worldwide has enabled enormous world growth to take place. That growth has enabled newly industrialising economies to take off, developing countries to get a start to grow into more substantial partners, and the OECD countries to enjoy greater trading benefits.

Anything that impinges upon the ability of world trade to grow and for more and more countries to give a higher standard of living to their individual citizens, to my way of thinking, is a policy which stands condemned. That is the basis upon which I moved this motion to take note of the letter from the United States Ambassador last evening to say that we simply do not accept that subsidising a product and thereby distorting international trading practices is acceptable. The argument that the United States perpetually uses, that it is only there to fight the Europeans, just does not add up.

As I pointed out last night when I mentioned that I had read the remarks from Mr Baker, whereby he told the Australians to stop whingeing, not only is the policy to extend the EEP penalising efficient traders such as Australia and individual farmers but it is also exacerbating the problem in the United States because once subsidies are introduced the price of land is altered, the status of mortgages is changed and very often banks are put at risk because when that subsidy is taken away the reverse occurs.

So there are many aspects to this question which are pertinent not only to the Australian farmer and the Australian nation as a whole but also to the farmers and to the economic system within the United States. The spectacle of the two candidates for the presidency of the United States, President Bush and Governor Clinton, trying to outbid each other on how much subsidy they can pay to farmers, which in turn distorts the world market, is a most dispiriting spectacle indeed.

That is why we originally passed the resolution which was sent on to His Excellency, and His Excellency has told us in his letter that that message has been sent on to Washington. It is a most serious issue. It is a most serious manner in which this Senate has chosen to take note of Ambassador Sembler's letter, and I trust he will read the debate with great interest.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Bishop. A moment ago Senator Bishop sought to equate what I said about a guaranteed minimum price for wheat with an increase in taxation.

PARA.TAB: The lie to what she said is adequately demonstrated by the fact that, when the Federal Government removed the guaranteed minimum price for wheat, the Western Australian Government immediately legislated to put back a guaranteed minimum price for wheat, which allowed the farmers to go to the banks under that guarantee and plant next year's crop.

The guarantee was never in fact called upon. It cost nobody anything to put that in place, and that is in the record. So the conclusion which Senator Bishop has drawn is totally false and without any foundation whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: if I might say, I let Senator Coulter have his words but I would like to say on the record that it was not—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! What is your point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of order is that that was not a personal explanation; it was a continuance of the debate, and I would like it to be seen as such.
—I am ruling that Senator Coulter was in order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Federal Airports Corporation Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 255 and made under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion relates to the disallowance of the regulations made under the Federal Airports Corporation Act. It is really a most astonishing move by the Government to exempt the Federal Airports Corporation from having to comply with State laws in relation to the preparation of an EIS in relation to the third runway.

PARA.TAB: In the debate on this motion some three weeks ago, when I sought to have the Standing Orders suspended in order that the motion could be debated before the issue was heard in the High Court, I expressed the outrage that the Australian Democrats felt and, in fact, the outrage that many community groups in Sydney felt, at this action of the Federal Government in seeking once again to exempt one of its statutory corporations from State planning and environment laws that would otherwise apply to its activities.

This, of course, is a very important issue in Sydney. The third runway, as honourable senators would be aware, has been a very contentious issue. It has been a very contentious issue in the suburb in which I live, Bondi, and certainly across Sydney there is widespread concern, and has been so for some time, about the construction of the third runway. I am sure that that concern will be heightened now, in light of the recent accident in Amsterdam which tragically caused so much loss of life.

The regulations before us today are nothing more than an attempt by the FAC in collusion with the Minister to exempt the FAC from the New South Wales Environmental Protection Act. Every other citizen and corporation in New South Wales is bound by the Environmental Protection Act and we are asking, `Why should the FAC be placed above the laws which the rest of us are forced to comply with?'.

It is an exercise of unsurpassed cynicism that the Federal Government has here produced a regulation which would subvert the legal processes of appeal to the New South Wales Land and Environment Court. These regulations were put forward as a desperate attempt to circumvent the local government appeal to the Land and Environment Court which is scheduled for hearing later this month.

As I mentioned earlier, we have seen the Federal Government use this device of simply exempting their bodies from the State planning and environment laws in relation to ANSTO at Lucas Heights. We saw it attempt to do this successfully with the support of the Opposition back in June of this year in a move which was greeted by outrage by State governments all across Australia. Here the Federal Government, with the collusion of the Opposition, is once again seeking to put its own activities above laws which would otherwise apply.

A lot of concern has been expressed about the environmental impact statement produced in respect of the third runway. It is worth mentioning and noting that that EIS was produced under Commonwealth environmental planning laws, not State planning laws. The concern that Botany Municipal Council and other councils have raised before the Land and Environment Court is that really this issue should have been assessed under the New South Wales planning and environment laws which are in fact much stronger than those in place at a Federal level. That has not happened.

A lot of concern has been expressed about whether the EIS has in fact dealt with all the concerns raised by the community. For example, it has been cited that the draft EIS is inadequate on a number of points, including its failure to take account of a $400m reduction in property values caused by new and added aircraft noise. It is believed that the draft EIS has failed to take into account the need to spend at least $300m at Kingsford-Smith Airport if downgrading the east-west runway is not realistic, as appears to be the case.

It has been suggested that the EIS fails to take into account the need to spend at least $100m to satisfy the Civil Aviation Authority call for land reclamation to avoid the greatly increased risk of bird strike causing aircraft crashes. In addition, the EIS has failed to take into account the millions of dollars required to compensate people for relocating their homes or soundproofing them against aircraft noise which will greatly increase as a result of the third runway.

Of course, the issue that the Botany Municipal Council is most concerned about is that of the dredging of Botany Bay where it has been revealed that some 15 million cubic metres of sediment will be taken from Botany Bay in order to assist with the construction of the runway. That may have absolutely devastating effects on the environment of the Botany Bay region. The FAC wishes to go ahead and dredge Botany Bay despite the fact that previous dredging of the bay in the region of the Penrhyn Estuary was stopped by the Department of Public Works because it contained toxic waste. This waste included heavy metals.

The concern of the local community groups is that this issue has not been adequately covered by the environmental impact statement. The 15 million cubic metres of material that the FAC intends to dredge may well include similar concentrations of toxic material. The dredging of the bay will also destroy an area which is recognised as the second largest fish breeding area in New South Wales and one of the largest oyster farming areas in the State. That is an enormously important primary industry to the region of Botany Bay which could be totally destroyed by the dredging of 15 million cubic metres of sediment.

It is also worth nothing that the Kurnell area is an important bird migration region. Whether we like it or not, those birds are there, they have been going there for centuries, and they will continue to go there until the environment is so devastated and destroyed that they will have to move elsewhere. That is an issue that also needs to be put on the table.

I do believe that it is time to reassess the validity of having a major airport in a metropolitan area in light of the recent crash which occurred in Amsterdam. This was a very tragic accident which saw at least 250 people killed. It has even been suggested that the number of people killed by that accident may never be fully known because of the number of illegal immigrants who were living in that area of Amsterdam.

That was a tragic accident, but it is the sort of accident that community groups concerned about the third runway have warned could happen here in Australia. Yet we are considering increasing traffic at an airport located effectively in the middle of a major city. It is important that that issue be reassessed in the light of this tragic accident. The Citizens Airport Environment Association put out a press statement yesterday claiming that such an accident was highly possible in the Sydney region. The press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: The EIS for the third runway points out that, rather than reducing risk north of the airport, residents of Marrickville, for example, will be subject to a risk of death from an air crash about 2.5 times greater than at present.
That is if the third runway is constructed. The press release goes on:

In working papers for the draft EIS, Marrickville was shown as having a current risk of 42 fatalities per million per year by the year 2010 if a third runway is constructed. This risk would have increased to 103 per million per year.
It continues:
