This massively exceeds New South Wales Government recommendations for risk criteria for land use safety planning, as specified in Department of Planning publication Hazardous Industry Planning Advisory Paper No. 4 1990.

PARA.TAB: The paper specifies that the risk criteria for residential land use is one fatality per million per year. We are now talking of a possible increase in fatalities to 103 per million per year. The third runway will therefore mean that residents north of Sydney Airport will face a risk of death from air crash over 100 times greater than New South Wales Department of Planning guidelines. Hospitals and schools will have a risk imposed upon them 200 times greater than the guidelines recommend.

SPEECH.PARA: These statistics do not take into account possible multiplier effects such as a crash into the huge chemical and petrochemical storage sites adjacent to the airport. It should be recognised that an air crash into those important petrochemical facilities would be absolutely disastrous, not only for Kurnell but for all of Cronulla and that region of Sydney as a whole. That is something that I think local residents have every right to be very concerned about.

PARA.TAB: It is our concern that, if these regulations were passed, State environment law would become irrelevant. They establish a precedent; in fact, that precedent has already been established by the passage of the ANSTO Amendment Bill last June. It establishes a precedent for circumventing environmental legislation requirements for any project, any time, anywhere. The FAC has been given the power to shop around for the environmental standard that best suits its empire building.

We have said that if the Federal Airports Corporation believes that the environmental impact statement it has produced is totally adequate, it has nothing to fear from having this matter heard in the Land and Environment Court in New South Wales. However, if the EIS is found to have been inadequate, then of course it has something to fear. That is why we believe the Federal Government has moved in this way to ensure that the FAC will be exempt from those planning and environment laws that apply to everyone else.

Despite the potential to destroy the ecology of Botany Bay, this Government is now trying to regulate to allow the FAC to do what it likes and not to be accountable to the people who will suffer at its hands. I draw the Senate's attention to the unanimous objection to the FAC's plans of the municipal councils in the area, environmental, social and recreational groups and representative groups from the fishing industry. The move allows the FAC to decimate a sensitive environment and to disregard the objections of citizens of New South Wales and other concerned Australians that did not begin with this underhand attempt to put the FAC outside the law.

The third runway assessment report was railroaded into Cabinet by Ros Kelly. The public was denied an opportunity to comment on what is one of the major urban environmental issues in Australia. It certainly is the major environmental issue facing Sydney at this time. The report, when it was finally made public, made it patently clear that the FAC does not care about the environment or about the many people whose lives will be affected. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The FAC puts priority on minimising inconvenience to passengers and costs to airlines rather than environmental quality north of Sydney Airport.

But the FAC is not honouring its own priorities. By dredging the bay, the FAC is placing airline passengers and staff at greater safety risks. The Seamen's Union has brought to the attention of the Democrats' leader, Senator Coulter, its serious concerns about the safety of air travellers should a sea rescue ever have to take place in the bay.

PARA.TAB: I would hope that the Opposition would recognise what a serious attack these regulations are on States rights. I know that last time I spoke on this matter, Senator Cook quite rightly pointed out to me that the Democrats have never really been big supporters of States rights. We certainly believe that many areas of government activity would benefit from having a more coordinated approach across the States with the Federal Government on a whole range of legislative issues, and the environment is certainly one of those.

We believe that certainly business and commercial activity would greatly be enhanced by the standardisation of a range of laws across the States to ensure that business operates in the same kind of regulatory environment from east to west and from north to south. But what we have at the moment is a whole range of different laws covering the same issues in a range of different States and this makes business very difficult to operate in this country. It is time that the States got together—I know there has been some progress on this but it has been at a snail's pace—to ensure that we are operating in the same regulatory climate right across Australia.

The very important area of environmental law would benefit from a more standard approach to legislating within the States and with the Commonwealth. But what we have at the moment, both in environmental law, business regulation, workers compensation, stamp duties and a whole range of other State charges, is a huge hotchpotch of legislation which differs from State to State and which makes governing Australia very difficult. We would ask the Government to accelerate that process to ensure that there is some certainty in legislating and some certainty in the business climate around Australia. That is not happening at this time.

But be that as it may. I am very concerned that this Government is arrogantly overriding the States. It is arrogantly saying, `We will simply exempt ourselves from those laws because we do not like them. Because we feel that we have complied with the Commonwealth law, therefore the State laws do not need to apply'. As a result, we are seeing an increase in this activity by government which started with the ANSTO Act and has now been proliferated by these regulations.

I ask the Federal Government: how many times are we going to see Ministers come into this place with regulations which will simply exempt their own statutory corporations and business enterprises from laws that everybody else must comply with? I think the Opposition should be very concerned about this development. It should be very concerned that the power of the States to legislate in areas of their responsibility is being overridden by a government that is arrogant enough to think that it does not need to comply with laws that everybody else must comply with.

I would ask the Opposition to look very seriously at what is happening here. It should ask the Government when will it stop; when will it end? Or does the Opposition itself plan simply to legislate over the States in order to push through its programs when it gets into government?

On that note, I would once again plead with the Opposition to recognise and understand what is happening here. We are seeing an ongoing erosion of the legislative functions of the States. This is happening without consultation. The fact that all of the State governments have joined in an action in the High Court to prevent the Federal Government from doing this is indicative of the concern that they have about the Federal Government's attempt simply to exempt the FAC from laws which would otherwise apply to its activities.

I have therefore moved that these regulations be disallowed. They are an attempt to place the FAC outside the law, and they disregard State legislation that is designed to protect the environment. These regulations will allow the FAC, with a policy of environmental carnage that will decimate local marine industries, to simply continue unabated in Sydney. These regulations are an underhand attempt to silence the voice of protest by concerned Australians. I call on the Senate to support my motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a great deal of respect for Senator Sowada. She has again today delivered to the Senate an articulate and comprehensive defence of her position. Unfortunately, I have to say that it is not a position with which the Government agrees. We ask the Senate not to be enjoined by her to defeat these regulations but indeed to support them, to carry them and to allow the third runway development in New South Wales at Mascot airport to go ahead.

PARA.TAB: I do that for a whole host of reasons, the principal one being this: in looking at sensible airport planning in Australia, a decision has been made to develop a third runway at the Mascot airport, but not at any cost. If this is done, there should be sufficient environmental safeguards and protections to ensure that the local environment, particularly that of Botany Bay, can be reasonably protected in the circumstances.

This is an important development, and one which has a huge economic impact for Australia. Sydney is the major gateway to this continent for all overseas travel. The facilities at Mascot can be upgraded at reasonable cost to ensure improved safety standards above the very high safety standards that already operate for that airport. In that way, the most reasonable outcome for the community can be achieved. That is a sensible planning-project development-air traffic management option.

But we do not do these things simply because all those criteria are satisfied; we as a government have a serious and demonstrated concern about the environmental impact of development. We have conducted an EIS—an environmental impact statement—to see what the impact of developing a third runway at Mascot will be. Having said that, the environmental impact statement has returned a finding which enables us to proceed to develop that third runway with confidence and a huge degree of security based on scientific research and understanding. The environmental impact will be minimal, and the dangers forecast by those who oppose this development are not real.

This debate ought to be brought into this context at the beginning: almost every major development in this country that is of significant economic proportions has some impact on the environment in some way. In a community that is concerned about environmental values, and rightly, questions get raised about the competing values in terms of the environment and the development.

In this case, the circumstances can be fairly described as these: a group of people, mostly Sydney residents, are, in many cases for understandable reasons, opposed to the development of the third runway. Without being trite, those reasons are the NIMBY reasons—the not in my backyard reasons, or the do it somewhere else but do not do it here approach. Stemming from that motive, a whole array of oppositions have been argued. The Federal Government has considered those arguments and decided that, in all the circumstances, the best way to proceed is by extending that third runway at Mascot.

We are supported in that belief by the New South Wales Government. I point out in passing that we are a Labor government, it is a Liberal government and we are both of the same view on this issue. From the point of view of what is the most sensible development, we can claim a majority position between us. In managerial terms, this is a most sensible position. Nonetheless, citizens and local government authorities are mounting a legal action to prevent the third runway from going ahead. In those circumstances, any argument that can be used as an obstruction is seized upon, thrown up and then used to try to block development.

A lot of the environmental arguments, with the greatest of respect to those who have propounded them, ought to be approached from that point of view. Their arguments are being utilised as convenient arguments, not necessarily to deal with the problems they are alleged to stem from but to prevent the development of the project at all. In saying that, I do not want to be uncharitable; I am sure that there are a number of people who have raised the environmental arguments out of serious and conscientious concern for the environment. Those people who have done that would raise those arguments anyway because, in the main, they believe that almost any development has an adverse impact—as I have said, every development has some impact of some sort—and that those developments should be set aside. We do not have that view. We recognise their view; we respect their right to hold it. We disagree and, being a government, we intend to implement our governmental authority in these circumstances.

The argument is centring around the question of whether or not an appropriate environmental clearance has been made. That argument has particular force because there are three levels of government in this country—national, State and local. We have conducted a Federal environmental impact study considering all of the issues. The argument now being raised is that it should have been a State one because there are conflicting areas of authority between the Commonwealth and the State; Botany Bay is a State jurisdiction, so it should have been a State EIS. Doubtless, if that argument fails, as may be the case, there will be contending arguments that there was some local government involvement.

What this argument is about in one respect is twisting on the horns of the dilemma of the three levels of government who has the authority and which is the right governmental agency to make these decisions. It is exactly because of those reasons that the Commonwealth conducted its environmental impact study in close collaboration with the New South Wales Government. The plan that springs from that study exceeds or matches State standards in every respect. Mostly it exceeds all of the State standards; it never goes below any of the State standards.

The environmental impact statement—I speak as a former Minister for Resources and someone with some knowledge of these things—was one of the most comprehensive ever conducted in Australia for a major project. We are a government that is proud of its green credentials and its environmental position. We do not want to lose that pride by shoddy workmanship. We set very high standards for this environmental impact statement. It has matched very high standards. It is one of the most comprehensive ever. The statement has dealt with coastal hydrodynamics, the effect of the development on the tide flows in and out of Botany Bay, the impact on water quality within the area, and—the question raised by Senator Sowada in her address—the issue of the disturbance of sediments, including heavy metals.

Those matters have been scientifically studied, analysed and reported on. Conclusions have been reached about them which do not justify what I might, with respect, call the alarmist view that there are serious concerns about the spread of heavy metals. The findings do not support that alarmist presentation. We have looked at the potential damage to the seagrass beds in Botany Bay and made evaluations. We have looked at—this was a matter raised by Senator Sowada—the impact on fish species and other marine fauna and organisms. The conclusions—these are not conclusions by government or by politicians acting out of political expediency; these are the conclusions of the scientists who have made the study, so to that extent they have to be seen as scientific—are that, with safeguards, it is reasonable to proceed with the development of this runway. When all the evidence is in, as it now is, I think we are bound to do that.

There is one other point that I should make. This is a Federal Government development. Why would Federal Government law not be applied? The Federal Airports Corporation is an agency of the Federal Government charged with the responsibility of commercially managing airports in this country and doing it in an appropriate way with regard to safety and the general environment, including the level of noise and sound and proper operational practice.

While one environmental impact statement has been made—not one by each government—it has been made in cooperation with the State Government and is more comprehensive than would have been the case if it had been done at a State level. It folded in to its survey the State concerns as raised by the duly recognised authorities. The conclusion is that the runway can proceed with the proper safeguards. The proposal for development is consistent with those findings.

In those circumstances we would be in contempt of our responsibility if we did not then proceed. It is hard to escape a conclusion that the reason why some of these matters are being raised now is to delay the process, making the project less economic and causing a consideration of having to do other things as stopgaps. The eternal reality remains that Sydney is the gateway to Australia for most international flights. There is an obligation to ensure that the airports can accommodate that traffic. The best and most reasonable way of doing it is by developing a third runway.

That leads me to the horrific crash in Amsterdam. The issue that is being raised by Senator Sowada is that, by concentrating airport movements over Sydney at Mascot close to or in part of the metropolitan area, we will risk in Sydney an Amsterdam type crash. I do not want to take from the Dutch in any way their proud record of air safety. But Australia's record of air safety is better than or at least equal to any in the world. We do not need to doff our hats to anyone when it comes to the level of air safety in Australia. So we have a very proud record to stand by, a record enforced by very competent technical people.

What is the truth, in any case, about Mascot? The third runway will enable more take-offs over Botany Bay, a non-residential area, than over the residential areas of Sydney. The recommendations are that there will be 86 per cent more take-offs and landings over Botany Bay than there would have been without the third runway. That is a pretty impressive change. It means fewer aircraft over residential areas and a lessening of the risk. If there is an air mishap, in such grievous circumstances it is more likely that it would be over the sea in Botany Bay than over a metropolitan area in Sydney.

So, from the point of view of the Amsterdam argument, the best way of preventing an Amsterdam type crash is to develop a third runway. It is certainly not to withhold the development of a third runway. The likelihood of a crash in a densely populated metropolitan area will be less with the option of a third runway than it would be without it. I think that is an important consideration.

There are perhaps a number of other points I should make, but in general terms the major issues here have been summarised. It is fair to say that the Federal Airports Corporation's regulations established a licensing regime to ensure that contractors working on the third runway construction site and dredging sites in Botany Bay are required to comply with the findings of the EIS. They are required by law to do that. That enforces those standards and ensures that the work will be done properly with due regard to the sensitive environment.

As I have said, those standards are a direct outcome of the extensive environmental assessment of the third runway project and they include measures for preventing and mitigating any adverse environmental impact effects as set out in the environmental impact statement itself, as set out in the recommendations made by my colleague Ros Kelly, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, and as set out in the Botany Bay environmental management plan stage 1.

I also note that the consortium engaged by the Federal Airports Corporation to undertake the runway construction project, that is to say, the managing contractor, is also required to observe strict environmental standards under the terms and conditions of that contract. The contract has been let, writing into the contract those standards as requirements for performance. The environmental standards demanded of the contractors working on this project, as I said before, are at least equal to and, in many cases, exceed the requirements that would apply under the State laws.

The Botany Bay environmental management plan stage 1 was developed by a steering committee comprising the Federal Airports Corporation and the New South Wales Department of Planning—joint Federal-State cooperation. A key feature of the plan is a range of specialist environmental studies that were undertaken which provide baseline data to assist in the development of strategies to manage any environmental impacts during the construction phase and in the longer term. The study of the third runway represents one of the most comprehensive undertaken. It deals with all of those matters that I have referred to. It deals with a broad range of issues, including a thorough and extensive examination of the environmental effects of dredging sand from Botany Bay.

Because the environmental impact statement on the third runway was prepared in accordance with Federal environmental assessment legislation, not State legislation, the Federal Airports Corporation's regulations are also intended to remove any doubt about the extent to which New South Wales laws apply to the construction of the runway. The draft environmental impact statement provided a statement on the relationship between the Commonwealth and New South Wales environmental assessment processes. It summed up the position by stating that the State legislation would not apply to the construction of the proposed runway on Commonwealth or Federal Airports Corporation land.

The Federal Airports Corporation's intention was to implement measures to ensure the project remained under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth legislation only where clearly stated in the supplement to the EIS. Therefore, it is not sustainable to say there has been an attempt to conceal these plans. Some have claimed that these plans have been concealed; that is not a sustainable allegation. Furthermore, the measures were discussed with and subsequently endorsed by senior New South Wales Government officials before being implemented.

There is little doubt that the environmental impact statement would have adequately met the technical requirements applicable to an EIS prepared under New South Wales legislation. The New South Wales Department of Planning was consulted by Ros Kelly's Department, DASET, in the drafting of the guidelines for the preparation of the EIS, and there was extensive consultation with New South Wales departments and agencies during the draft EIS review process.

The third runway project has already been subject to one of the most thorough environmental impact assessments ever undertaken in Australia. The FAC has complied with all the assessment requirements of the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. To submit the project to further delay for further environmental assessment would simply be a negative approach to this issue.

I ask that the Senate allow the regulations to stand and that this important development, which will facilitate aircraft safety and movement in Australia—particularly in Sydney—and be a sensible development, conducted in a way that meets proper environmental standards, be allowed to go forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few minutes ago the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) made reference to the possibility that Senator Sowada's motion was simply another delaying tactic in what has effectively been a very long saga. That was my concern as well. There has been an extraordinarily long gestation period for this airport. It goes back to 1983 when the Hawke Government cancelled the coalition plans to commence construction of a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport. Then six years passed and we had the Hawke Government announcement in March 1989 that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the economically rational option is to build a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport, subject to an environmental impact statement, and proceed with the development of Badgerys Creek but not on a fast track basis.

Then, on 20 September 1990, we had a draft environmental impact statement released for public comment. On 18 January 1991, 1,897 submissions were passed to the Federal Airports Corporation for consideration. Then, also in September 1991, a supplement to the draft environmental impact statement was presented. In November 1991, the Government finally announced approval for that third runway.

PARA.TAB: I do not need to canvass that environmental impact statement in great detail. The Minister gave it a fair amount of consideration in his speech and broadly I would agree with most of the things he said about it. Looking at the question of dredging, which has been a major issue under debate, the Commonwealth has moved to give the Federal Airports Corporation the right to dredge for the runway without having to comply with the environmental assessment processes of the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act. But, as the Minister said just a minute ago, the draft EIS said that the New South Wales Environmental Planning and Assessment Act of 1979 does not apply to the proposed construction of a third runway on Commonwealth or FAC land.

There seem to have been submissions which suggested that this was not correct, but in fact it is the case that the Commonwealth has, if you like, the right to overrule the State laws. But, in fact, that is not the way it has turned out anyway. The dredging issues were considered in part E of the supplement to the draft environmental impact statement which, as I say, was released nearly 12 months ago. That part included consideration of the fill requirements, the on-shore sand sources and the impact on Botany Bay, including the coastal hydrodynamics of Botany Bay. It looked at the potential erosion of the foreshores as a result of changes to wave climate caused by dredging and runway construction. It looked at the marine ecology of Botany Bay. The Minister mentioned fish, but it included references to the impact on water quality, sediments and seagrasses as well as fish, and it looked at dredging generally.

Just how much more in the way of such studies do the Democrats demand? Perhaps they will not be satisfied no matter what happens. Let us look at the provision being developed for the environmental management plan. It is to be implemented by the Federal Airports Corporation and the relevant State agencies. For instance, it says in appendix C:

SPEECH.PARA: This Environmental Management Plan will be developed and implemented jointly by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and relevant State agencies. The FAC is committed to the mitigation of such environmental impacts on Botany Bay as are determined to be attributable to the construction and operation of the Third Runway at Sydney Airport.
It could not be much clearer than that. It says further:

The objectives of the environmental management plan are to project, restore and enhance, as appropriate, the environmental qualities of Botany Bay (especially the water quality and the aquatic and terrestrial habitats for flora and fauna in and around the bay) in relation to any adverse impacts of the Third Runway.

So all of these things—the environmental impact statement and the processes that went into the consultations and submissions, and the establishment of the mechanisms for the development of an environmental management plan, its objectives and the way it is to operate—still do not satisfy the Democrats. Once again, they are finding that their principles are flexible to the extent that, while they are not normally concerned about such parochial matters as States rights, they suddenly discover that State rights are an important issue to flog in relation to this airport—despite the fact that the New South Wales Government is keenly and actively contributing to the establishment of a third runway and is very keen to see it happen.

PARA.TAB: One has to look at some political issues. As I have said, what more do the Democrats want and why do they want it? How satisfied would they be if another mechanism was introduced? Just why are they trying to delay this vital project? One just has to wonder at their motives. They seem insistent on joining Labor's troglodytes in their opposition to the third runway. In saying that I am referring to such people as Messrs McLeay, Punch, Brereton and Baldwin, and also to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Ms McHugh, all of whom have seen it to be in their personal political interests to oppose that runway.

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this third runway must proceed. It is not that the Opposition—or even the Government for that matter, to give it credit—has been unwilling, unready or unprepared to listen to people's genuine concerns about that runway. But there are other considerations that apply, which I think perhaps the Democrats are not prepared to give credence to.

The construction of that third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport is the most important infrastructure decision of the Federal Government to date. Goodness knows, we in the Opposition have been very critical over a long time of the paralysis of this Government in developing major infrastructure projects. On this one, it may have taken nearly a decade but it finally got there. If the third runway is not built by 1995, Sydney will be unable to handle effectively any further increases in passengers, so the whole economy of Australia will suffer. Sydney Airport must expand to cope with the forecast growth in tourism. The third runway will reduce the forecast aircraft delays by 90 per cent by the year 2010. If nothing is done, those aircraft delays could cost airline operators $695m a year by the year 2010.

We have heard hearts and violins today coming from the Democrats about aircraft safety. It seemed to be quite a convenient moment to refer to aircraft accidents. Perhaps they are not prepared to acknowledge, as the Minister has just done, that aircraft safety will be enhanced by a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport. There will be a lessening of the risk with that third runway, as indeed there will be with a new airport at Badgerys Creek, which we are pushing strongly.

The impact on tourism is not to be neglected. These are important issues which the Democrats are not prepared to address. The increased capacity of that airport will create 40,000 new jobs in New South Wales, at a time when we have nearly one million unemployed. Surely that is a major consideration for us all. In addition, there is the contribution by international visitors in badly needed increased spending in our country. Peter O'Clery, the chief executive of the Australian Tourism Industry Association, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Failure to proceed with the runway will cause increased congestion to the point where by 1995 flights will have to be diverted regularly from Sydney.

I do not wish to delay the Senate longer. I sum up by saying that the coalition's position is basically that the third runway should commence immediately because of the demands of the aviation industry, the need for growth in tourism, and the safety requirements as well. Those aviation and tourism concerns are vital to the revival of Australia's economy and our country's future.

PARA.TAB: We also believe strongly that private enterprise should be permitted to begin construction at Badgerys Creek at the same time as the third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport. We believe most sincerely that the environmental matters have been given thorough attention and that the regulations the Democrats would disallow will effectively require the Federal Airports Corporation to act in accordance with the State requirements. In fact, in the House of Representatives on 10 September, Mr Beazley said:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, if honourable members look at the schedule attached to the regulations, they will see a whole series of requirements upon the FAC to act in a manner that effectively conforms with the State law and also requires them to cooperate effectively with the various State authorities.
One would find that hard to believe if one had heard only Senator Sowada's speech. That is why the Opposition has not felt able to support the disallowance motion proposed by the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the motion by Senator Sowada to disallow the regulations that would remove the requirement that the Federal Airports Corporation be subject to State law, specifically in relation to the proposed third runway development at Sydney Airport, a matter which Senator Sowada notes is also before the courts. It is not so much a question of whether State law should or should not apply but of whether the local people, through the recognised court system, have an opportunity to put their case fairly.

PARA.TAB: I was very surprised to hear the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) argue in relation to an increase in safety, a matter that has just been taken up by the Opposition spokesperson on this matter. Senator Sowada earlier pointed out that the estimate is that the risk would actually increase as a consequence of the increased number of flights. I was also surprised to hear Senator Cook talk about taking off over Botany Bay. I think he would know that in the Amsterdam crash the aircraft took off quite successfully and circled around and was in the process of attempting to re-land when the accident occurred and it crashed into that building.

I was also rather surprised to hear Senator Cook dismiss the figures given by Senator Sowada of the risk of 100 deaths per million population. As Minister for Industrial Relations and certainly as somebody formerly in the trade union movement, he would know that in occupational health, when people are exposed to hazardous substances such as carcinogens, the recognised standards are between one in a million and 10 in a million, or one in 100,000. That is the recognised standard. In that situation, the worker who goes into that potentially hazardous occupation understands that there is a risk involved. He also understands that there is some benefit in being exposed to that one in a million or one in 100,000 risk.

In the case of the risk in relation to air crashes over Sydney, most of those people who are exposed get no benefit whatsoever. They are simply people who will be arbitrarily under a flight path when an aircraft is in difficulties. Under those circumstances, I think the figure Senator Sowada quoted of 100 per million, or roughly one in 10,000, is somewhere between 10 and 100 times higher than would be expected in occupational health. In those circumstances, I find Senator Cook's acceptance rather strange.

The other point I want to pick up is that last night Senator Kemp, who seems to be the Opposition Minister for Democrat bashing, chose to talk about the number of occasions on which the Democrats have voted with Labor and compare that with the number of times we have voted with the Opposition. On the same day, Senator Short put out a press release headed `Democrats Destroy Coalition's Major Senate Initiative'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to the following recent comments by the boards of leading Australian companies: A V Jennings, `Recovery could be up to five years away'; Pacific Dunlop, `Economic recovery will not occur until 1995'; BHP, `We expect the economic environment, both domestic and internationally, to remain subdued in 1993'; and to similar expressions of concern by North Broken Hill Peko and BTR Nylex. In the light of these statements by major companies, does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister's statement yesterday that, `We were out of recession long ago'; and will he advise the Senate as to which Australian businesses support this view?

—The Prime Minister's statement was made in the context of a lot of debate here about the nature of a technical recession and we were undoubtedly in one for four quarters. We now have a growth rate in the economy of something in the order of 1 1/2 per cent and it is certainly true that the economy is now growing.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the international scene where the OECD and the IMF, for example, were predicting international growth rates of 3 per cent through the OECD, for example, and now have hauled that back to 2 per cent, we see something of the same perspective in the analysis which has been done in respect of growth in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this to do with whether we are out of recession and for how long?
—I do not need any help from Senator Alston. The 1 1/2 per cent growth rate, which we believe will be sustained and improved, is growth in the Australian economy.
—Have we had a recession or not?
—Senator Alston, be patient. You might get a question later.

—I do not know what comfort we draw, if any, from the comments which were published at the weekend by the various business people Senator Short has referred to, but a lot of that analysis is dependent on growth or lack of growth in the international economy. If we look at the businesses concerned we see the reasons for that. Our situation in Australia is somewhat different from the international protections because of—

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, do I have to put up with this all the time?
—No, you do not have to put up with it, Senator Button. The Leader of the Opposition will remain quiet.

—Our position is somewhat different because of the high export activity of a whole range of Australian companies, particularly in the region where we have high growth rates in other countries. So our situation is a little different. There is a tendency sometimes for despondency in business. I notice that none of these businesses say that if the Opposition were elected their forecast would change.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —None of the people Senator Short quoted said that, not one of them. We have to recognise in all these things that these are long term projections which, in our view, are on the gloomy side.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of that incredible answer, does the Minister's answer mean therefore that he disagrees yet again with Australian business leaders who state quite unequivocally that economic recovery is several years away? I ask the Minister again whether he will advise the Senate which Australian businesses support his and the Prime Minister's view.

—The view I put just a minute ago was that there is currently growth in the Australian economy. It is slower than we would wish, but it is steady and will continue. I do not think there are any business people who disagree with that view. What they are concerned about understandably in their comments is that they are not expecting a return to the high levels of growth which we had in the 1980s; they are not talking about that. They do not see that happening, and I understand that. That is all I am saying.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he is aware of remarks made by John Howard, the Opposition's industrial relations spokesperson, at the Australian Council of Social Service's annual congress on 2 October, where he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The most important message coming from the Opposition in the area of industrial relations . . . .. is the quite dramatic proposal to move away entirely from the concept of a fixed working week.
Can the Minister advise the Senate whether there are any barriers to companies abolishing a fixed working week in the Government's workplace bargaining system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is done properly with the normal checks and balances one would expect in a civilised society, the answer to that question is no, there are no obstacles. It is passing strange, I might say, that Mr Howard, in talking to ACOSS, has tried to hold himself out to be the friend of families by talking about family flexibility in working hours, because the Opposition joined with those among the employer organisations at the time this Government supported unions in the parental leave case to introduce the very flexibility into the system that Mr Howard is claiming now he will introduce should he ever have the unlikely possibility of coming to power in this country.

PARA.TAB: The flexibility exists now, and the flexibility exists through the system now because of dicta laid down in a landmark case in the Commission two years ago, which the Opposition was opposed to at the time. But let me illustrate that that is not just a simple matter of fact; it is a simple matter of practical usage by a number of respectable employer organisations in Australia at the moment.

For example, the National Australia Bank and the Australia and New Zealand Bank have both developed agreements which allow workers, in consultations with their supervisors, to choose any combination of working hours that they want provided that they work at least 38 hours per week in the case of the National Australia Bank and 152 hours per month in the case of the ANZ—great flexibility. I referred to that in this chamber in terms of how, under our workers and family responsibilities commitments, we have encouraged employers and unions to blend family needs with working life.

The Sheraton Towers agreement has folded ordinary time earnings and penalty rates into one annual salary for all workers regardless of the hours worked. The Coles supermarket agreement, which covers some 35,000 workers in Australia, provides wage increases for workers in return for greater flexibility in working hours and reductions in night shift penalty rates, which are allowing many supermarkets to open on a 24-hour basis. Coles wants to be open all hours. It has concluded a workplace agreement enabling hours flexibility with its work force in order to do that.

Workers at Southern Cross machinery have agreed to arrange their working hours so that they receive the one weekly salary by working less than 38 hours per week in the winter down time and around 42.5 hours per week when work picks up in the summer. Those are good examples to illustrate that the flexibility which Mr Howard proposes to deliver is there and is being utilised by Australian companies across the board.

What does this establish? It establishes that Mr Howard has a vested interest in running around this country misleading Australians into believing our system is inflexible, that it does not have the flexibility necessary and that he will somehow have the elixir of flexibility when a quiet revolution has been undergone in the Australian workplace in which those flexibilities are being utilised to the benefit of the people with the proper checks and balances necessary in a civilised society.

That means that if there is a question of the type of agreement, it ought to be put through the Industrial Relations Commission so that the umpire can have a look at it, to make sure this is not an exploitative agreement, that this is indeed a constructive agreement on which all parties can build a better workplace relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the Minister to Mr Keating's claim yesterday that we were out of recession long ago. If that is so, how is it that there are 950,000 Australians officially unemployed and a further three-quarters of a million hidden and underemployed? There are 680,000 children who are still living in families where neither parent has employment. St Vincent de Paul, the Brotherhood of Saint Laurence and the Salvation Army are still receiving unprecedented demands for help. In light of these figures, I ask the Minister: do you share the Prime Minister's view that we were out of recession long ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button in fact answered this question as the first question of Question Time. It was certainly phrased differently than it is now phrased; it was phrased with reference to companies, but the point of the question was the same. The Prime Minister was referring, of course, when he made those remarks, to economic indicators which indicate, technically or otherwise, the state of the economy. What is a well-known fact of economic life, but may well have defeated Senator Crane, is that the levels of employment and unemployment lag behind other growth indicators. I have constantly said in this place, representing this Government and, in particular, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, that we take no joy whatsoever from the level of unemployment in this society, but that we do have—
—You caused it.

—We did not cause it; there is an international recession, and that international recession has afflicted all economies in the world and we are not separate from the global environment in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators on my left will come to order.

—The issue has to be: who has policies to put Australians back in work soonest? In terms of that policy comparison, there is no argument. The accolade rests with this Government. The One Nation statement proposes to invest in public infrastructure development, which will be the linchpin or the locomotive for widespread economic growth in this country. The gains of that are starting to appear. That is one of the reasons why we are out of recession. The Budget which followed on from that, not to mention the youth summit initiatives which followed from that, ensures that we not only have a strategy for putting Australians back in work, but we have a strategy which is a responsible one for ensuring that those who are out of work, particularly the long term unemployed, have access to training to upgrade their skills to make them more relevant to the emerging economy.

PARA.TAB: If one looks at the Opposition's package of so-called initiatives, what is most notable about those is a kicking out, and, I might say, a fairly thorough kicking out, of all the supports that there really are for training related to re-employment prospects and for training for people in employment, and any strategy at all for putting people back in work.

There is the allegation that there will be two million jobs by the end of this century, but that is an allegation, a claim or an assertion not based on any papers associated with the consumption tax package, and it is an allegation or assertion not based on any facts or studies by the so-called relevant consulting economists, either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of the release of 1991-92 figures indicating the financial results of Qantas and the levels of international air traffic to Australia? Can the Minister indicate how these results compare with other ICAO countries?
—Mr Deputy President—
—What has this to do with what John Button was just saying about the recession?

—In response to that interjection, there is indeed an international recession in Great Britain, Germany, the United States, Canada and Japan. That is why this particular result is so pleasing, because one of the depressed areas for some time has been international aviation. In the face of those results around the world, it is particularly pleasing that today Qantas has announced an after tax profit of $137m for the 1991-92 financial year. Most importantly, the airline group achieved a pre-tax profit before abnormal items of $103m compared with a loss of $158m the previous year.

PARA.TAB: This major turnaround has been achieved largely as a result of significant cost reductions and increased productivity resulting from the major restructuring of the airline group. The performance by Qantas is also commendable, given that it was achieved against a background of a highly competitive operating environment which was significantly affected by depressed international trading conditions. Most other international carriers have recorded major operating losses over the past year.

I am aware of figures supplied by the airlines to the Department of Transport and Communications outlining that Australian international air traffic continued to grow in 1991-92. The Australian international scheduled airline passenger market grew by 7.2 per cent in 1991-92. Although the result cannot be directly compared with ICAO traffic reports, it can be noted that the latest ICAO estimate for 1991 indicated an overall decline in passenger traffic of 3.5 per cent on the previous year. Therefore, Australia's growth performance is even more creditable when viewed against this background.

In the decade ending June 1992, international traffic to and from Australia grew at an average annual rate of 7.8 per cent. This compares more than favourably with a total world compound growth rate of 4.9 per cent and shows that Australia continues to be a popular world tourist destination.

These results will be further enhanced by the international aviation initiatives announced by the Government, including multiple designation of Australian carriers and the benefits of a strong combined Qantas-Australian airline. Recognition of Australia's major role in world aviation was recently demonstrated with the re-election of Australia to the category 1 council of ICAO for the next three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the Australian Federal Police aware of investigations linking Daikyo with a Japanese investor, Mr Kotani, a bankrupt, who is facing charges in Japan of manipulating stock prices and attempted blackmail? Did Mr Kotani control a company called Kohshin and has the Daikyo chairman, Mr Yokoyama, ever been a director of Kohshin Australia? Finally, is this the same Mr Yokoyama who was identified in the Brisbane District Court last year as giving over $110,000 in political donations to the then Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, shortly before the 1986 Queensland election?

—I am advised that the AFP is aware of investigations being conducted by the Japanese authorities into allegations concerning stock market irregularities. I emphasise that they are aware only of Japanese stock exchange investigations. I think what lay behind the question was some sort of inference that perhaps the AFP itself was conducting such investigations. AFP investigations have not linked a senior executive of Daikyo with a high ranking Yakuza member, as was alleged or implied in some questions asked by Senator Kernot a week or so ago, and to which I will give answers after Question Time.

PARA.TAB: Mr Mitsuhiro Kotani ceased being a director of Kohshin Australia Pty Ltd on 10 September 1990. Mr Shuji Yokoyama was a director of Kohshin Australia. As to the third part of the honourable senator's question, which I did not get down in detail, I believe that to be a State matter and there is nothing on which I am able to immediately comment.

In general, it has to be said that the responsibility of the Minister for Justice is to deal with those matters which the AFP might be investigating because it is alleged that a Federal offence has occurred. That is the role of the Australian Federal Police and Federal authorities. It has become apparent over the last few weeks that this chamber is being used, perhaps because of a lack of Democrat numbers in the Queensland Legislative Assembly, as a vehicle for raising matters which are properly matters of State jurisdiction. Therefore, I think Senator Kernot will continually be disappointed in the scope of answers I am able to give her because so much of what she raises falls within State law enforcement jurisdiction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not within the Minister's jurisdiction to advise the Parliament whether the Australian Federal Police actually liaises with any of the State law enforcement bodies? Surely the answer to that is yes.

—In so far as these questions have been linked to the issue of a casino licence, they are matters for State authorities. If the State authorities wish the assistance of the AFP to be provided then I am sure it would be. But I believe it must be apparent to members of the Senate that these matters are matters for the Queensland Treasury Commission, or whatever the official body is within that particular jurisdiction, to determine.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Federal Police, I repeat, has a proper, real and fundamental responsibility in relation to Federal offences. That is the limit of its true investigative power. Of course, it would be prepared to assist when called upon, but that is not its normal role.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister seen the latest report on the quality of Australian-made cars published by the Automotive Industry Authority? In the light of recent criticisms of the Australian car industry, can the Minister provide details of the improvements in quality being made by the local car companies? Can the Minister explain to the Senate how Government policy has encouraged these improvements in quality?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an important question because the AIA report, which was published a few weeks ago, came out at a time when there were some ill-informed criticisms of the car industry in relation to quality issues—criticisms which were absolute nonsense. One of the main aims of the Government's automotive industry plan has been to improve quality levels because until recent years we had not been making cars of good enough quality. Indeed, some of the perceptions from the 1970s are quite wrong.

PARA.TAB: In the past there was a quality gap between locally produced and imported cars. In its report on the state of the automotive industry for 1991, the AIA said that the gap had narrowed significantly. Now the Authority has reported that survey data for this year shows that the gap no longer exists on some models and continues to narrow across the Australian industry. That is a 34 per cent improvement in quality, in terms of consumer response to vehicles, between 1988 and 1992.This is the same industry which the honourable member for Barker criticises for quality problems of the past. Mr McLachlan's celebrated comment on quality has made him a laughing stock amongst car industry people and workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does Bruce Watson say?
—What did Sir Arvi Parbo say?

—I said that some of these comments, including those of Sir Bruce Watson, reflect the perceptions of the past during a period in which those opposite were in government and in which they allowed this industry to enjoy very high levels of protection with no stimulus to improve quality, productivity or performance. Let me give an example for the benefit of Senator Kemp and Senator Alston, the two loudmouths on the Opposition benches. Last week, the first shipment of Mitsubishi Australian designed and built station wagons left Adelaide for the United States. In reporting this, Alan Kennedy of the Sydney Morning Herald said:

ANSWER.PARA: The wagon forms part of what. . . Dr Hewson, calls. . . the genre of poorly built, expensive, low-quality Australian-made cars.
Alan Kennedy went on to comment:
Now Mitsubishi's parent in Japan is not encouraging the exports of these vehicles because they are expensive, low-quality and poorly built. . .

PARA.TAB: Rather, the wagon meets all its stiff quality requirements and is world class.

TALK.START.PARA: —Marginal cost!

—Oh, the honourable senator would not know anything about it. Mitsubishi says that the quality of Magnas produced in Australia is equal to the quality of cars the company makes in Japan. Sadly, I have to say that the same comment has recently been made by Nissan!

PARA.TAB: The export facilitation scheme for the automotive industry, which the Opposition rejects, was a crucial factor in Mitsubishi Australia winning the right to produce Magna wagons for sale in North America and Europe. That would disappear with zero tariffs and so would export programs such as the Mitsubishi wagon. As Alan Kennedy pointed out, that is a small price to pay for intelligent policy relating to this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand that Ford Australia recently announced a major new export contract to Mazda in Japan. Did quality standards play a role in winning that contract?
—Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. Clearly, that supplementary question does not arise out of the answer given by the Minister. It is a second question.
—What are you scared of?

—I am not scared at all. The next dorothy dixer from the Government side can be the question just asked by Senator Zakharov; it should not be in the form of a supplementary question because it is not one. It is a second question and therefore it should be ruled out of order.
—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: the first question related to the quality of automotive products. The supplementary question relates to the quality of automotive products.
—Order! I believe that there is sufficient in that question to make it a supplementary.

—Mr Deputy President, Senator Zakharov has asked a thoughtful supplementary question. Senator Zakharov is a person who has actually been in an automotive plant and knows what it is about. Ford Australia, which already exports the Capri to the United States, has recently won an order worth $20m for engine blocks from Mazda to Japan. That is an ongoing order year by year. Productivity and quality improvements at Ford in Geelong, combined with the export facilitation scheme, made that contract possible.
—You know your answer. You are reading it out.

—I do not have to, Senator. The productivity and quality improvements were achieved by the same people and management the Opposition—and others, as Senator Kemp might point out—so frequently criticises.
—How is the Capri going?

—It has been the top rating car of its class in the United States for two years. Ford management sat down with the workers and together they identified potential improvements in productivity, and they achieved them.

PARA.TAB: A significant factor in all the quality improvements in recent years has been the willingness of the car companies to invest in new plant and machinery. This investment would dry up if the Opposition policies were put into effect. Zero tariffs mean zero industry. We certainly would export under a Liberal government, but we would be exporting jobs, not automotive components.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Prime Minister's assertion yesterday that `we were out of recession long ago'. I ask whether the Minister supports this claim or whether he agrees with the comments of the President of ACOSS, Mrs Merle Mitchell, that:

QUESTION.PARA: The pain is far from over..we're going to be left with a large number of people who will remain unemployed for a long period of time. . . There is very little comfort in that (Mr Keating's) statement for the probably 400,000 to 500,000 long-term unemployed people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the comment. If one had to address the question directly, the answer is yes, I do agree with the Prime Minister. I also agree with Merle Mitchell. I agree with her when she says, as she has said a number of times in recent months—
—Your policies have created the problem.

—If you want to talk about the long term unemployed you should go to Boothby, Hindmarsh and Adelaide and talk to the car industry. That is where you ought to be talking about the long term unemployed. How can you be serious about the unemployed when the Opposition's policies will put 60,000 car workers out of a job? You should go back to South Australia and explain that.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will come to order. They are not at a football match this afternoon.
—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Bolkus is directing his remarks across the chamber when he ought to be directing them through you. I ask you to call him to order.

—I said that I agree with the Prime Minister. I was about to speak to the comments of Merle Mitchell that relate to what I think is growingly becoming aware to the electorate and community as a whole.
—Growingly.

—Growingly. The electorate understands that there are two ways to handle the problem and that there are two ways to handle those who are suffering because of the recession and unemployment. Merle Mitchell is one of those at the forefront who can see through the Opposition's policies and can see the merit of the policies of those on this side. We have put in train a number of measures to get this economy going, and the Prime Minister has detailed them over six or seven months of this year.

PARA.TAB: What is the Opposition's response? It would make cutbacks of billions of dollars on expenditure in the public sector and on infrastructure, all geared towards accelerating and augmenting the problem that the community faces. The community can see through that.
I was in London recently and discovered there something that the Opposition should be aware of. Despite high unemployment in the UK, at the last election there was a swing amongst—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It might be interesting to hear on another occasion what Senator Bolkus was doing in London, but now is not the appropriate occasion. The Minister was asked whether he agrees that the Labor Government should take little comfort from having half a million term long unemployed under its policies. He should respond to that question, not talk about his geographical travels.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy President, I will return to the point. The point I was making is that there is a growing awareness in the community that there are two ways of handling the economic problem and there are two ways of handling those who are suffering because of it. It seems that Senator Hill has found a recent awareness of the long term unemployed since he came back from his jaunts.

PARA.TAB: There is one way to handle the long term unemployed and there is one way not to. The way not to is to cut off their benefits after nine months or deny them adequate training, because that goes directly to the viability of families in the long term unemployed group. The Opposition wants to cut off their benefits after nine months. Where is the equity and compassion there? Where is the equity in those opposite stopping the economic activity that we are generating in the economy by cutting back on public expenditure?

There is an awareness of the situation in the community. Though we are responsible for the economic situation, the community is looking and moving to the future, and the debate has moved on. This community is concerned about equity, compassion and jobs into the future. It will get those things from those on this side, but it will not get them from those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Just to put the record straight, we will not be cutting off unemployment benefits after nine months. If the Minister agrees with the statements that the recession was over long ago and that the pain is far from over, can he tell me, on behalf of the 500,000 people who are unemployed, when the pain will be over?
—If I wanted to know what the 500,000 or so unemployed are thinking, I would not have to listen to Senator Patterson. I live in a part of Adelaide where unemployment is—
—Very high.
—Precisely. I also live in a part of Adelaide where over—
—Because of your policies.
—Bowled by a full toss.

—Do those opposite want an answer or not? I know that it is very hard for people who might be listening to this to appreciate that there is a rabble on the other side. I would appreciate just a moment of silence.

PARA.TAB: I spent the last two months or so talking to people, both unemployed and employed, in South Australia. I also come from a part of South Australia—the western suburbs—where the car industry basically dominates our economy. People from that area tell me that, although they and their families are concerned about unemployment, they are terrified at what the Opposition's policies will put South Australia and its major industry—the car industry—through.

I will leave Senator Patterson to consider this point: these people are saying of the Opposition, `How can they be serious about unemployment if they are prepared to risk the jobs of 60,000 Australians'. These are the words of representatives from not only the motor vehicle industry but the components industry. When Senator Patterson answers that question, she can come here and ask me questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been drawn to an article on the front page of the Age of 15 September reporting a failure by the judiciary, the police and the community to take notice of domestic violence and child abuse? Is the Government concerned about this report? What can or will the Government do to address this tragic and hugely expensive problem?

—I did see that article, although I do not have it with me, a week or so ago. I admit that I was a little surprised about it because I would have thought that in the Australian community there had been a considerable change in the attitude to what is euphemistically called domestic violence but which is nothing less than criminal assault, usually within the home or the household. The growing recognition that one is talking about a criminal assault has led to quite a different attitude by the police and courts so far as intervention in those circumstances is concerned.

PARA.TAB: I also think it is important that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has decided on a scheme whereby protection orders obtained from, for example, the magistrates court in Western Australia could be applied to a situation where the assaulted spouse tries to get refuge, say, in Tasmania or New South Wales. The magistrates courts in those jurisdictions could enforce that protection order. If the person were followed by the assailant to the State of refuge, the assailant would be subject to penalties within the State of refuge.

TALK.START.PARA: —You gave us this answer three weeks ago.

—No, I did not. I believe that this is a very important advance. In so far as the States are required to pass legislation, in my home State of Tasmania the required legislation has been passed and is in force. In South Australia I understand that the legislation has been introduced into the Legislative Assembly but is still to be passed. It would be good work on the part of Senator Crowley to encourage her colleagues in the Parliament of South Australia to ensure that that legislation is properly in place to protect those who seek refuge in one jurisdiction from an assailant in another.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley also asked me about child abuse. The commissioners of the various police forces have been instructed by Ministers to pay particular attention to child abuse, particularly child sexual abuse, not only within Australia but also when Australians travel overseas. The Australian Federal Police, through their liaison officers in Bangkok and other places around the world, keep an eye on Australian paedophiles who travel to those jurisdictions and take advantage of the poverty of youngsters there in order to gratify their particular lusts.

I believe that we have a regional responsibility, not only a domestic one, to deal with child abuse, and that is being undertaken very forcefully within all Australian jurisdictions and in our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. This is not the first time that domestic violence has been raised in this place. What assurance can the Minister give that this time it will be different? In particular, what efforts are being made to further educate the community, including the judiciary, about the right attitudes?

—I believe that there is a changing attitude in the community which will be observed and become part of the reflex attitude of those on the benches, whether they be in the magistrates courts or the supreme courts. I do not know that it requires a particular program of education or instruction or whether they would be happy to submit themselves to it. Thanks to the women's refuge movement in particular, which 20 years ago inaugurated the protection of women who were subjected to domestic violence, there has been a growing awareness in the community that we are talking about criminal assault of a particularly vicious kind, quite often a hidden kind. Now that it is more openly spoken of in the community, I believe magistrates and judges are willing to respond, as are the various police commissioners and police forces, in dealing with this form of criminal activity.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Singapore, led by the Speaker of the Parliament, Mr Tan Soo Khoon. On behalf of honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming them to the Senate. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mr Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TAB.EMPHASIS: Mr Tan Soo Khoon was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the Government's proposal to take unrealised capital gains on shares held by pensioners into account for the income test on the age pension. Can the Minister confirm that if that policy had already been in place, a pensioner with just 1,000 BHP shares would have lost around $50 per fortnight in pension payments over the last six months?
—Why didn't you use Westpac as your example?

—We could probably do even better, if the honourable senator wants me to. How does the Government justify this draconian proposal in terms of its professed mortgage on social justice, when at the same time the Prime Minister, for whom the recession obviously ended a long time ago, has achieved an unrealised capital gain on his share in a piggery from $430,000 to $4.2m in just over six weeks without incurring any penalty whatsoever?
—I do not accept the assumptions in the second part of the question. In so far as the first part of the question is concerned, I will direct it to the Treasurer and obtain an answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer him to Mr Justice Toohey's reported statement that the High Court could construct a bill of rights based on `fundamental common law liberties'. I ask the Minister: does he agree, firstly, that the High Court has the role to interpret and protect the Australian Constitution and subsequent legislation enacted under that Constitution and, secondly, that it is the responsibility of Parliament to ensure that individual liberties are enshrined in law and to balance the freedom of the individual with the rights of others and the well-being of the community as a whole? Finally, is the Government going to abdicate its responsibilities to the High Court and allow the Court to usurp the role of Parliament?

—I find it quite remarkable—breathtaking, in fact—that a High Court justice should speak of fundamental common law liberties as though they were the foundation for the judgment the other day. In fact, that judgment was founded on representative government as being essential to our form of democracy, and that was never conferred by the common law judges. They never conferred a right to vote. As our colleagues from Singapore will well know, the old imperial common law judges never gave the right to vote to the people. It had to be fought for at every stage. This breathtaking idea that the High Court is on the side of common law enshrining of the right to representative government is absolute nonsense. Where was the right to freedom of religion under the common law? It would not have a bar of it.
—Bolkus reckons it is a good thing.

—Catholics and dissenters know that they would not have a bar of it. The right to vote is not a common law right. The way in which the High Court constructed its judgment last week does not give any confidence that the common law judges have the capacity to protect the rights and liberties of the Australian people. That will fall to this Parliament. Admittedly, the High Court has had a very proper role. For example, when the conservative coalitions back in the 1950s tried to ban a particular political party and dissolve it, the High Court held that that was beyond the constitutional power of the Federal Parliament and Government. In fact, the people upheld that judgment in a referendum. But that was based on our Constitution, which was founded on referendums in the late 1890s and passed by the Imperial Parliament. It was nothing to do with the common law itself. If the workers in the 1890s had decided to go for class warfare instead of the parliamentary and arbitrary system to better their working conditions, the common law judges would not have given them any help either to secure their democratic rights.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler asks about whether the Government is going to allow the High Court to usurp the role of the Parliament. The answer is no. For example, only a few weeks ago this Parliament passed a law to do with conscientious objection to military service in particular theatres of war. Where were the High Court judges during the Vietnam war? Where were they in protecting the conscientious rights of young Australians to say, `No, we will not kill other human beings in that conflict'?

TALK.START.PARA: —What a slur. Of course they did.

—The High Court was not there protecting the right of conscientious objection. That is the point: the common law does not have that capacity. This Parliament has done it over the last few weeks. We will not allow the High Court to usurp that role. In the combination of the exercise of powers—the judicial power exercised by the High Court and legislative power exercised by this Parliament through the two chambers—we have protection available to the Australian people. We will ensure that such rights as are proper to recognise—I do not say to confer or to create—will be recognised in properly formulated legislation from this chamber.

—Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. The logic of his answer compels me to ask him whether the Government is now disposed to enact a bill of rights and, more particularly, to support the Democrats' bill of rights now in preparation?

—I doubt whether the Parliament would be disposed to take the model to be put forward by the Democrats as the final word in regard to the enshrining of the rights of the Australian people in this question of the exercise by the Parliament of its responsibilities to protect those rights. But I do acknowledge the goodwill of Senator Spindler in speaking of a role for Parliament in this regard. Whether a comprehensive bill of rights could be sufficiently founded on the constitutional power of the Commonwealth Parliament would need to be very carefully looked at. Senator Hill and I once sat on a Senate committee which looked at the question of a bill of rights for Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that in the time that has elapsed since that particular project various pieces of legislation have gone through this Parliament which have dealt with rights for Australians which the common law—once again I say—never recognised. One that comes to mind is the question of the right of privacy, which this Parliament has dealt with fundamentally over the last several years, over a lot of objection as to the way in which it was worked out—at times from the Opposition and at times from others within the community. That has required a tremendous amount of work by this Parliament. That is the sort of work we will continually undertake. It will ensure that the rights which the common law never recognised will be recognised by this Parliament and protected in the ways that I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Now that Senator Button has adopted Mr Keating's style of attacking business leaders who have a different point of view from the Government, I ask whether he holds the same views in regard to Mr Argus, the Chief Executive of the National Australia Bank, who yesterday said that Australia could not afford the Government's tax cuts as, in an underlying and structural sense, the Budget remains stimulatory well into 1995. Is Mr Argus wrong, together with other Australian business leaders such as Sir Arvi Parbo and Mr Charles Allen, whose views Senator Button has attacked; and where precisely is he wrong?

—First of all, I do not think we should talk about political leaders who antagonise sections of the business community, because if we start down that track I can give Senator MacGibbon examples which will last for a quarter of an hour about his Leader's nervy response to any criticism from members of the business community and the reception which that has got in the business community.
—What did you have to say about the Business Council?
—In answer to the interjection about any criticisms I have made of business leaders, what I said was that they were misinformed about the particular issue on which they were making comment.
—You mean they disagreed with you.

—What I said was that the Liberal Party had tried to round up the usual suspects and involve them in the tariff debate, and I happen to know that that is true because I happen to know that Liberal politicians have been telling fibs to business leaders, particularly in the mining industry, about the nature of the Government's tariff policy.
—What an insult! These blokes have not got minds of their own?
—That is a calculated insult and it is directed right at people like Senator Alston. Let us not have any misapprehension about it; that is where it is directed.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the comments made by Don Argus of the National Australia Bank, I think Mr Argus has been a serious and very conservative commentator on issues relating to the Australian economy. What he says, of course, is that if the Government's tax cuts in 1994 are too stimulatory, those opposite have to face the prospect that so are theirs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ours are funded; fair dinkum funded!
