—The Opposition's are funded, apart from a $6 billion hole in its Fightback package. It is all very well for those opposite to say that theirs are funded, but that is the fact: there is a $6 billion hole.

PARA.TAB: For the benefit of those who are watching the Senate show and not listening to this noise, the interjections are all directed at the four-legs-good two-legs-bad type arguments in support of Fightback. We have to analyse what the real situation is, and the Opposition can find no real succour in the comments of Mr Argus about the medium term fiscal outlook. If our tax cuts were too stimulatory, so would be the Opposition's. The Government does not believe its offered tax cuts would be excessively expansionary because, as I have said on a number of occasions, we are committed to returning the Budget to surplus in the medium term. That is why we introduced the changes to the fringe benefits tax regime and so on which were announced a couple of weeks ago.

Mr Argus said that an expansionary policy was understandable in the present economic circumstances. Mr Argus was a willing contributor to the preparation of the One Nation statement, which did introduce stimulatory economic policies at that time—and I think he is right. He has a different view, by the way, from the other business leaders Senator Short quoted today at Question Time. Mr Argus had a slightly more bullish view about a recovery than them. Mr Argus's view of fiscal policy contrasts with that of Dr Hewson, who said that he wanted to take $6 billion or $7 billion out of the Budget and reduce the Budget stimulus by 2 per cent of GDP. So I do not think the Opposition can take much comfort from what Mr Argus said about these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the answer has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like to give the Leader of the Government an opportunity to carry on on that theme. I heard him say that there would be no undue expansionary effects of the proposed uncoordinated tax cuts that his Government is proposing. Will he assure the Senate that there will be no adverse effect on Australia's balance of payments debt as a consequence of these unfunded tax cuts?

—The effects of a domestic deficit or surplus on the balance of payments are in some senses remote. I do not think we can argue in the political debate about tax cuts to be offered by either side in 1994-95 and say that this will have such and such an effect on the balance of payments at that time. There are so many extraneous circumstances that enter into that calculation.
—It depends on whether they are funded.

—Senator Short, a four-legs-good two-legs-bad disciple of Fightback, says that it depends on whether they are funded or not. The Opposition's tax cuts are said to be funded, but unfortunately the funding is as bad as the arithmetic of those opposite in every policy they have put forward at election time in the last five or six years. That is to say, there is a big hole of $6 billion or $7 billion, which the people of Australia increasingly understand.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to a report on the front page of today's Age by Mark Metherell that the United States has been offered the use of a new underwater exercise range only 100 kilometres off the coast of Western Australia for exercises involving its nuclear-powered submarines. I ask the Minister: when was the offer made? Has the deal been struck and, if so, what are its terms? When was it intended to inform the Australian public of the arrangement? Was the Minister hoping the justifiable anger over US trade policies would die down before the agreement became public? Will the Government guarantee that it will not bow to pressure, which will no doubt be applied in time, for maintenance and service facilities to be provided for the nuclear submarines at Garden Island, thus putting Western Australians at risk of nuclear accidents?

—The article this morning was not in any way new news; it has been known for two years—since we made a decision to put in a submarine range off Western Australia—that there would be invitations for our allies to use it. The story was given a bit of currying up this morning by referring to nuclear submarines. That has not been discussed one way or another. There has been simply a broad offer for the use of those facilities and the facilities at the Delamare range, which reciprocates our use of similar facilities off Hawaii, the former facilities at Crow Valley and other similar facilities in the United States.

PARA.TAB: It is not unusual in any sense for allies to offer each other use of their facilities. So most of the rest of the question is redundant. There has been no attempt to cover this up. It was announced two years ago. It has been discovered as a fresh news item this morning when in fact many people have known about it for a number of years—at least one or two years. So I think the rest of Senator Powell's question is basically irrelevant.

I do not believe and never have believed in putting up security matters as a trade-off for trade policies. The reason we have entered these security arrangements is that we are advantaged by them. It is simply cutting off one's nose to spite one's face to put them up as pawns in some sort of negotiation over trade issues, and we will not be a part of it. I know it is not associated with Senator Powell, but I notice the New South Wales Farmers Federation put it up again yesterday. We are the major beneficiary of the arrangements with the United States, not the other way around. It would be foolish to do anything in that regard.

To come back to the central theme of Senator Powell's question, this is not a new announcement; it has been on the record for one to two years. Nuclear submarines have never been discussed one way or another. At this stage I am not sure whether the various sensors, et cetera, in the submarine range would be useful for nuclear submarines; they may be useful only for conventional submarines. That is something I will have to check on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister give the assurance that I have asked for about access to Garden Island, a pressure which no doubt would come to bear with increased use of our facilities off the coast of Western Australia?

—Any access to any Australian port requires a port safety plan. Senator Powell would realise the inquiries that Senator Maguire's committee made into this question. I think those recommendations were taken up entirely by the Government, with maybe a minor exception. So those recommendations that the Senate committee put to the Government were adopted in regard to these port visits. One can have such a port visit only if there is a proper port safety plan in operation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. When the bids for the university open learning initiative were being considered the evaluation panel made a recommendation to the Minister that Monash University and its rival, University Partnerships, should combine resources and present a joint submission. On what basis did the Minister then contradict this advice and accept a monopoly proposal from Monash, which had incorrectly reported that the University Partnerships proposal had fallen apart?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I represent the Minister here. I do not have an answer to that question in any detail and I will refer the question that has been asked by Senator Tierney to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin. However, I do say that Senator Tierney ought to stop engaging in cheap political gimmickry on this. We have made a very positive initiative in introducing open learning into Australia, which supplements the tertiary system—a very useful innovation. Senator Tierney has been running around Australia condemning us for that and misrepresenting the position. Senator Tierney should actually stop doing that. In the meanwhile, I will refer the rest of the question to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister claims it is gimmickry; let us hear his answer to this: Is the Minister aware that some universities which are part of the University Partnerships proposals have been contacted by Monash and threatened—yes, threatened—with isolation from the open learning initiative once Monash won the bid, unless they withdrew immediately from the University Partnerships consortium? Given these actions, how does the Minister propose to ensure that the non-metropolitan universities with distance education centres will not be disadvantaged by the proposed Monash University dominated open learning system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not actually know whether a supplementary question is in order since I did not answer the first question. I do not see how, automatically, a supplementary question follows. But allowing for the laxity with which Senator Tierney approaches the Standing Orders, let me say I have indicated that I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, which I will do. But I should indicate to him very firmly now that I do not accept any of the premises that are in his supplementary question or any of the allegations that he makes, and I do not accept them, with the greatest of respect, because I find him to be a very unreliable witness. He has been running around this country—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I find it quite unacceptable that the two senators behind the Minister are holding up a press release so that it will appear on television, and I would ask you to ask them to put it down.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. It merely continues in the fine tradition of vexatious points of order by Opposition senators in order to disrupt Question Time. PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—
The DEPUTY PRESIDENT—Order! Before I hear your point of order, both sides of the chamber will come to order.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: National Occupational Health and Safety Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of plans by the Opposition to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, should it ever win government? Could the Minister inform the Senate if the Government has any plans to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not, of course. What is a reality in industrial life in Australia is that time lost to industry through industrial accident and disease usually runs at about 10 times the amount of time lost through industrial disputes, but for whatever reason we are fixated on industrial disputes and do not often enough approach the issue of time lost through accidents and disease, lowering the level of lost time to industry, and improving the occupational health and safety of Australian workers at the same time.

PARA.TAB: Worksafe Australia is an important agency which makes the workplaces of this country safer, and it is estimated in its annual report that since 1984 it has saved Australian industry $1.5 billion. The Opposition in its Fightback package proposes to abolish Worksafe Australia in order to make a $19m a year saving. That means that since 1984 it would have saved $160m and forwent a saving of $1.5 billion. That is Opposition economics and that is Opposition attention to this fundamental issue of industrial relations change.

It is not surprising, in those circumstances, that the distinguished Australian businessman, Mr Warburton, who is the head of Du Pont (Australia) Ltd, and also, coincidentally, the Chairman of Worksafe Australia, has come out on behalf of Worksafe, saying to the Opposition that this is a retrograde step, that it should delete from its consumption tax package the threat to abolish the Occupational Health and Safety Commission and that it should, in fact, encourage—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is paid to defend it.

—He is paid to defend it? He is the Chairman of the agency and the agency has made a saving of $1.5 billion since 1984. He is interested also, as the chief executive officer of a major Australian company, in reaching efficiencies for his company. Occupational health and safety is an important consideration in making his company, along with all other Australian companies, operate efficiently and cost effectively. He is also interested because he is a human being and has some concern for the safety and well-being of his work force in order to ensure that they too are protected.

PARA.TAB: The commitment in the consumption tax package is to devolve occupational health and safety matters back to the States. I watched Mr Howard at the Press Club at lunchtime today. He is proposing to introduce one national industrial relations system to deal with industrial disputation—one national system for disputes—and to devolve occupational health and safety back to the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to remember the point of order I raised yesterday dealing with Ministers answering questions that are not part of their portfolio. I would be interested to know how the honourable senator can justify watching Mr Howard on television and saying what he thought he said as constituting a comment on his portfolio.
—I believe the comment is in order.

—Another vexatious point of order. The point is the hypocrisy of the Opposition saying that it wants one national system but that it will devolve occupational health and safety back to the States and create six different State systems. This will require national companies to have six different versions of workers compensation cover and six different sets of regulations according to the States to govern workplace requirements in terms of occupational health and safety. There lies the hypocrisy and stupidity.

PARA.TAB: Worksafe's urgent priorities at the moment are achieving national uniformity of occupational health and safety standards for Australia by the end of next year, improving productivity by reducing workers compensation and related costs through better occupational health and safety performance, and conducting research on major hazards in the work environment in response to requests from industry. It also plays a key role in hazardous chemicals. To remove it is to go backwards and create more disharmony in Australian workplaces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the answer has expired.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a series of answers to questions asked by Senator Parer, Senator Kernot, Senator Spindler and Senator Chamarette involving Daikyo, Jupiters and various AFP investigations or invitations for investigation and so on. I have circulated the answers to the honourable senators concerned, and I seek leave to incorporate the questions and answers in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The questions and answers read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: (A)The Questions and Answers for Question Time of 16 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (i) Senator Parer—Question on Mackenroth, Goss and Coco and the alleged bribe?
Supplementary—capacity of AFP to investigate such allegations?
(ii) Senator Kernot—Yakuza penetration Gold Coast property market?
Link between Daikyo executive and Yakuza?
AFP consult with CJC/Queensland casino authority-Jupiters Brisbane?
(iii) Senator Spindler—ASC investigations, breach insider trading law?
When were Jupiters recommended as preferred applicant?

ANSWER.PARA: (B)The Questions and Answers to Questions placed on Notice Paper for 16 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (i) Senator Chamarette (2269)—AFP investigation Yakuza/Daikyo?
(ii) Senator Chamarette (2270)—ASC and Jupiters Brisbane?

ANSWER.PARA: (C)Question and Answer for Question Time of 6 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (i) Senator Chamarette—ASC and the Treasury Building Casino.

PARA.EMPHASIS: AFP INVESTIGATION OF MR SANTO COCO

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer asked me the following question during Question Time on 16 September 1992:

Is the Minister for Justice aware that the Federal Police, in the course of criminal investigations, obtained a transcript of a telephone conversation between the State Member for Chatsworth, Mr Mackenroth, and a Mr Santo Coco and that transcript, which included allegations of a $5,000 bribe, was given to the Premier of Queensland, Mr Wayne Goss, by the Queensland Commissioner of Police? Has there been any further action by the Federal Police, as it appears that the Premier has been involved in a cover-up which includes the extraordinary expunging of the Hansard record?
Senator Tate—I am now able to provide the following additional response to the honourable Senator's question:
I am advised that the AFP did in the course of criminal investigations, lawfully record by use of a listening device, one side of a conversation conducted by Mr Coco by telephone.

A transcript of Mr Coco's side of the conversation was prepared and, in the absence of offences against the Commonwealth legislation, provided to the Queensland Commissioner of Police in accordance with police operational practice of notifying the appropriate police service where information may involve matters within state jurisdiction.

The AFP has indicated that neither Mr Mackenroth nor the Labor Party is under its investigation. Due to on-going operational sensitivities in relation to other people and a matter currently on appeal before the court I am not able to comment further.
Senator Parer also asked me the following supplementary question:
Does the AFP have the capacity to investigate the Premier of Queensland and the honourable member for Chatsworth.
Senator Tate—The AFP has the capacity to investigate any person where there may be a breach of Commonwealth law.

Senator Tate—During Question Time on 16 September 1992 Senator Kernot asked me a number of questions without notice. Following advice from the Australian Federal Police, I am able to provide the following answers to her questions:

Have Australian Federal Police investigations during the past twelve months on the Queensland Gold Coast concluded that the Japanese Yakuza's penetration of the Queensland property market could be well above 25 per cent?
The AFP has no evidence which would support such a claim.
Have these investigations linked one senior executive of Daikyo with a high-ranking Japanese Yakuza member?
No. AFP investigations have not linked a senior executive of Daikyo with a high-ranking Yakuza member.

Was the Australian Federal Police involved in consultation with the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and the Queensland Treasury Casino Control Division, because of investigations by these bodies into a question mark over Daikyo as a founding partner in the Jupiters Brisbane casino bid?

No. Although the AFP does liaise with state law enforcement authorities the question of the issue of casino licences is not within the jurisdiction of the AFP and in this instance the assistance of the AFP was not requested. It is understood that this particular matter was one solely for the Queensland Treasury Department Casino Control Division. I am advised that the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission has had no involvement in the investigation or selection processes of casino applicants.
Senator Spindler asked the Minister for Justice, without notice on 16 September 1992:

Can the Minister advise whether investigations have been conducted by the Australian Securities Commission to determine whether any insider trading laws have been breached by the extraordinary sales of one and a half million shares in Jupiters Limited in the two weeks prior to Jupiters Ltd being awarded preferred applicant status for the Brisbane Casino on 26 May this year?

Has the Australian Securities commission determined at what stage during this two week flurry of activity, which saw the share price for Jupiters increase from $2.19 to $2.52, the Queensland Premier and the Cabinet were advised that Jupiters had been recommended as the preferred applicant for the casino tender?
Senator Michael Tate—The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Australian Securities Commission has advised that it has not formally commenced an inquiry into this matter under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Act. Preliminary inquiries are, however, being made by the Commission. As the Commission is still making preliminary inquiries it is not appropriate for me to make further comment at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chamarette asked the Minister for Justice upon notice on 16 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) have Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigations of Japanese-owned property in Queensland during the past twelve months revealed that at least 25 per cent of such property was held in trust for Japanese Yakuza syndicates, and was it found by the AFP that Queensland's tourist industry is being used to launder profits from Japanese criminal activities, including drugs, prostitution, gambling and extortion.
(2) Have Queensland's state property laws made it difficult to trace the real owners of property held in the names of nominal Japanese investors.
(3) Have the AFP's investigations linked one senior executive of Daikyo with a high-ranked Yakuza member.
(4) Has the AFP informed the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and the Queensland Casino Control Division of the Queensland Treasury of any association between Daikyo and the Yakuza.

(5) Was the AFP advised by the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and the Casino Control Division that this association was known to them through their investigations into the suitability of Daikyo as a founding partner in the Brisbane casino bid by Jupiters Ltd.
Senator Michael Tate has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

(1) (a) AFP investigations have not revealed what per cent, if any, of the Japanese owned property in Queensland may be held in trust for Yakuza syndicates. The AFP is not aware of any evidence which would support such a claim.

Any AFP role in such cases is of course directed at those matters which may involve a breach of Commonwealth legislation, such as money laundering, cash transactions or requests which may arise under mutual assistance provisions.
(b) The AFP is not aware of any evidence which would support the suggestion that the Queensland tourist industry is being used to launder profits from Japanese criminal activity.
(2) No. The Queensland state property laws have not made it difficult to trace the real owners of property.
(3) No. AFP investigations have not linked a senior executive of Daikyo with a high-ranked Yakuza member.
Senator Chamarette asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice on 16 September 1992:

(1) Can the Minister advise if investigations have been conducted by the Australian Securities commission (ASC) to determine if any insider trading laws may have been breached by the sale of 1.6 million shares in Jupiters Ltd, in the two weeks prior to Jupiters being awarded preferred applicant status for the Brisbane casino on 26 May 1992.
(2) Has the ASC determined when the Queensland public service interdepartmental committee considering the various casino bids had finalised its recommendation to State cabinet.
(3) When were the Premier and State Cabinet informed of this recommendation.
(4) Did the trading of over 800,000 shares on 14 May 1992 represent the biggest single day of trading in Jupiters Ltd script since December 1991.

(5) Did the adoption of this recommendation by the Queensland cabinet assist Daikyo to pocket a profit of $50 million from the sale of its 24 per cent investment in Jupiters, as has been claimed by a Daikyo spokesperson in the Queensland media.
(6) Has the ASC been advised of Australian Federal Police investigations into Daikyo's association with Japanese Yakuza crime syndicates.
(7) Will the Minister make public any report made to him by the ASC of any investigation or hearing relating to these matters.
Senator Michael Tate—The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) The Australian Securities Commission has advised that it has not formally commenced an inquiry into this matter under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Act. Preliminary inquiries are, however, being made by the Commission.
(2),(4),(5) Since the Commission is still making preliminary inquiries it is not appropriate for me at this stage to make comment on the issues raised in these questions.
(3) This is not a matter on which I have information.

(6) The Australian Securities Commission has been advised of an assessment made by the Australian Federal Police in October 1991 that allegations Yakuza influence in Daikyo could not be substantiated.

(7) If a report were to be made by the Commission to the Attorney-General a decision would be made at that time regarding its public release on the basis of advice to him on whether its public release would hinder further investigation or other action.
Senator Chamarette asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, without notice on 6 October 1992:

I refer to investigations conducted by the Australian Securities Commission to determine if insider trading laws may have been breached by the extraordinary sale of 1.6 million shares in Jupiters Ltd in the two weeks prior to May 26th this year, and I ask:

(1) has the Australian Securities Commission been advised by the Queensland Government Interdepartmental Committee for additional casino licences of possible errors in their published report of May this year, specifically a failure to mention a second submission from Jupiters for the Treasury building;

(2) was this submission in conformity with the published minimum requirements for 200 hotel rooms in the Treasury Casino project and involve a complete gutting of the Treasury building, so that only bare facades of this National Estate registered building would remain;

(3) did Jupiters, in the knowledge that the IDC would grant a concessionary reduction of 50 in the number of rooms required for the hotel, prepare a second non-conforming tender concurrently with their conforming tender;
(4) if so, did this give Jupiters a commercial advantage over other tenders?
Senator Michael Tate—The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) The Australian Securities Commission has advised that it has not formally commenced an inquiry into this matter under section 13 of the Australian Securities Commission Act. Preliminary inquiries only are being made by the Commission. As preliminary inquiries are still being made it would not be appropriate for the Commission to comment on specific matters in relation to these inquiries.
(2), (3) and (4) These are not matters on which I have information.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Letter from Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a letter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade relating to the resolution of the Senate of 9 September 1992 concerning the presence of Russian troops on the territories of the Baltic states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter of the Minister, I have to confess, is somewhat disappointing. The resolution of the Senate which was as a result of a motion moved by my colleague Senator Short, who of course has taken a very close interest in the welfare of Baltic peoples over a long period of time, was to protest the continuing presence of Russian troops in the three Baltic states—troops which are of course now regarded as occupying forces now that the three Baltic states have been accepted by the international community as independent sovereign states.

PARA.TAB: This is a position that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would know we held throughout the years of occupation by the Soviet Union and was in fact held by all Australian governments except the Whitlam Labor Government which reversed that policy for a period of time. Since the breakup of the Soviet Union and since the international community accepted the independence of the three Baltic states on a general basis, up to 200,000 Russian troops have remained. The exact number is somewhat in dispute, but it is certainly somewhere between 130,000 and 200,000. The Baltic peoples are deeply distressed by this continuing presence of Russian forces on their soil and have sought support from the international community in pressuring Russia to withdraw those forces.

We know there is difficulty for Russia in withdrawing in terms of providing housing and other material benefits for the grossly extended Soviet force, in particular the Russian force, but, nevertheless, that does not negate the very reasonable demand by sovereign nations that occupying forces or forces of former occupying powers still on that soil should leave. This Senate very reasonably expressed that demand also and requested that the Australian Government protest that continuing occupation to the Russians and join—I am not sure whether it said it specifically, but certainly that was the spirit—with other governments of like mind to apply that pressure.

As I have said, the response of the Minister to that demand as evidenced by his letter today is disappointing. Nowhere in his reply does he say that the opinion of the Australian Government is that it is opposed to the presence of the Russian forces in the Baltic states. He does not in any place indicate that the Australian Government is prepared, either on its own behalf or in conjunction with others, to diplomatically apply pressure to Russia to withdraw those forces. He does not canvass the possibility of the international community looking for ways in which it might support Russia in the provision of housing for its forces upon withdrawal.

I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that even the Baltic states themselves in their very difficult economic circumstances have said that they would try to look at ways in which they could help ease this financial burden. All the Minister really says is that the Australian Government is pleased that a timetable has been agreed with the Government of Lithuania for withdrawal over the next couple of years and that the Australian Government hopes that a similar agreement will be reached with Estonia and Latvia as well. That is not good enough. That is a reply that will disappoint the Baltic peoples in Australia. They deserve more from this Australian Government. One can think of many states in the world that have foreign soldiers on their soil, but of the Baltic states particularly when one takes into account the fact that they were forcibly occupied for so long. They deserve more from the international community and they deserve more of the Australian Government.

I hope this reply was drafted by someone other than within the Minister's office. During the course of this debate the Minister might get up and in fact say that the Australian Government's policy is that these troops should be withdrawn forthwith from the Baltic states and that the Australian Government is willing, together with other Western and like minded nations, to apply what diplomatic force is open upon Russia to require that withdrawal as soon as absolutely possible.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a pathetic little bit of grandstanding from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and he ought to be ashamed of himself for doing it. I do not mind in the slightest his getting up here and saying that he, the Opposition and members of the Australian Parliament are concerned about the continuation of the presence of Russian forces on Baltic states' soil. That concern is a concern that we share as I made perfectly clear in the text of this letter when we said that we hoped that similar agreements of the kind that had been reached with Lithuania would in fact prove achievable with the other states.

PARA.TAB: The whole point of the letter that I did the Senate the courtesy of sending to the President of the Senate was simply, as a point of information, to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that one particular state referred to in the motion had in fact the day before the motion was passed entered into an agreement which would, within a reasonable time frame, allow for the withdrawal of the troops in question from its soil. In the letter I could have drawn attention to the obduracy and the stupidity of Senator Short in not amending his motion properly in the way that he was advised he should on the morning that the thing went through. The motion makes several references to Lithuania which are not appropriate, given the reality of the particular agreement signed on 8 September.

Senator Short could not get his amendment correct and the point of the motion was simply to clarify that particular matter for the benefit of the Senate. It is absolutely no justification for pretending in some way that the Opposition's position on this is holier than that of the Australian Government. The motion did not call upon me or the Government to take any particular diplomatic action. If it had, I would, of course, have been responsive to that in the terms of my reply. It simply expressed the views of the Senate on an issue in respect of which it was entirely legitimate to express views—views which the Australian Government shares.

The attempt that has just been made to try to draw some wedge, open some gap or pretend that the Opposition feels more strongly on this issue than the Australian Government does is misconceived, deliberately distorted and misleading. It is an attempt, which, as I said, Senator Short ought to be ashamed of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far from grandstanding, as Senator Evans has accused Senator Hill of doing, what has actually been revealed now by Senator Evans is that he did not have a clue as to the wording of the motion to which he was replying.
—`Virtually no progress', when it was the day before they reached an agreement.
—The motion that I gave notice of on Tuesday, 8 September—
—We told you that the language was just loopy.

—Just let me finish. It is no wonder that his Department is an absolute shambles because Senator Evans and his office are a disgrace. I gave notice of motion on Tuesday, 8 September 1992. I refer the Minister to page 529 of the Hansard of 8 September. The first part of the notice of motion I gave on that day stated:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a) expresses its concern that, despite many efforts by the leaders of the nations of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania to reach agreement with the President of Russia (Mr Yeltsin) for the withdrawal of Russian forces from their soils, as promised by Mr Yeltsin at the meeting of the G7 nations in Munich on 12 July 1992, there has been no progress on the withdrawal;

SPEECH.PARA: Between giving that notice of motion and the motion being brought on the following day, there were announcements over the wires from Lithuania that, in fact, an agreement had been reached between Russia and Lithuania. To its credit, Senator Evans's office rang me on the morning of 9 September and said to me, `We have consulted with the Department on this and it has drawn to our attention the fact that overnight there appears to have been an agreement signed between Lithuania and Russia. Therefore, we suggest the following amendment to your notice of motion'. Senator Evans's office suggested, with words supplied by his Department, that my motion be preceded with the words that the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a) whilst welcoming the news of the agreement reached between Russia and Lithuania, nevertheless expresses its concern. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I later inserted the word `virtually' in the first paragraph of the motion so that, instead of saying `there has been no progress on the withdrawal', it said `there has been virtually no progress on the withdrawal'. That amendment was cleared with Senator Evans's office and his office said that that was okay by the Department. On that basis, the Senate agreed to carry it as a formal motion on 9 September.

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator Evans for an apology for the mistake that he made in his remarks. He has implied that I did not take any notice of the agreement that had been signed between Russia and Lithuania. I did take notice of it; it had occurred in that 24-hour period. The wording of the resolution and the amendment that was made to that motion were words supplied to me by his office and his Department. How he could not know that is beyond my comprehension. As I have said before and as this chamber now knows par excellence, it simply reflects the fact that Senator Evans is not up with the game in terms of his Department and his portfolio responsibilities.

Senator Evans implied in his letter to the President that he was doing the Senate a courtesy—and it is a courtesy—in deigning to reply to the President. I would be absolutely amazed if he had shown the discourtesy that is implied in the opposite—namely, that he would not even have considered replying. Given that Senator Evans replied—and I welcome that—I find his response, as Senator Hill has said, very disappointing.

The motion that this Senate passed, formally and unanimously, expressed concern that there had been virtually no progress on this matter whilst recognising the Lithuanian situation. There is no mention in Senator Evans's letter to the President acknowledging that concern. Weakly, he said in his response that he had an expression of concern because he says in the last sentence that the Government `hopes that similar accords are signed with Latvia and Estonia in the near future'. If that is a response to an expression of concern that is supposed to reflect what the Senate had felt about this matter—it felt strongly about it—then Senator Evans grew up in a different school of English language from that which I and my colleagues on this side of the chamber grew up in.

The letter says nothing about the continuing situation. As I understand it, that situation is that there has been no further progress in terms of any form of agreement between the Russian Government on the one hand and Latvia and Estonia on the other. The letter also does not reflect the fact that, whilst the defence Ministers did sign an agreement between Russia and Lithuania on 8 September in Moscow, at that time it was also hoped that a similar agreement would be signed between President Yeltsin and President Landsbergis. A last minute hitch occurred, so that agreement was not signed and, as I understand it, has still not been signed. That is an important agreement because without it the defence Ministers' agreement is much weakened. Senator Evans's letter does not acknowledge any of those things.

Without taking up much more time, I very strongly endorse Senator Hill's words of disappointment in Senator Evans's response to this formal resolution of the Senate. I believe that Senator Evans has not dealt with the issues concerned. He has certainly not reflected in any way in his answer the concern that this Senate and many Australians, not just those of Baltic origin, feel about this matter. It has much wider implications than the situation simply between Russia and the Baltic nations, because it goes to the whole question of the presence of foreign troops on the soil of sovereign nations.

There is no reflection at all of any acknowledgment of that concern in Senator Evans's letter. I hope very much that the Government of Australia will be lending its good offices in whichever way it can, much more strongly than is indicated in his letter, to achieving the resolution of this matter in Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia and also doing what we can through our good offices to get a better basis for agreement between President Yeltsin and President Landsbergis. It is a matter of very real concern and it is something that the Government, as well as the Australian Parliament, should feel much more strongly about than the intent that is shown in Senator Evans's letter.

I request from Senator Evans an apology for what appears to be a gross mistake he has made in that it appears that he has been looking at the wrong piece of paper. He has looked at the notice of motion of 8 September, not the motion that was passed on 9 September, because the motion that was passed on 9 September was amended to take into account exactly the wording that his office and his Department passed on to me and which I was happy to accept.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make an explanation in response to Senator Short's invitation. It is not me who has made a mistake; it is Senator Short. The truth of the matter is very simply as follows: on the morning that the motion was scheduled for debate, 9 September, it is the case that my office rang Senator Short's office to draw his attention to the very substantial agreement that had been reached overnight going to the heart of his motion so far as Lithuania was concerned. It is the case that language of the sort that Senator Short has referred to and which was incorporated in the text of the motion was suggested to his office by my office at that time.
—And accepted.

—And accepted. It was the clear understanding of my office that the implication of that would be further linguistic changes to remove the references to Lithuania in the latter part of the first paragraph and in paragraph (b). Our clear understanding, as I think anyone who understands the English language would understand, is that, given the agreement which had just been reached, it was no longer appropriate to refer to Lithuania in those terms.
—It had not been reached between the heads of state.

—That is not the point. When Defence Ministers reach an agreement on the withdrawal of troops that is a sufficient foundation on which to act. In any event, at that point I am advised that it occurred to my office that maybe it would be appropriate to explicitly convey that suggestion and not leave it implicit. Subsequently, further communication was made by my office later that morning to Senator Short's office proposing that there be a deletion of the subsequent references to Lithuania, by which time I am told that Senator Short had already tabled the motion in the abbreviated amended form and it was too late.

PARA.TAB: That is the context of my referring earlier to Senator Short's not appreciating the logic and the force of his own motion and amending the motion properly accordingly. He amended it in a half-baked and incomplete fashion. Because the motion had been thus amended and because there were continued references to Lithuania, conveying the impression that there had been something less than substantial about the agreement that had been reached with Lithuania, I thought it appropriate under those circumstances to write to the President, not in any way referring to that exchange but simply for the record, making it clear that there was this very substantial agreement on the record signed by the Defence Ministers providing for the withdrawal of all forces from Vilnius by November this year and from the rest of Lithuania by 31 August next year. On the face of it, it was a perfectly reasonable thing to do and simply does not justify the criticism that has been directed towards me or the Government by Senator Hill and now Senator Short.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the thirteenth report of 1992 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 13 of 1992, dated 17 October 1992.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reports of the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills come before this chamber on a regular basis. They speak for themselves. They are the result of work done by senators from the Government, from the Opposition and from the Australian Democrats. These people meet each sitting week and discuss whether the legislation coming before Parliament could reasonably be taken to breach a series of tests going to issues of civil liberties.
—A great Committee.

—I thank the honourable senator very much. Party political matters are left aside. This enables the Committee to work together efficiently and well. In these circumstances, the occasions on which a speech is made when the reports are tabled are uncommon. Given discussion that has recently taken place following the decision of the High Court in the political ads case, it is appropriate for me to make the following remarks.

PARA.TAB: Parliament does more for civil liberties than is now acknowledged. That the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 may have infringed civil liberties was a matter raised by the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in a report dated 15 May 1991. Page 14 of that report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Prima facie, the limitations which are to be imposed by the Bill amount to an interference with the freedom of expression. Such an interference would be considered a trespass on personal rights and liberties, as contemplated by principle 1(a)(i) of the Committee's terms of reference. However, the principle requires the Committee to examine legislation as to whether it trespasses unduly on personal rights and liberties.

It then goes on to discuss that issue over the next page and a bit. I will not quote that. I have quoted what I have on the basis of showing that the Committee raised the matter very specifically on 15 May.

PARA.TAB: Suggestions have been made that Parliament establish a committee to test the legislation coming before it against the principles which must be upheld if we are to have the sort of society we all want. Such a committee already exists in the Senate. It has performed magnificent work over a decade. It has comprised many senators, some of whom still serve in this chamber. All have served splendidly. Its support staff have been quite outstanding, and no-one more so than its present Secretary, Stephen Argument.

Much criticism has been directed at the High Court over its decision in the political ads case. I do not join in that criticism. Rather, I look at the positive work that this Parliament, through the Senate, is doing to protect the civil rights of Australians.
