TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the Australian environment and tourism report, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Some might say this report has been a little long in finding its way into this chamber, but I think anyone who gets the opportunity to read it will see that the delay has done it no harm. The principal reason for the delay is that the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, at the time of receiving this term of reference, was devoting itself to the drugs in sport inquiry. As everyone knows, as a result of an extraordinary effort, the Committee brought down an excellent report on drugs in sport. The inquiry clearly was a matter of considerable scope and priority for the Committee.

PARA.TAB: We offer the Australian environment and tourism report as part of the continuing debate and evidence about tourism. I make three principal points which are highlights of this report. I do believe anyone with an interest in tourism would be well advised to read the report, in particular the detail under the headings of the points that I make.

The first point relates to the concern the Committee had about putting together the words `environment' and `tourism'. For many years, indeed until fairly recently, environment and tourism were at war with each other. People who spoke the language of environment seemed to regard tourism and all tourist developments as the enemy and vice versa.

It is easy to report and it is certainly fair to report that that attitude has changed. The environmental lobby and the tourism developers appreciate that there is much more to be gained by both of them through cooperation. Not only is it a matter of what can be gained but also it is a fair representation and recognition by both those groups that it is vital that they do cooperate.

The way Australia has been marketed as a tourist destination for overseas tourists has been to emphasise—apart from shrimps on barbies—those virtues such as the great, wide open spaces of the Australian outback; the beauty of the Great Barrier Reef, which clearly belongs under the heading of one of the wonders of the world; places like Kakadu, Broome; our huge coastline; glorious beaches—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dorothea Mackellar summed it all up beautifully.

—She did indeed and perhaps we should have called our report the title of her poem. I was tempted to at some stage, but in the end we were not persuaded by poetry. Senator Brownhill is quite right. Australia has been marketing itself as an overseas destination because of its environmental or landscape attractions. It is very important that the tourist industry, in developing opportunities for people to see and explore that countryside, that outback, does not in the process jeopardise or even damage that environment. That has been the case in times past.

PARA.TAB: It is very comforting that our report was able to table a recognition of the changed language between those two groups, those parts of industry, in the Australian community. There has been a recognition that there is no point in killing the goose that lays the golden egg. Although we did not examine it in great detail, it was certainly brought to the Committee's attention that there is a need for tourism and the environment to work together—not only to cease to be at war, but to work together—in preserving the environment. Even if the tourism development at the outset is a very sympathetic development, the number of tourists that come to stay in an area and/or visit the surrounding areas still

SPEECH.PARA: may, by their very numbers, further damage the environment.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a number of examples, some of which we referred to in the report, where it is important to ration the number of tourists, either the total number or the number at any one time able to proceed to an area. This is certainly happening with the area around Uluru rock and in many other areas of the environment, not only in areas which in the past were called fragile environments but also in areas that are overrun by uncontrolled or unlimited numbers of tourists and which can become threatened and proceed to a fragile state.

We thought it was very important to make the point that `environment' should include not only landscapes but very much the people living in the landscapes and to make recommendations about the importance of tourism developments to take account of the environment in consultation with the community but in particular to include that local community.

Taking evidence at Broome, we were told about the fairly dramatic impact of the increased population in Broome on the local community, a dimension that is not always developed in looking at the impact on tourism and environment. One important consideration, for example, is that the costs of everything rise with the increase in population in a tourist resort. The changing character of Broome is a very salutary lesson in some ways. The local population, white and Aboriginal, have had to come to terms with fairly significant increases in costs—the cost of living in particular. Further, some of the people, particularly the Aboriginal community, have had to deal with the changing landscape of their culture through the development of tourism in what was previously not a tourist resort. We urge in our report an understanding of the environment to include `the people' and `the local community'.

We were also told of sleepy beach resorts that people like to retire to for quiet holidays. If those beach resorts are turned into skyscraper-type holiday resorts, people visiting them do not experience the same kind of holiday at all; they do not enjoy the same kind of rest. We also met the concept of the anti-tourist tourist—someone who likes to be a tourist visiting places but who does not want to meet 5,000 other people also there at the same time. There is a very large appeal in our tourist industry for places to which people can go to be away from it all. If we want to go to a wilderness, the last thing we want to find is that it is overrun by other humans. The very word `wilderness' means that we expect to find few other people. I do not think most people mind finding sight and sound of other humans; not all of us want to be hermits. But the concept of the anti-tourist tourist I think is worthy of consideration and is reflected in the variety of tourist developments that we find around Australia.

I would not like to leave the impression that environment and tourism refer only to such things as the Great Barrier Reef or Uluru—not at all. One of the exciting things about the Australian tourist industry is just how wide is the range and how geographically spread are the tourist resorts in this country.

The second main point I highlight is the issue of adequate statistics in the area of tourism. In trying to assess the impact of an industry or to set goals that we want measured to account for the impact of changes and developments in that area, it is very difficult if we do not have adequate baseline statistics, or at least an agreed set of statistics and figures. What is a bed for the purposes of being counted as a tourist bed? Most of us can describe what a bed is, but is this bed to be counted amongst tourist statistics or is it for local use and, therefore, not to be described as part of tourism?

There is still much more debate to go on about what exactly constitutes tourist statistics, but we do now have the Bureau of Tourism Research and the Australian Bureau of Statistics; I think the ABS is producing the framework of guidelines for what constitute tourism statistics and how to collect them. It is very important that those principles be agreed to and that the collectors of the data—the small providers of beds, support services, restaurants, accommodation and so on—appreciate the way in which that data is being asked for and contribute to its collection, so that we begin to get consistent national data.

Finally, the Committee makes recommendations about the changed nature of the Foreign Investment Review Board. We agree to its continuing; we agree about the good work it does; but we feel that, if we really are serious about the Foreign Investment Review Board giving independent advice, that advice should proceed directly to the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) after being examined by the FIRB and not back through Treasury officials. We have made recommendations to that effect and to the effect that there would therefore be a requirement for some at least modest change in the structuring of the FIRB.

We were interested to discover that the FIRB did not monitor the outcome or development of any of the projects to which it had given approval for foreign investment. We feel that that is not sufficient and that the Foreign Investment Review Board should at least have more than a we-read-the-newspapers-to-see-what-is-happening regard to monitoring massive investments in this country. Local communities are very concerned if a significant overseas development gets started but does not proceed, and there are any number of examples of that happening around the country. We feel that that is a matter of relevance and pertinence to the FIRB, and we have made recommendations along those lines too.

In the time frame that has been agreed today, I do not have the opportunity to canvass all the recommendations. In summary, I believe that this is a good report which is very timely. We now have a national tourist strategy in the process of being implemented. I think it is a credit to Australia that we can actually consider the concept of a national tourist strategy, although I have a suspicion that my colleague Senator Campbell may want to paraphrase those remarks of mine.

This is an opportune time to have a report such as this which puts the tourist strategy in place, particularly in terms of the opportunities for jobs and growth in this area. Nowhere is there any report that tourism is a negative in terms of economics. I do not wish to canvass again the economic issues or changes to local communities, for example. In the limited framework of looking at it in terms of economics, from all accounts tourism seems to be a very significant plus. Export earnings from tourism for this country are larger than rural and mining earnings combined, something that is still not widely recognised by the Australian community. Certainly once known, it ought to focus our minds considerably on the importance of protecting the tourist industry and seeing that it is developed, but in a way that is consistent with other principles and policies of the Australian community, let alone of Government or Opposition policies.

There are jobs in the tourist industry. Many of those jobs are smiled at and dismissed as menial, but they do not actually reflect what the tourist industry is built on. Many of the jobs, I am interested to note, are for women, and many of those women are employed in their own small businesses dealing with the day to day running of a profit-returning organisation offering a service to people. There are opportunities for increasingly diverse jobs within tourism, and I think it is important that in understanding the benefits of the industry we also understand the character of it. It is not just a bed-making industry.

I had the pleasure of being in Russia—what used to be called the Soviet Union—a couple of years ago. There we were given immediate and real evidence of the failure of that country to have anything approaching a national transport strategy that could deliver food to the people. Sometimes I am inclined to worry about national strategies on the ground that they seem to be establishing a bureaucracy. When I came home I though about this in terms of a national tourist strategy. It is very much to Australia's credit that we can, firstly, have the skills and sophistication to define and consider a national tourist strategy; and, secondly, define and address the areas of considerable difficulty. It is a measure not only of our sophistication but also of our civility.

I think that is something we need to reflect on. In and amongst the requirements of something like a national strategy—in this case, a national tourism strategy—we have areas of expertise, for example in the computing industry, that are going to provide us with even more export dollar opportunities from marketing those very skills of being able to implement a national strategy. So there is much about the tourist industry that is sophisticated, exciting, profitable, and good for Australia in the short as well as the longer term.

If people have an interest in this area at all, I recommend that they look closely at this report. It is an update of the data and statistics in the whole industry. It also stresses the better way in which the environment and tourism can, must and are beginning to go together. It also points to some changes that might be very constructive in the area of the Foreign Investment Review Board behaviour. All of the recommendations are designed to preserve and develop the tourist industry in this country.

I thank all of those officers in the secretariat who have assisted the Committee over the time in dealing with this report: Peter Grundy, Gay Stevenson, Derek Drinkwater, Christine McPaul, Laurie Swift, Angela Misic and the other officers in the very early stages before the drugs and sport reference intervened, including Mick McLean, Mary-Louise Willheim, Les Rymer, Kay Chee Lance, Doug Hynd and Rosie Jervis. I thank my colleagues and I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I at the outset, on behalf of the WA tourism industry and Broome in particular, just put one thing on the record to help with any misapprehension caused by Senator Crowley's comments about the rising costs in a place like Broome. I can assure all of those people who read this report or Senator Crowley's speech that, even though Broome is a long way away, it is a destination which people from Sydney and Melbourne can get to at a very reasonable price flying with Ansett. Once they get there, they will find that the cost of a beer or a meal at any of the very fine resorts, be it Lord McAlpine's Cable Beach Club, the Auski resort or many of the other resorts in Broome, is very reasonable. I thoroughly recommend it. I tell them not to be put off by Senator Crowley's, I am sure, well-meant reference to some of the implications of increasing tourism numbers.

PARA.TAB: The report on the Australian environment and tourism by the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts is a substantial document which has taken a number of years in its gestation and preparation. I join Senator Crowley in recommending to those people who have an interest in the tourism industry, and of course the environment, to read the report. Most Australians will have an interest in both of those topics because tourism has become so important to Australia's national economic advance. And the environment is a matter of deep concern to all of those who care for the future of this great land, described by Senator Brownhill's favourite poet, Dorothea Mackellar, as a very wide brown land.

The report contains a minority report which was drafted by the Liberal senators, myself, Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Crane—all Western Australian senators and all having names beginning with the letter `C'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you also win the Australian rules football final?

—Yes, the West Coast Eagles did win it. I am reliably informed that they will probably travel to Broome for a bit of rest and recreation after their tremendous victory. I now turn to the topic of the minority report. Most of the majority report I agree with and on most things the Committee had a large degree of consensus. But there were a number of themes in it which I thought deserved some separate comment and recognition.

PARA.TAB: They were, in summary: the whole role of the Commonwealth Government—a central government—in coordinating the tourism industry, the impact of the tourism industry on the environment and the broader environmental questions; the role of the Foreign Investment Review Board; and, lastly, the general concerns about the marketing of tourism and the role of the Federal Government in encouraging investment in tourism and the growth of the tourist industry.

It is important that honourable senators and Senate standing committees do not immediately accept a reference in this Parliament and presume that the outcome of that inquiry should be to see whether or not the Commonwealth Government should get more involved. We should always be healthily sceptical about the role of a central government—one that is often located, particularly with respect to Queensland, Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia, so many miles away from the action or activity. We should always be healthily sceptical about the role that that government can play in successfully trying to change people's behaviour.

I am a confirmed sceptic about the benefits of central government action in many things—particularly in environmental action and often in the area of promotion of industry and investment—in terms of whether or not a Commonwealth government can actually be a positive force. I have yet to be convinced, for example, that setting up an environmental protection authority at the Federal level will actually achieve the worthy aims of trying to protect the Australian environment. Many honourable senators will disagree with that, but it needs to be put on the record that setting out to solve a problem by creating a new bureaucracy has failed many times in the past. And I think setting up a central agency such as an environmental protection authority will not help the environment. I remain to be convinced.

Centralising environmental control can also be dangerous because one of the negative aspects of doing this is that one will in practice smother some of the entrepreneurial work and some of the innovative work at the academic level, in the private sector and in the government sector in trying to create environmental best practice. If we have State governments, local authorities, small businesses, medium sized businesses and academics all around Australia working on achieving best environmental practice, we are likely to come up with a higher degree of success in achieving environmental outcomes than if we have bureaucratic control and political control centralised in Canberra.

That is not to say that there is not an earnest and sensible need for more coordination and exchange or cross-pollination of ideas in matters relating to the environment and environmental protection. I am just a little sceptical about whether something like an environmental protection authority, based in Canberra under the control of the Federal Government, will achieve that end. That is one of the main reasons why I have put forward that view in the minority report attached to this report on the Australian environment and tourism.

The second main comment I wanted to make was on the Government's role in creating an investment environment where we maximise the opportunities for Australia in relation to tourism and particularly international tourism, which is growing in importance. I share Senator Crowley's view that the conflicts between environment and tourism which were commonplace 10 years ago have tended to be diminished and that the major obstacles to investment in tourism, in expanding our tourism infrastructure, are indeed created by governments at a number of levels. I will refer briefly to some of these.

The rigidities in the labour market still make many of our tourism operations not as feasible as they could be and indeed inhibit the sort of service that we provide to international tourists. As Senator Crowley said, the sometimes seemingly menial jobs of changing beds, making cups of tea or coffee for people or serving them toast in the morning are not menial; they are absolutely vital to Australia's economic future.

Even if the front-line troops in the Australian tourism industry happen to be fresh out of grade 10 at school, by serving a bit of toast and a cup of tea to an American or Japanese tourist they are absolutely vital to the future of the Australian economy.

The investment environment we saw around Australia and at Magnetic Island with the stalled Magnetic Quays development—and I also believe that Senator Crowley, on her visit to Broome, saw evidence of a stalled project—was the victim of the monetary policies, the economic policies, of this Government, whereby it forced interest rates very high and ensured that both of those developments stalled in the middle of the process.

I am honestly not trying to score cheap political points here. It is a lesson for all governments of both political persuasions. But here we have two blights on the environment of Australia not because of some mismatching of environmental and tourism objectives but because of the economic policies of a central government which forced the cost of money so high that the developers of these projects were just forced off the sites and were unable to continue. I am sure that, as the economic recovery gains momentum and people are able to re-finance these projects, Australia will be blessed with two new developments, at Magnetic Island and, of course, in Broome in Western Australia.

To add to that, Australia does, with increasing focus on international tourism, need more and more capital going into tourism infrastructure—be it hotels, be it resorts, be it roads, be it railways, or whatever. A recent decision, indeed, a Budget decision of this Government, has put another major brick wall in front of investment in tourism—that is, the decision by the Keating Labor Government, and I believe with the support of the Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Button, to tax limited partnerships.

Limited partnerships are a structure available in Queensland, Western Australia, New South Wales, and lately Victoria, which allow people to invest money with little hope of reward in the medium term, but with tax advantages in the short term, and encourage people to invest in long term projects such as tourism projects which often have a long lead time to get a healthy economic return. The Government decided, I think very unwisely, to tax these limited partnerships, and I am reliably informed by people around Australia that this decision has halted dead in the water a number of proposals to develop tourism resorts, one which I know of in my home State of Western Australia. Again, a decision of the central government has limited the amount of capital which will flow into the tourism industry, which we all agree, on both sides of the chamber, and I believe also in the middle of the chamber, with the Democrats, is an industry which can be environmentally friendly and which can, of course, enhance Australia's economic outlook.

I also wanted to touch on aviation policy. We have had a very controlled, regulated environment. I congratulate the Government on the deregulation that has occurred to date, but of course the deregulation in the air, the deregulation of international flights, naturally turn our focus to what happens when we get on the ground, which is an integral part of the tourism chain. I have already mentioned the school leavers who serve us toast and tea for breakfast. The airports are a crucial part of the tourism chain because the tourism experience starts when one gets on the plane in one's home port and finishes when one gets off the plane and gets home again. So every experience one has on the way through is crucial.

Australia, of course, has highly regulated airports controlled by a central government monopoly. We must ask ourselves, when we compare some of the facilities around Australia with the international experience, whether or not we are developing the very best infrastructure in airports. Of course, the Opposition has made its policy quite clear on airports—that is, they should be owned and controlled by the private sector, allow private capital to flow into them and ensure that we develop them to make sure that Australia can keep up with the infrastructure requirements of the rapidly growing tourism market.

In the short time available to me, I want also to refer to the Foreign Investment Review Board decisions and recommendations made in the majority report. In one recommendation, the majority of the Committee recommended that the Foreign Investment Review Board analyse social impact statements which should be required by developers to look at the social impact of tourism development. We all share a view that the social impact of tourism is something that needs to be looked at and considered. However, it is very hard for me to come to terms with the concept of a body like the Foreign Investment Review Board having to take social impact into account when it is coming to a view on whether or not a foreign investor should invest in Australian tourism—or any other investment, for that matter. I would think that the social impact is something that needs to be considered by the local community, in particular, and that local councils and local democratic processes should perhaps have some say, not over the investment factor, but over the development approval itself.

Again, that brings me back to the point that if one moves tourism and environmental matters into the Federal sphere, through the national environment protection authority, one takes away that decision making from the grassroots level where people can have a direct say in what goes on in their local community. I think it was Dr Suzuki who said, `Think global and act local'. I am afraid that in Australia, we seem to keep thinking globally, not thinking too locally, but acting globally as well. The trouble with the environment is that, even though the environment is an intricate system of interconnected ecosystems, those ecosystems generally start right down at the ground with micro-organisms and build up into bigger ecosystems. They do, of course, in the long term become a massive global ecosystem, but the trouble usually starts down at the ground and the best people to control those problems are people in the local area who have a direct interest in living in a fine environment. I reiterate my scepticism about bureaucrats and politicians in Canberra being able to improve that environment, no matter how well intentioned they are.

The other factor about the Foreign Investment Review Board which is referred to in the minority report is an inconsistency whereby the majority report actually asks the Foreign Investment Review Board to include the pre-1986 reform requirement that net economic benefit be demonstrated. My view, formed after considerable hearings with the Foreign Investment Review Board representatives, was that it is impossible to get anyone to analyse, scientifically or arithmetically, whether a particular development will have a net positive impact for the Australian economy. There are so many variables involved that it is very hard to decide that.

I think that the recommendation of the majority of the Committee in relation to that is actually inconsistent with another of its recommendations. I would recommend that the current position be maintained whereby the Investment Review Board just makes a decision based on whether or not the proposal will have any demonstrable negative impact which, of course, is easier to determine.
I think—Senator Crowley can correct me if I am wrong—that the FIRB was unable to tell us of any proposal to invest in Australian tourism that had actually been knocked back during recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't tell us, but their annual report lists some.

—Yes. The Foreign Investment Review Board is probably operating now more successfully than it has done in the last 10 years, particularly with the reforms relating to the purchase of condominiums associated with resort developments.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the matter of the role of the Commonwealth Government, and the idea of the creation of an environment protection authority. I have made a recommendation in this report which I think is one of the most important ones—that is, to ensure that any legislation for the establishment of a national environment protection authority should be made available for public exposure and public comment for a period of at least six months prior to its being introduced in this Parliament.

I am very worried that in Australia at the moment the environmental agenda is being run by a small handful of people who often have their own agenda to push. I refer, for example, to the listing of World Heritage properties. There is a very good example at the moment with the Nullarbor. The environment Minister federally, the environment Minister in South Australia and the environment Minister in Western Australia agree that they should list the Nullarbor and are proceeding with some speed to list the Nullarbor on the World Heritage listing without any consultation whatsoever with the local community. At the moment, no-one knows exactly where that proposal is. All of the reports are in, but again, there has been no consultation.

The environment protection authority and the process by which it is being set up is being controlled by a small handful of politicians and bureaucrats. What I suggest, in the interests of all Australians, so that they know what sort of national environment protection authority they will get, if indeed they want one, is to have a long period of exposure of the draft legislation to allow everyone to come to grips with the implications of setting up this new centralised controller of the environment. I think that it would be democratic, I think that it would help the environment debate and I think it would allow all levels of society to have some view on the way in which the environment of Australia is controlled in the future.

If we allow the environment protection authority to go down the path it is following at the moment, allow the legislation to be tabled in this place some time between now and Christmas, or whenever it suits the Federal Minister and her Department, allow for a quick debate in the House of Representatives and another debate here—and all of a sudden we will have this new authority—we may actually be taking a step backwards for Australia's environment. I urge all senators and, indeed, the people of Australia to support the idea of making this legislation available for public exposure for at least six months prior to tabling it here. I commend the report to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate a formal tabling speech on the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australian Environment and Tourism Industry Report

SPEECH.PARA: The report that I have just tabled is very much about the environment and tourism. It was not so very long ago as support for the environment grew, so did the tension between the environment and development lobbies which included tourism. Fortunately that attitude has changed. The tourism industry recognises that Australia's major environmental features like the Great Barrier Reef and Uluru Rock are significant drawcards and that it is in the industry's own interest to protect them. However, pressure on the environment will increase as a result of our rapidly expanding tourism industry. Therefore, it is vitally important to be able to identify these threats and ensure that we do not `kill the goose that lays the golden egg'.

The extent of the economic potential of tourism is now widely known. Not only does income from inbound tourists exceed foreign earnings from wool and mineral ores, but growth projections suggest that numbers of inbound tourists will increase by up to three hundred percent over the course of this decade. On any assessment the Australian tourist industry will continue to play an increasing role in the future well being of the Australian economy.

Essentially this is very good news. Economic growth is most welcome in all industries. This is especially the case in labour intensive industries such as tourism. Given appropriate training, these jobs would be permanent and the employees would be part of a dynamic industry with excellent prospects.

This Senate inquiry into the Australian Tourist Industry has therefore been most timely and since December 1990 it has been able to draw on 103 submissions, 1475 pages of Hansard evidence as well as other sources of information to complete its report. The economic dimension of the tourism issue has been a priority concern of the Committee throughout its inspections, hearing and deliberations. The Committee heard from peak authorities of the industry (such as the Australian Tourist Industry Association) on this matter through to individual developers of tourism enterprises and the managers of such projects. There was real enthusiasm for the industry's prospects.

Several questions were raised during the inquiry concerning obstacles to the industry's further development and ways in which those obstacles could be surmounted. The Committee heard about the need for the international marketing of Australian tourism to be better coordinated between the Commonwealth and the States, the need for environmental impact statements for tourism development applications to be assessed competently and expeditiously, and the need for tourism developments to be properly completed so that the environment is protected and any environmental damage during construction to be made good.

With regard to marketing, it was clear to the Committee that the Australian Tourist Commission has been performing a necessary function with competence and should continue. Nevertheless, there is concern about the appropriate role of the States and Territories in the international marketing of Australian tourism. That concern has resulted in coordinated efforts between some States and the recent announcement of the withdrawal of the Northern Territory Tourist Commission from its overseas offices. The Committee has taken this issue a step further with a recommendation that an investigation be carried out by the Tourist Ministers' Council to evaluate whether a rationalisation of overseas representation is required.

Similarly, the Committee was advised that tourism developments need to be assessed competently and expeditiously. It is clear that local and State governments need access to competent advice for the environmental impact assessment of proposed projects. If this is done well it will ensure that developments are both environmentally benign and economically beneficial. It is notable that the National Tourism Strategy released by the Federal Government in June confirms that, through the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment, a cooperative approach will be sought to the management of environmental issues in tourism contexts. For its own part the Committee has expressed its concern that the definition of environment include people; and the Committee has recommended that social and cultural impact statements be prepared for all tourist developments. It is essential therefore that care must also be taken in major tourism developments not to disenfranchise local communities and encroach on their culture. Tourism developments must address any likely dislocation of members of the community including costs of living effects and possible adverse impact on cultural values.

The environment and tourism sectors are very much dependent on one another and they must continue to achieve `win-win' outcomes. The need for tourism developments to be properly completed was highlighted during the Committee's visit to Magnetic Island and inspection of the Magnetic Quay development. There a failed development has resulted in a devastated beach, disfigured headland and siltation on the Great Barrier Reef. These consequences can be deleterious to tourism. The situation on Magnetic Island is due, at least in part, to the fact that the developer went bankrupt. It is regrettable that there can be no guarantees about the economic soundness of developers, and insurance to make repairs to the environment in such circumstances is a difficult proposition—adequate repairs would entail the completion of the project to a certain level. Nevertheless, in this situation there are two steps that can be taken to deal with environmental degradation from tourist developments. The Committee has recommended, first, that projects likely to cause significant scarring only receive development approval conditional upon an undertaking to renovate the area. Second, the Committee recommends that before tourism developments are approved, provision be made for community consultation including with the involvement of local government where appropriate.

The Committee addressed problems of this kind that provide difficulties for the further development of the tourist industry; those difficulties need to be overcome. In addition, the Committee's inquiry revealed three significant areas in which changes of an administrative nature will greatly benefit Australian tourism. These are the report's most important findings.

First, tourism worldwide depends on the availability of a sufficient range of unique sites and features as well as quality facilities including hotels and restaurants. Increasingly, it is also depending on accessible natural sites that are both beautiful and interesting. For an extended period up until late last decade, however, there was a need for the tourism industry to acknowledge the significance for it of the Australian environment and take coordinated steps towards its preservation. This situation was remedied with the publication in mid-1990 by the Australian Tourism Industry Association of its Code of Environmental Practice followed by the Environmental Guidelines for Tourist Developments.

The Committee was particularly pleased to note these initiatives on the part of the tourism industry. And close scrutiny of these documents revealed their soundness in appreciation of the environment and its protection. The Committee endorses the ATIA's documents from that perspective. The implementation of the Code and Guidelines could ensure that many of the more regrettable mistakes in tourism developments in Australia will not be repeated.

The second area of change that could significantly benefit tourism concerns foreign investment. The Committee found that there is general agreement that foreign capital is welcome if not necessary for the development and support of the Australian tourist industry. This agreement extends from the Commonwealth Government and the States to the Bureau of Tourism Research and the tourism industry. One of the Committee's most important findings was that the operation of the Foreign Investment Review Board, the authority charged with advising the Treasurer on foreign investment proposals, needs to be reformed. The Committee found that the FIRB process for recommending approval of foreign investment has not been fully independent. Further, the FIRB has not comprehensively monitored projects that have been approved. And the FIRB needs to acknowledge the full scope of its responsibilities under the Impact of Proposals Act with regard to the social impact of developments.
In order to address these problems the Committee has proposed a number of recommendation relating to the structure and method of operation of the FIRB.

The third major finding of the Committee's inquiry concerns the need for accurate and comprehensive statistics about the industry to assist development planning. The Committee's task of inquiring into the Australian tourist industry was complicated by the fact that statistics on the industry are not collected and presented uniformly and comprehensively. Since the Committee inquiry began, however, some significant steps have been taken to address the inadequate state of tourism industry statistics. In June 1991 the Australian Bureau of Statistics released its Framework for the Collection and Publication of Tourism Statistics. It remains for the collectors of the data to provide the data in accordance with the formula.

In concluding my remarks, I believe that the Australian Landscape is one of our greatest assets. Valued appropriately and managed properly, it can become the centrepiece of our rapidly developing Tourism Industry. Our report has endeavoured to draw together the major issues associated with the development and proper management of a long term, sustainable industry. The recommendations we have made, we believe, will go a long way to ensuring that the tourism sector continues to expand and develop into one of our key industry sectors, providing wealth and employment opportunities well into the twenty first century.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this report in view of some remarks which Senator Campbell has just made. I find it passing strange that earlier today when giving notices of motion both Senators Campbell and Panizza strongly supported mining in a national park, namely, the Karijini National Park in the Pilbara in Western Australia, despite the fact that there are more than adequate supplies for hundreds of years of iron ore outside the national park and despite the fact that the pebble mouse, which is on the threatened species list, is within the national park and that the most important site for that animal lies within that national park area.

PARA.TAB: For Senator Campbell to be arguing that the local population should do battle with the large forces of some of the mining interests and try to deny the Federal Government some role in setting environmental standards again I find somewhat strange.

Senator Campbell also mentioned the Magnetic Quays development and laid the failure of that development at the foot of the Federal Government in relation to its economic policies. It seems to me quite clear that what happened in that case was that inadequate attention was given to the economic viability of the proposer of that development. Inadequate conditions were written in, in that the developer was supposed to have taken out an insurance policy so that if there was an economic failure or bankruptcy of that development company provision was made for the restoration of the area. Neither was that provision insisted upon nor was the provision that was written in acted upon before the date of expiry in relation to Magnetic Quays. There was a failure of the environmental protection process in relation to the Magnetic Quays development, and that is what has led to very serious damage to the environment in that area.

I want to pick up the point made by Senator Crowley that there are really two extremes in the tourism industry. There is the beer, brothels and casino type of tourism industry that one sees well exemplified on the Gold Coast with the glitz, glamour and the high cost type of holidays. That is one type of tourism. The other extreme is tourism which one can only associate with wilderness and which, as Senator Crowley pointed out, is necessarily associated with very low population density—in fact, very often so low that one needs to be completely alone in those locations to enjoy the wilderness experience.

The first type of tourism depends particularly on sight—going quickly to an area and having a look at something—and the other type depends very much on a full range of experiences such as sound, touch, smell and aloneness with a natural environment. That latter type of tourism is very much in danger of being lost in Australia, yet Australia is one of the last countries in the world where one can have a wilderness experience. Within the next few decades wilderness will probably disappear from the face of this planet, with the exception of a few places in Australia where it can still be experienced.

While there is not a large immediate profit to be made from wilderness tourism—indeed, it is the most rapidly growing area of tourism—over hundreds of years the integrated economic return to be made from that type of activity, leaving aside the very important cultural and experiential aspects, is very great indeed. We need to recognise the great importance of hanging on to those wilderness areas and maintaining very low population densities so that people can continue for many future generations to experience wilderness.

In the last week I was down in northern Tasmania in an area which has come to be known as the Tarkine, an area of temperate rainforest, where quite clearly the number of people who could go into that area and experience it at first hand would be very small at any given time. There are very few examples left in the world of temperate rainforest. In terms of the integrity of the central area, the area is still very much intact with very little human intrusion and one which really should be incorporated into the World Heritage area.

That brings me back to what Senator Campbell was saying, that these sorts of areas do need Federal activity to ensure that they are protected. By their very nature, these areas have very low population densities and do not have people who might raise a case for or against tourism. These areas, which share characteristics right across Australia, need Federal Government intervention to ensure that they are properly protected and that there are comprehensive conditions laid down for their protection.

That also brings in the matter of threatened species. Over many years we have been expecting Federal legislation to protect threatened species. It has been promised for at least seven years, to my knowledge. We are still to see that legislation. We understand the legislation which is in the process of being argued by several Federal Ministers is likely to be significantly watered down; yet this is an area, in contradistinction to what Senator Campbell said, which demands Federal comprehensive legislation across the whole of Australia.

Certainly the application of that legislation needs to be administered through some local knowledge, and that needs to be fed into the system. But without that comprehensive Federal legislation it will simply fail to protect threatened species. We will fail to protect the wilderness experience, of which Australia is one of the last refuges in this world.

I simply add on the plea that that other end of tourism, the low population density end of tourism—that which offers the wilderness experience where one puts a pack on one's back, walks for several days and sees very few other human beings—is the sort of tourism that Australia can continue to offer for a very long time into the future provided we look after it; yet I believe it is in danger of disappearing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to briefly finish off the remarks I started before lunch. We were discussing the motion by Senator Sowada to disallow the regulations of the Federal Airports Corporation, specifically those not requiring them to observe State environmental protection laws in relation to environmental impact studies and the third runway in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: The point I was making was that the figures Senator Sowada had presented indicated that the risk to the people of Sydney of that third airway were way above the acceptable levels of risk in an industrial capacity. In this capacity one is dealing with a general population which in the main stands to gain nothing in particular from the expansion of that airport whereas in an industrial situation the worker at least expects to get some employment from the exposure to potentially dangerous situations.

I also made the point that the recent crash in Amsterdam did not involve a plane immediately after take-off—the plane was in fact attempting to return to the airport when it crashed—and the claim made by Senator Cook in relation to take-offs over Botany Bay was largely irrelevant to that situation. Almost certainly, a plane losing two engines and attempting to return would be circling over either an area of population or, perhaps even more dangerously, over some of the chemical storage facilities or some of the petroleum dumps and refining facilities which surround Botany Bay. So the risks are really quite considerable and, as Senator Sowada has pointed out, some of those aspects were not taken into account in relation to the Federal environmental impact statement procedure.

Last night, Senator Kemp, who I believe is the shadow Minister for Democrat bashing, was analysing the number of times the Democrats had voted with either the Opposition or the Government. Quite clearly, in this particular case, which we see as a very important issue, the Democrats will call a division and the Government and the Opposition will vote together. According to Senator Kemp's own figures, there were 97 occasions on which the Democrats raised amendments and very important points when the Opposition and the Government voted together. Yesterday, Senator Short put out a press release entitled `Democrats Destroy Coalition's Major Senate Initiative'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The issue before the Senate is the motion moved by Senator Sowada. The issue being pursued by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, contrary to an agreement made earlier today between the Whips, is an entirely different matter, in which he is obviously expressing the extreme sensitivity of the Democrats, and has nothing whatsoever to do with the issues raised by his colleague Senator Sowada. I would ask you to draw him to attention and ask him to make his comments relevant, given that he is speaking outside the agreement. This shows that the Democrats cannot honour any agreement they make.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, the point I am making is that this is an important issue.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—I will rule on the issue before you continue, Senator Coulter. I uphold Senator Tambling's point of order and I ask you to return to the subject before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was exactly the point I was making: that this substantive issue we are debating is an important issue unlike the issue raised yesterday which the Opposition identified as an important issue, namely, whether we have two minutes or four minutes for Ministers to answer questions. The Opposition has decided that that is an important issue. This is an important issue which will go down as occasion No. 98 on which the Government and the Opposition voted together—something which they do very often because there is precious little to choose between the Government and the Opposition.
—Stupid, idiotic amendments, you mental midget!
—Senator Knowles, I heard that. Would you withdraw?
—I withdraw.

—That interjection was rather interesting. A moment ago we had Senator Campbell saying that we should not have Federal legislation but should stick with State and local government legislation to protect the environment. Here in this particular debate that is precisely what we are attempting to do: to say that the State law in New South Wales in relation to environmental protection, which is supported by the residents of Sydney, should be observed.

PARA.TAB: How inconsistent can the Opposition get? For Senator Knowles to argue that the very point her colleague was making five minutes ago is a stupid point is very interesting indeed. Of course it is a stupid point; it was just made by her colleague Senator Campbell. So go outside and take it up with him!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask Senator Coulter to withdraw that. I did not make the comment against Senator Campbell and he knows it.
—There is no point of order there.
—I am not casting aspersions against Senator Campbell, and Senator Coulter knows it.
—Order! Senator Knowles! Can we return to the subject in front of us, Senator Coulter.

—I was simply pointing out the inconsistency in Senator Knowles's interjection. The point that Senator Sowada and I are taking in relation to prevailing Federal Government laws is exactly the same point that Senator Campbell was making only five minutes ago and which Senator Knowles just said was a silly, stupid point. I am just saying that obviously Senator Knowles does not know logic when she sees it and she should go outside—
—Why don't you stick to your agreement?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order: there is an act of terrorism going on from the other side. I ask you to pull Senator Knowles up and let Senator Coulter continue with his contribution.
—Continue, Senator Coulter.

—In this situation, particularly given the fact that there is a legal challenge in train and that there are aspects of the environmental impact requirements under New South Wales law which have not been fulfilled under the Federal Government's legislation, we are calling for the regulations in this case to be disallowed. That is the point we are making. It is essentially the point Senator Campbell was making only a few moments ago, and I thank him for supporting us, although I am sure that when we come to the vote he will, as typically happens, vote with the Government.
—in reply—I rise to make a few remarks in reply. I do thank honourable senators—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I was attacked in the last speech by Senator Coulter and I would like to make a personal explanation.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Sowada is on her feet and about to make a speech. Senator Kemp can make a personal explanation at the end of her contribution, but he should not be allowed to interrupt it.
—Senator Kemp, you can make your personal explanation at the end of the debate. I believe Senator Sowada is closing the debate.

—I think we are all looking forward to the conclusion of this debate so that we can move to other matters—and I look forward to hearing Senator Kemp's personal explanation. But I do thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. Both the Government and the Opposition made very reasoned contributions, and I thank Senator Newman and Senator Cook. However, there are a number of points I would like to address in response to the issues raised by honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: In response to a couple of points raised by Senator Newman, the Australian Democrats certainly do agree with her point that Sydney does need increased airport capacity. I do not think anyone with half a brain would disagree that that is necessary. We support any move to increase that capacity. However, we do not believe that the third runway is the way to go. We support the fast tracking of Badgerys Creek and one would be very hard pressed to find anyone in Sydney who opposes the Badgerys Creek airport. In fact, the western Sydney regional councils have requested of the Federal Government that the development be fast tracked and speeded up so it can come on stream much sooner than its current completion date.

Bankstown airport is a very important existing facility for light aircraft. It has been suggested on many occasions that the smooth running of Mascot airport would be assisted by moving many of the smaller aircraft at Kingsford-Smith to Bankstown. I understand that Richmond Air Force base will slowly be changed from military use to civilian use. We could possibly see many of the cargo flights that currently go into Mascot move to Richmond. Even Williamtown airport in Newcastle has a very important role to play in developing wide ranging airport services in the Sydney region. So it is not just a matter of Kingsford-Smith. There are many options. We believe—and this has been suggested by a number of people—that even better management at Kingsford-Smith would result in a better flow of air traffic.

Senator Newman accused us of listening to troglodytes. I hope that she was not referring to the very sincere local community groups and local residents who have voiced their concern about the third runway. I hope that she does not use the word `troglodytes' when she is referring to those lobby groups who come to see her when they have an issue of concern. I certainly hope that she would perhaps give the members of the Atomic Ex-Servicemen's Association a better hearing than they got when they came to see her about their claim for compensation.

Senator Newman referred to a range of issues that she believes were adequately addressed by the EIS. It may well be her opinion that those issues were addressed, but there are a lot of people who believe that those issues were not adequately addressed by the environmental impact statement. That matter is now before the courts and it should be decided there. If that environmental impact statement has adequately met all the concerns and has addressed all the issues, the FAC should have nothing to fear from the courts scrutinising that document and coming up with a judgment in its favour.

Ours is not a delaying tactic, as has been claimed by the Opposition and, I suggest, by the Government. In fact, the Opposition should be desperately concerned about the processes at work here. One of the main reasons I have raised this issue in the Senate is that, once again, the Federal Government is using the processes of this chamber and the Parliament to ride roughshod over local communities and the States.

A matter of great concern was raised here in relation to the ANSTO Amendment Bill. The Government was successful in respect of the issue of radioactive waste at Lucas Heights. Thanks to the actions of this Government, we now have a situation where the management of radioactive waste by ANSTO is not covered by any State planning environment law anywhere in Australia.

What we are seeing once again is the Federal Government riding roughshod over the States, believing that it can take matters into its own hands when it does not like what is presented to it by way of State legislation. We believe it is very important that this principle be opposed. To that extent, we have pleaded with the Opposition to defend vigorously, as it has in the past, the rights of the States. It should once again recognise that this is a very arrogant move on the part of the Government. The Government has not consulted anyone. The State governments have found the Government's actions so offensive that they have joined in an action in the High Court. In fact, I am amazed at the Opposition's response in this matter. Where are the defenders of States rights? The Opposition is the group in this Parliament that will continue vigorously to defend States rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, for example.

—Exactly. Just five minutes ago, Senator Campbell was on his feet defending the States. I have to say that I agreed with a number of issues that Senator Campbell raised in his address; they were very valid. However, when we are presented with clear Federal Government intervention in matters pertaining to a State, we find that the Opposition just collapses in a heap. It is the first group to jump on to the bandwagon with the Government and ride roughshod over the will of the States and over those groups that it has so vigorously protected in the past.

PARA.TAB: Once again, I suggest to the Federal Government that its actions here are extremely arrogant. This is something that has happened before. I ask the Government: how many times will we have to put up with this kind of legislating to ensure that its Federal statutory authorities can simply ignore State legislation that otherwise applies to the activities of every other commercial entity and business in every other respect? I ask the Opposition to reconsider its decision on this matter as this device is being used increasingly by this Government to ride roughshod over the States. It is not something that the Australian Democrats would support, and I hope that the Opposition would do likewise. I commend the motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Sowada's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—The fact of the matter is that no person on this side of the chamber is appointed to bash the Democrats. —The point that I wish to make is that no-one on this side of the chamber, including me, has been appointed as a shadow Minister for Democrat bashing because it is our duty—indeed, it is the duty of every one of us in this chamber—to bring to the attention of the chamber the ceaseless way in which the Australian Democrats have danced to the Labor tune and constantly supported the Labor Party in critical divisions.

DEBATE.TITLE: DISABILITY DISCRIMINATION BILL 1992HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 September, on motion by Senator Bolkus, and 20 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Disability Discrimination Bill 1992. I begin by reminding the Senate of speeches made in relation to this Bill in the House of Representatives on 19 August of this year. My shadow Ministry representative, Mr Bruce Scott, led the debate for the Federal coalition and was followed by the Liberal MP Mr Russell Broadbent, who spoke of his extensive work in the disability field. Another Liberal member of parliament, Mr John Bradford, told the House:

PARA.TAB: Community attitudes to the disabled vary enormously. Generally I believe that most people support the principle, and so they should, that disabled people should not be discriminated against. I think many people would go further and suggest that if there is to be discrimination, it should be in favour of those who are disabled.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, took an arm's length position when he called the Bill `a heyday for the social engineers' and expressed frustration with its aims. While his views may be extreme, they do reflect widespread scepticism in the community about the so-called politics of difference and the need to legislate for social change. Mr Campbell's colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Gary Johns, tried to make up lost ground for the Government.

PARA.TAB: I would like to remind honourable senators of the words of Minister Howe in May this year when he told the House of Representatives that the Bill `represents a landmark in receiving human rights for all Australians'. He said:
This Government has a long term commitment to achieving a better deal for people with disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister then invited interested parties to comment on the legislation over the winter recess. Several months later the Minister and his Bill are now under fire from such respected groups as the Australian Medical Association and the Australian Association of Surgeons. Both associations have expressed concern about the expanded definition of the term `disability' and the rights of health professionals when dealing with HIV positive patients.

PARA.TAB: Even groups representing people with disabilities have hit out at the Bill, labelling it as discriminatory and a mockery of the very essence of the reasons for the Bill. Letters and faxes expressing concern about this Bill have poured into my office over recent months. I have brought a number of the submissions to the attention of the Minister's office. However, the Minister remains unconcerned and unmoved. I am appalled that there is not one backbench Labor member listed to speak in the debate in this chamber today. I am surprised that Senator Zakharov and Senator West, who have normally been champions in this area for many constituencies, are not speaking and we are to hear only from the Minister in charge of the Bill, in summary—in a similar way to the way the issue was dealt with by the Parliamentary Secretary, and probably with the same briefing notes that Mr Johns used in the House of Representatives in August.

On the other hand, the Federal coalition is seeking to obtain details of all submissions made to the Government so that the concerns raised in them may be properly addressed. We have asked for a full list of people and groups who have made submissions. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that it was Minister Howe who publicly invited community organisations and groups to make submissions on this legislation to the Attorney-General's Department. I have been informed that the Attorney-General's Department has been precluded from making available the numbers of people who made submissions, the list of names and the comprehensive issues raised. I have been provided only with a summary of the main issues that have been addressed.

We need to ask: why is the Government refusing to disclose the numbers of submissions and the details as requested? Back in August the Federal coalition was so concerned about the Government's lack of cooperation that we asked the House of Representatives to refer this very important Bill to a joint select committee for proper parliamentary scrutiny. Our second reading amendment, moved in the House of Representatives, read in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that . . . a Joint Select Committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on the Disability Discrimination Bill 1992 . . . be appointed to inquire into and report . . . on the following matters:
(1)a general assessment of the outcomes of the proposed legislation in relation both to persons with disabilities and others in the community, including:

PARA.TAB: (a)the appropriateness of exemptions included in the Bill, particularly for the telecommunications industry and the deaf community and whether further exemptions should be included, for example, for the Australian Defence Force;
(b)whether the Bill deals satisfactorily with significant issues of health policy and whether these could be dealt with more appropriately in separate legislation;

(c)the appropriateness of the definition of `disability', including an examination of existing definitions of disability in the UN Declaration of the Rights of Disabled Persons and/or State legislation, the reasons why the proposed definition is different and whether it should include, for example, cognitive and neurological dysfunctions;
(d)the need to clarify provisions relating to `unjustifiable hardship' and `action plans';

(e)the interrelationship of the legislation with existing legislative provisions such as the `compulsory conference' procedure and the procedures in existing racial and sex discrimination legislation; and

SPEECH.PARA: (2)whether the mechanisms contained in the Bill are the most appropriate means of reducing disadvantages experienced by people with disabilities, including a detailed examination of the costs of the proposed legislation to industry and taxpayers and of the practicalities of its implementation.

Our amendment was rejected. Various peak bodies have made representations to me, as well as to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, and they are the tip of the iceberg in relation to concerns about the Bill. For example, the Confederation of Australian Industry strongly opposed the legislation, saying that employment decisions should be taken on the grounds of merit. The Law Institute of Victoria questioned why the burden of proof in disproving the exemption of unjustifiable hardship rested with the complainant. The Multiple Sclerosis Society of Victoria highlighted the ambiguity of `unjustifiable hardship' and the lack of action plan monitoring. The Senate's own Scrutiny of Bills Committee found that the legislation failed to set out the qualities and attributes needed for a person appointed to preside over a compulsory conference.

PARA.TAB: Reading the representations, I find a common concern relates to exemptions, particularly the proposed three-year exemption for the telecommunications industry. The Royal South Australian Deaf Society went as far as describing the Bill as discriminatory and, as such, not acceptable to the deaf community.

The definition of `disability' covers physical, sensory, cognitive, neurological, intellectual and psychiatric impairment, mental illness or disorder and the presence in the body of organisms causing or capable of causing disease. It is worth noting that cognitive and neurological impairment were not included in the original explanatory memorandum. The Liberal and the National Federal coalition took up the issue with the Government in the House of Representatives in August. I am pleased that it has finally agreed to it.

Controversy continues to surround the definition of `disability' and the fact that it includes `the presence in the body of organisms capable of causing disease'. I received a barrage of criticism about this definition. The Australian Medical Association rightly pointed out that virtually all Australians carry organisms in their body capable of causing disease. The need to protect personal or private health was also raised in the AMA submission as well as the need for a special exemption to cover the health professions.

Similarly, the Australian Association of Surgeons expressed concern that the Bill would make it illegal for a surgeon to refuse to perform an elective procedure on a known HIV positive patient. While acknowledging that the Bill was laudable in concept, the Association felt that its implications have not been thought through, particularly in regard to the medical profession.

The cost of establishing the Office of the Disability Discrimination Commissioner, funding public education programs, support agencies, additional staffing and legal aid is also contentious. The explanatory memorandum provided to the House of Representatives predicted that this cost would be $5.5m in the first year. Yet the memorandum now provided to the Senate forecasts just $2.3m. The reason for this massive $3.2m discrepancy lies in the Federal Budget Papers. Far from delivering the expected $5.5m, the Federal Government came up with only $1.553m in the first year, $1.032m in 1993-94 and $0.761m recurrently. Such evidence exposes the rhetoric of this Federal Labor Government and again calls into question its much publicised bona fides.

I now turn to the principles of this Bill. The legislation is complaints based and provides for the establishment of an office of the Disability Discrimination Commissioner who will be part of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Commissioner will try to conciliate complaints but, where that process is unsuccessful, the Commission can inquire into complaints and make determinations. The determinations, which are not binding on the parties, but enforceable in the Federal Court, include remedial action and payment of compensation. The legislation specifies that damage can cover injury to a complainant's feelings or for humiliation that the person might suffer. The Federal Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, illustrates this point with the case of a Tasmanian footballer banned from playing because he was HIV positive. Speaking on ABC radio on 17 July this year, he said that the footballer could soon have recourse to new anti-discrimination law and demand compensation from the local league.

The Bill also provides that only reasonable accommodation needs to be made for people with disabilities. Persons against whom complaints are made can argue that the accommodation necessarily involves unjustifiable hardship. Similarly, an employer can argue that a person with a disability is unable to carry out the inherent requirement of the job. The Bill provides for the introduction of disability standards should the Government and relevant parties decide that they are necessary. The standards relate to employment, education, accommodation, provision of public transport services and facilities and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs. Service providers also have an opportunity to lodge action plans with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission outlining long term strategies to overcome perceived discriminatory practices.

The legislation exempts charities, the telecommunications industry for three years, pensions and allowances, migration, combat duties and peacekeeping services by the Australian Defence Force and peacekeeping services by the Australian Federal Police. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission may also grant temporary exemptions.

Originally, this Bill defined `de facto spouse' as a person living with another person `on a bona fide domestic basis, although not legally married, whether or not they are of the same sex'. The definition broke new ground because it extended the definition of `de facto spouse' to homosexual couples for the first time. Last month the House of Representatives amended the legislation by deleting the definition of `de facto spouse' and defining `associate' as a spouse, a person living with another person on a genuine domestic basis, relative, carer or a person in a business, sporting or recreational relationship.

Unfortunately, too few of the Federal coalition's concerns have been addressed by the Government. In fact, the Minister's Parliamentary Secretary gave a less than convincing response on 19 August. We believe the issues raised in the submissions sent to us and in some of those that I have since seen sent to the Senate Committee are fundamental and deserve thorough consideration by the Senate Committee. I am pleased to note that that Committee will be meeting this coming Friday.

The funding discrepancies outlined earlier must be pursued to ensure that the Government is not creating false expectations, then dashing hopes through Budget shortfalls. Similarly, we have asked for a full list of all of the issues identified in the submission sent to the Attorney-General's Department and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission which the Minister for Community Services himself invited. Why should any of those issues be withheld? I can certainly understand that some of the names might be withheld on the basis of privacy, but there should be no withholding whatsoever of any of the details or the issue. What hypocrisy—inviting the major players to request and suggest amendments to the legislation, and then filing their suggestions in the bottom drawer. They had better be available to the Senate Committee in full detail on Friday. Exactly how many submissions is the Government hiding and what details are not being disclosed? Until the Senate Committee sees this full list of suggested amendments and the Government's reasons for rejecting them, the Minister makes a mockery of the parliamentary process.

The objects of this Disability Discrimination Bill are highly commendable. I recall reading a 1990 speech by the United States President, George Bush, in which he told the National Leadership Coalition on Aids:

SPEECH.PARA: We're in a fight against disease—not a fight against people.

Once disease strikes, we don't blame those who are suffering. We don't spurn the accident victim—he didn't wear his seatbelt. We don't reject the cancer patient who didn't quit smoking. We try to love them and care for them and comfort them. We don't fire them. We don't evict them. We don't cancel their insurance.

The speech by President Bush covers a wide range of issues that ought to challenge us. I therefore seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the text of his remarks of 2 April 1990 for the information of honourable senators and other interested people.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Official Text
United States Information Service
April 2, 1990
Bush wants law passed banning AIDS discrimination

PARA.TAB: Washington—President Bush called on the U.S. House of Representatives to pass a law that would ban discrimination against persons infected with the AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) virus.
He told the National Leadership Coalition on AIDS meeting March 29, "We're in a fight against a disease—not a fight against people. And we won't tolerate discrimination.
The legislation the president referred to is the Americans with Disabilities Act, which has been passed by the Senate and is now pending before two House committees.

The president said he was encouraged that the projected AIDS infection rate will not be as high as estimated a year ago. He said that the effort to combat AIDS includes research into a class of virus that might cause not only AIDS, but also such other diseases as muscular dystrophy, multiple sclerosis and at least two forms of leukemia.
Following is the text of the president's remarks:

I am delighted, and I really mean that, to be here with you today, the leaders who guide American business as it helps those suffering with HIV and AIDS. You make our hearts glad, and you make your country proud.

Other generations have faced life threatening medical crises, from polio to the plague, and this virus is our challenge—not a challenge we sought, not a challenge we chose—but today, our responsibility is clear: We must meet the challenge, we must beat this virus, for whether talking about a nation or an individual, character is measured not by our tragedies but by our response to those tragedies. And for those who are living with HIV and AIDS, our response is clear. They deserve our compassion, they deserve our care, and they deserve more than a chance, they deserve a cure. America will accept nothing less. We are slashing red tape, accelerating schedules, boosting research, and somewhere out there, there is a Nobel prize and the gratitude of planet Earth waiting for the man or woman who discovers the answer that's eluded everyone else.
We pray that that day will come soon, but until that day, until this virus can be defeated by science, there is a battle to be waged by society.
Because in 1990, the most effective weapon in our arsenal against AIDS is not just medication, but also education.
Our goal is to turn irrational fear into rational acts. And every American must learn what AIDS is and what AIDS is not. And they must learn now.

Every American must learn what AIDS is—and what AIDS is not. And they must learn. You in this room already know. The HIV virus is not spread by handshakes or hugs. You can't get it from food or drink, coughing or sneezing or by sharing bathrooms or towels or conversation.
The transmission of HIV is as simple as it is deadly. In most cases, it's determined not by what you are, but by what you do and by what you fail to do.
Let me state clearly: People are placed at risk not by their demographics, but by their deeds—by their behaviour.
