I wonder whether he has mentioned it to the countless thousands of small businesses that have gone to the wall in the last couple of years and that are still going to the wall as a result of his policies. I wonder whether he has mentioned it to some of the major companies in Australia which, as we pointed out in the Senate today on several occasions, have said quite categorically that economic recovery in Australia will not be under way at least for the next two, three or four years.

What the Government has done with this year's Budget, and what it is using the Loan Bill as a mechanical device to fund, is to provide Australia with one of the most spendthrift Budgets relative to the needs of our circumstances that we have ever had in our history. There has been an enormous increase in government spending this year, a 9 per cent increase—$9 billion, or 6 per cent in real terms. It has put enormous pressure on financial markets. The inevitable result of that will be to push up interest rates. Senator Collins, who is present in the chamber, might care to confirm this a bit later, but the Caucus economic committee yesterday received a report from the ANZ Bank which said that interest rates would go higher under the policies of this Government. We have all the seeds of a further major blow-out in the balance of payments, which continues to be in huge deficit. We are now in hock to the rest of the world by $150,000 million, that is, more than $8500 for every man, woman and child in this nation. That is a figure that compares with our debt to the rest of the world of $8 billion net around the time that the Hawke Labor Government first came to office in 1983.

So what we have seen during the 1980s and the early 1990s is a progressive deterioration in Australia's standard of living. Countless hundreds of thousands of people, particularly middle Australians, now suffer a lower living standard in absolute terms than they did 10 years ago. Every Australian is suffering a fall in his or her relative living standard compared with 10 years ago when we look at the performance of this nation compared with that of our trading partners and most other countries around the world.

We have fundamental problems in this country which are unprecedented. We have a Government which has absolutely lost control of the fiscal situation. That is part of the reason why we have these Bills before us today. We have a Prime Minister who, as Treasurer, caused those problems and who now says that those problems are behind us, when it is clear to every person in the real world, in the real Australia—I do not know where the Prime Minister gets his information from; he is not prepared to tell us—that the recession is far from behind us. Indeed, if anything, in many important quarters it is worsening. Certainly the hardship and the cruelty of that recession are biting as deeply now as ever they were.

It is for those reasons that, whilst not opposing these Bills because they are essentially mechanical Bills, the coalition nevertheless believes that, firstly, the Supply Bills are unnecessary and, secondly, are the result of gross fiscal mismanagement and policy incompetence on the part of this Government. The Loan Bill will certainly be required this year more than in most previous years to finance the gigantic hole in the Government's finances. That is why I have moved the amendment, which has now been circulated, to the Supply Bills.

I am sure that my colleagues in this debate will follow me in condemning the Government for the tremendous economic hardship it has caused in this country and for the difficulties it has built into this nation that make a solution to our problems more intractable day by day. The only solution that we have for any sustainable basis in Australia today is to get rid of this Government at the first possible opportunity and to replace it with a government which is prepared to take the decisions that will enable Australians, individuals and businesses, to have the incentive, the hope and the opportunity for growth in the future for employment, for wealth creation—for all those things that are necessary to return the Australia of the 1990s to the Australia which we cherished and benefited so much from in the 1960s, up until the tragedies that befell it as a result of the policies of the Whitlam Government and later the Hawke Government. The sooner that change is made the better; the longer it is delayed the more intractable those problems will become.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Short to Supply Bill (No. 3) 1992-93 and Supply Bill (No. 4) 1992-93. In doing so, I support many of the remarks he has made. To reinforce some of those points—indeed, to make some extra ones—I refer to the Hansard of the Estimates Committee hearing on 22 September when Senator Short, Senator Kemp and I asked questions of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, about the reasons for the Supply Bills being used as a tool to give the Government the ability to spend and spend quickly.

PARA.TAB: If we look at precedent, we have previously seen the Government in need of appropriating additional funds. When the Iraq-Kuwait war was declared and prosecuted, we found ourselves with a shortfall on payment for wheat, the `insurance' for which is organised by EFIC but which in fact is paid out of Consolidated Revenue. In order for additional money to be made available, there was an additional appropriation Bill introduced, thereby allowing the money to be properly appropriated and spent.

In this case, we have, if you like, a similar circumstance. We have not had war declared but we have had a recession declared. There are additional expenditures, as Senator Short pointed out. Part of the additional expenditure is $170m for programs for which there is no appropriation. The Government might argue that it had not decided it was going to spend that additional money at the time of the preparation of the Budget or the Appropriation Bills themselves so it needed another mechanism. Surely, precedent could have been followed and there could have been an additional No. 3 appropriation Bill which very simply would have appropriated that money in the proper and orderly way.

The questioning that went on in the Estimates Committee will show why the Government was not interested in following proper procedure. Senator Short said during the hearing that the overwhelming impression he got was that the Government had taken this course of action to enable it to spend very heavily in the first few months of this financial year to give itself an additional option in terms of an early election and, in doing so, had adopted procedures in terms of budgetary processes that were unprecedented. Senator Short asked Senator McMullan whether he wanted to comment. Senator McMullan said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is so silly that it is not worth making a comment. I have nothing to add.
I then asked Senator McMullan:
The Supply Bills will give you instant money, will they not?
Senator McMullan replied:
When they are passed, they will give us the right to spend $170m for the purposes set out in the Bills.
I said:
As the Manager of Government Business, how quickly do you think you will get those Bills through?
Senator McMullan replied:
I expect that they will be passed in the next sitting week.
I said:
So we will have instantly $170m. How much do we have left in the Advance to the Minister for Finance?

That question, of course, was unable to be answered by anyone; and I am still waiting for the answer. Of course, a mechanism that could have been used by the Government—if it wished, if it had gone the appropriation Bill route—was to have sought an Advance from the Minister for Finance and spent the money on the basis that it would be reimbursed once the Appropriation Bills were passed. The problem with that is that there is not enough money left in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to allow that money to be withdrawn and meet the other demands that would be placed upon it before the Appropriation Bills are passed. When I asked Senator McMullan when he expected to get the Appropriation Bills, he replied, `The end of November'.

PARA.TAB: So we have seen that the real reason for the use and the creation of these two Supply Bills very simply is to allow the Government to have instant cash to spend in case it wants to have an early election. All along, this early election option has been maintained by the Government, looking for a window of opportunity. The Victorian election last week has probably shut that window, but at the time of the drafting of these Supply Bills and the working out of this strategy the Government needed to keep that window open, to keep the opportunity of an early election in December or at the end of November available to it.

If the Government were to get any advantage out of the programs, the intent of which is set out in the Bills, it would have to spend the money now. The only way it can spend the money now is to have these Supply Bills, which are unprecedented in being introduced contemporaneously with the Appropriation Bills. I can only imagine that the money that it will spend now will have to be finally appropriated in the Supplementary Estimates next year, unless we have an additional Bill somewhere else along the line.

What we are seeing is a highly contrived use of Bills which were designed very simply for another purpose but which are serving the Government's purpose of the day. It is not the good government of Australia—which is what it is charged with—but is simply political servicing because it gets a political advantage out of getting instant money. I will quote again from the Estimates Committee hearings. I asked Senator McMullan:

SPEECH.PARA: The Supply Bills will give you instant money, will they not?
He replied:
When they are passed, they will give us the right to spend $170m for the purposes set out in the Bills.

That is at the end of this week. It is cynical, but no more cynical, as Senator Short pointed out when he dealt with the Loan Bill, than saying that because of the additional expenditure again the mechanism is needed to allow additional funds to be raised.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short's amendment condemns the Government for the use of these contrivances and condemns the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for being so out of touch with the reality of the continuing economic recession and hardship—of which he, on his own acknowledgment, was the chief architect—that he can assert that Australia's recession ended long ago. Ask the million people who are unemployed if the recession ended long ago; ask the 300,000 Australians who are now long term unemployed if it ended long ago; and ask the school leavers who are facing the prospect of attempting to get into the work force next year if the recession ended long ago.

We have in our Prime Minister a man who is politically clever: he knows how to use a contrivance to get his hands on an additional $170m cash now to spend for political advantage; he knows how to borrow and add to our international debt so that he can meet his additional expenditure which is, quite frankly, necessary because of ineptitude on behalf of the Government's handling of legislation and, of course, the economy itself. It is a very cynical exercise.

When something like Supply Bills are listed on the Notice Paper they do not normally excite much interest, but on this occasion I think it is necessary to point out that it is a very cynical use of a mechanism which was designed for another purpose but which this very politically clever Prime Minister has seen he can use to his own political advantage. At least perhaps those who are listening to this particular debate or those who read the Hansard will be alerted to the fact that the good government of Australia is not the aim and object of this Government; it is merely to stay in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget has fallen apart already and Supply Bill (No. 3) 1992-93 and cognate Bills are simply the latest manifestation of it. Enormous changes have taken place since the Budget was brought down only two months ago. At that time the Budget looked pretty phoney anyway. Now it is looking even worse—and that is against the background of two consecutive years of hopeless Budget forecasting where the Government made the record level of mistakes that have ever been known in Budget forecasting. In the last two years the Government has been a total of $10 1/2 billion wrong in its estimates of its Budget or deficit—and, of course, in this case deficit.

PARA.TAB: Since the handing down of the Budget, events unfolding around the world have brought a dramatic change in the situation in which this Government is now budgeting and, of course, in the situation in which it is introducing these particular Bills to cope with some additional pump priming expenditure. I will go into the merit of that in a minute.

Let us consider the factors that are helping to destroy an already wobbly Budget. There has been a collapse of the European exchange rate mechanism and significant downgrading of European economic growth forecasts, which will clearly affect Australia's trading opportunities in the world; a further substantial reduction in Japanese economic growth forecasts for the forthcoming year, which clearly will have a direct impact on Australia; and signs that the United States economy has virtually stopped its already weak growth altogether and may yet again slip into recession. Obviously this worldwide unravelling of economic prospects will have implications on the Australian economy and, of course, this already demonstrated-to-be incompetent Budget.

One wonders what the Government is actually doing to shore up its budgetary position and the Australian economic position. We can see that these Bills—these politically motivated unprecedented Bills—are aimed at priming the pump, at doing the old and proven wrong thing at the wrong time in terms of what is right for the economy.

Things in fact are worse than these three external changes that I have pointed out. As evidence of that, one has only to look at Max Walsh's column in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. In that column he reminds Australia of something that a lot of the commentators appear to have forgotten—and certainly the Government appears never to have recognised or understood—and that is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Australian dollar has depreciated against the mark by 21 per cent in the past six months. In terms of the trade-weighted index we have depreciated by 11 per cent in the last six months.
And as for those falling stockmarkets!
That is those stock markets overseas which have been attracting headlines in Australia. The article continues:
Well, our market is 13.8 per cent off its year's high compared with a fall of 10.6 per cent in the UK and 6.8 per cent on Wall Street.
We are far worse. The article continues:
One other market indicator is long-term bond rates adjusted for inflation. Again we lead the pack, with the highest real long-term interest rates in the top dozen or so capital markets.

As the ANZ Bank has advised the Labor Caucus committee, interest rates under this Government clearly look as if they could go higher. We have a situation where the scribes report that the UK economy is in a financial and political crisis, yet here in Australia the foreign exchange, equity and bond markets are all performing decidedly worse than in the United Kingdom and nobody seems to be mentioning the word `crisis'. In fact, Mr Keating says, `The recession is over, everything is wonderful'. As someone pointed out in Question Time today, maybe for him it is, because he has managed to turn his $430,000 investment in a piggery into an investment worth $4.3m within only six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has done the same thing to our foreign debt, though.

—Of course, as Senator O'Chee interjects, he has also ballooned our foreign debt at the same time. Maybe for Mr Keating the recession is over when he looks at the increase in his own personal fortune. But clearly, here in Australia, as Max Walsh says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are having a crisis by stealth.

PARA.TAB: International investors have taken the collective view that this is now a hazardous economy. Surprisingly, our global unpopularity goes largely unnoticed and unremarked. Much more media attention has been focused on the pound than on the rapid decline of our currency in the past six months.

In fact, Prime Minister Keating's proud, but dubious boast at the time of his One Nation statement that Australia would be leading the way out of recession retains a quite surprising street credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have to wonder is: in these circumstances, having now as Prime Minister the world's greatest Treasurer, why are the markets giving us such a poor rating, and does it matter anyway? Max Walsh says:

PARA.TAB: It certainly matters, as demonstrated by the sorry state of the equity markets, the failure of the Westpac rights issue and the aborting of the Woolworths float. We need foreign investors in our equity market and they are simply not there in anywhere near the representation of the past. Weak equity markets mean the required process of de-leveraging corporate balance sheets is going to take longer than anybody expected.

Recent instability in global exchange markets and the failure of the US economy to recover as expected and the implications of this for commodity prices have no doubt brought an element of additional caution into global capital markets. However, the disenchantment with Australia pre-dated these developments. It began after the One Nation statement that relaunched the Labor Government under Paul Keating.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on:

PARA.TAB: In a departure from the deliberately prudent approach of his predecessor, Mr Keating indicated that he wanted to use the fiscal accelerator to get the economy moving. While pump-priming plays well at the local level it is anathema to the international investment community when an economy has excessive foreign debt and a chronic current account deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, what Mr Keating is doing is aimed directly and solely at an election. These are part of a political stunt that are doing major long term damage to Australia's status, standing and capacity to have long term and real economic recovery. As Max Walsh says:
. . . the Government is in election mode. And what is more, it believes it has half a chance.
That is, of course, if it keeps throwing money at the problem. He goes on:

PARA.TAB: Consequently the shift in political rhetoric already evident in Mr Keating's tariff policies is not an encouraging sign. . .

SPEECH.PARA: He described it as—and I quote:
. . . an increasingly populist approach by the Government. If this risk is validated then the deterioration in our exchange, equity and bond markets will inevitably continue.

PARA.TAB: Such a crisis of confidence in the markets, and that is what would be involved if foreign investors continue to walk away from the Australian market, would pull the floor from under the existing wheat recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: He concludes:
This could be a very expensive election for Australia.
That is not a problem that would worry Mr Keating; it never has in the past. He has been prepared to say anything at any time, do anything at any time, to grab hold of and maintain power.

PARA.TAB: That is what is happening to the Australian economy now. Certainly, he has been prepared to say anything. We all remember the expression which has every day usage, `This is the recession we had to have', but a lot of people have forgotten some of his other more appealing remarks. On 4 December 1990, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It—
that is, the recession—
is not a condition beyond control, it is a condition in fact engineered by the Government.

If it is not out of control, do we say to Mr Keating, `Well, what you have engineered certainly looks like being out of control'? I think one could say that if it walks like a pig, smells like a pig and oinks like a pig, presumably it is a pig. Mr Keating certainly has intimate financial relationships, at least, with pigs. Here is the recession that Mr Keating has engineered. Yet he is now apparently engineering a phoney recovery which will damage Australia's long term prospects.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't care.

—Senator Knowles is quite right—as long as he can win the next election, and that is what this legislation is all about and that is what economic mismanagement by this Government is going to be all about in the next six months or so. It is going to be aimed at short term appeal to the voters, and I am certain that the Australian public will be sensible enough to see through it. Let us look at this question of why we had this recession, anyway—the recession that Mr Keating happily says he engineered. Some people are saying, `It came from foreign parts'. Let us look at that because Dr David Morgan was one of the top people in the Australian Treasury until he moved across to Westpac. In an article in Westpac's Issues magazine—and I take the point that maybe Westpac is an appropriate place for someone from the Australian Treasury to go, in view of the size of the deficits and the miscalculations in both cases—Dr Morgan compares the 1982-83 Fraser recession with the 1990-91-92 Keating recession which, of course, is the worst since the Depression. Dr Morgan, who, by the way, is the husband of Mrs Kelly, the `Minister for having a good time', said:

PARA.TAB: The 1982-83 recession was caused by a combination of external and domestic factors, the 1990-91 recession by purely domestic factors.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a former top Government adviser in the Treasury, saying that this recession is due to purely domestic factors. He puts the blame for the old Fraser recession, the 1982-83 one which we are still hearing about in this chamber, on oil price rises that hit the world's major economies, coinciding with a severe Australian drought which halved the value of rural production while a wages explosion squeezed profits and caused job losses. However, this is what he says about the 1990-91 recession, the present recession:

PARA.TAB: The main catalyst for the 1990-91 recession in Australia was the Government's—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the Keating Government; he was the Treasurer then—
imposition of high interest rates aimed at curbing rapid growth in domestic spending (primarily business investment).

But the seeds had been sown, he says, by the Hawke Government's mishandling of the recovery from the 1982-83 recession. Remember, of course, who the Treasurer was—it was the world's greatest Treasurer, Mr Keating. The seeds had been sown by the Hawke Government's mishandling of the recovery from the 1982-83 recession as—and I quote:
. . . most of the gains in reducing inflation during the recession were lost in an over-rapid recovery.

By the way, the Reserve Bank's annual report for 1990-91 takes the same view. This incompetence, this mishandling by Mr Keating as Treasurer, laid the groundwork for the spending boom, high inflation and large balance of payments problem of the late 1980s so that—and I quote Dr Morgan again:
. . . another recession, this time due only to national problems, became inevitable.

That is exactly the sort of situation that Mr Keating is repeating right now and that this legislation is part of. It is part of an inevitable economic disaster as Mr Keating tries to buy his way back into power, just as in the past he has misled the Australian people with absolute nonsense to try to win, and succeed in winning, elections in the past.

PARA.TAB: Mr Argus, the Chief Executive of the National Australia Bank, said yesterday that Australia could not afford the Government's unfunded tax cuts because they would over-stimulate the economy leading to a blow-out in Australia's foreign debt—a debt, by the way, which now stands at $150 billion or almost $9,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia.

So here we have the same sorts of warnings, this time from the National Australia Bank, that Dr Morgan had given—as I said, an ex-senior economic adviser, a top economic adviser, of this Government, who is now with Westpac. Here we have these warnings against what this Government is doing now. Already in the Budget it was government spending that was pushing the economy along. As the Budget Papers say:
Public sector final demand will continue to support activity in 1992-93, with a pick-up in spending through the year.
Strong growth in both Commonwealth and State/local sector investment is expected in 1992-93.
Both Commonwealth and State/local sector consumption is forecast to grow moderately.

SPEECH.PARA: But there we have it: that is where all the growth is, that is where all the activity is—government spending, in other words, the spending of taxpayers' money or the spending of borrowed money, putting Australia's economic recovery at real risk. Because of this spending, imports in the Budget are projected to rise more quickly than demand as domestic expenditure recovers. Of course, that is mainly government spending. Even at that point, the Budget was recognising—and I quote:
Subdued growth in the world economy, particularly the slowdown in Japan, and smaller increments to capacity in the non-rural sector are expected to constrain export growth.

So here we have a major economic problem being worsened by this Budget and worsened even more by the sort of pump-priming spending involved in these latest supply Bills. And there was to be a worsening of the current account deficit even before these latest bits of evidence of the disastrous economic problems we face had become available.

PARA.TAB: All this sounds bad enough for the economy, but what does it mean for the ordinary Australians who are out of work—the one million people who are officially unemployed, the 800,000 who, according to the Bureau of Statistics, are the hidden unemployed, and the 600,000 who are underemployed and can get only part time work? What do all these figures and this sort of disaster mean for them? The essential answer is: nothing.

What this Government has been doing in this Budget and these Bills is throwing money at a problem without solving it. In fact, it is making it worse in the long run by trying to get some temporary help or doing some temporary papering over of the cracks in the run-up to the next election. It is being helped, I might say, by some extraordinary statements from the Governor of Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, who, as the Senate remembers, has been the subject of considerable criticism in the past by the coalition.

I will quote Max Walsh again, this time from Tuesday's paper where he totally rejects Mr Fraser's claim that Australia does not have a long term employment problem but only a short term one. It is incredible the way the Governor of the Reserve Bank always seems to be able to put a gloss on things that happen to suit to Government's line. Max Walsh states:

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that the Governor, and by extension the Reserve Bank and the Government, has got it wrong—horribly wrong. We do have a long-term employment problem. . . and a serious one at that.

Of course, the simple fact is that this Government managed to fund its expansion of the labour market by borrowing from abroad at levels that were far above those of the past and far above what we will be able to borrow in the future. Max Walsh says:
Nobody for one moment—including Governor Fraser—imagines the rest of the world will continue to underwrite Australia's employment growth in the future in the fashion in which it did through the 80s.
A very much higher level of domestic savings is required to finance investment and produce remotely comparable employment outcomes to the 80s.

He gives other reasons why we do have a long term problem—one which this Budget and these Bills before us will simply worsen. As Max Walsh says, if policy is being formulated on the basis of that proposition—that is, that we are having only a short term employment problem as the Governor of the Reserve Bank says—we are digging Australia into a deep hole. He goes on to say:
If Mr Fraser is engaged in a political exercise to give credibility to the Keating Government then he is destroying the integrity of the Reserve Bank.
Either way we are all losers.

I hope that the only loser to emerge from this will be this Government. I hope that this Government will be replaced in time to bring to an end these disastrous policies that are putting so many people out of work, putting so many Australians in situations where they are underemployed, putting so many Australians in the position where they do not even bother being on the unemployed list—they are the hidden unemployed—and putting so many Australians in a position where their economic future and the future of their children when they leave school will be massively diminished to suit the short term political objectives of a power hungry Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: These Bills are part of his short term policy of self-aggrandisement and holding desperately on to power. I hope the Australian people recognise that and I commend Senator Short's amendment to the second reading motion for these appalling Supply Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a time in the history of this country when hard work, honesty and thrift were considered qualities to be admired, yet we now find ourselves governed by a group of people who sit opposite us in this chamber for whom sloth, dishonesty and conspicuous consumption are the characteristics of office.

PARA.TAB: It is highly disturbing that we should be governed by such people as these, because they exemplify the worst excesses of the 1980s. Is it not ironic that we have as the leader of that Government a man who, when he was Treasurer and when he was plotting to become Prime Minister, railed constantly against the corporate sector of this nation for what he considered excessive consumption, for what he considered excessive spending and for what he considered financial irresponsibility? Yet tonight we have before us Supply Bills Nos. 3 and 4 which are an indictment of this Government's own excesses, this Government's own financial irresponsibility and this Government's own inability to balance the books.

Lest anyone be misled, these Bills are designed to achieve one purpose and one purpose only. What is that purpose? It is to give the Government instant money, not for the benefit of the economy, not for the good maintenance of office, but rather, as Senator Baume, Senator Bishop and Senator Short before me have said, to put money in the Government's war chest for an impending election. And at what price an election?

Here we have a government that came before the Senate in August this year and said quite brazenly that it intended to run a deficit of $13.4 billion. That is $13,400m of deficit. Here we have a government that came before the Senate and said in the Budget that it had a financing requirement and needed to borrow $18 1/2 billion. Here we have a government that has come before this country in the greatest recession since the 1930s and said, `Instead of having good financial management, we are going to spend and spend wantonly'. Where has it sourced the money? It has sourced the money from overseas, by pillaging the finances and the savings base of this nation and by making poorer the corporate sector and this nation's long term finances, which are what we really need to depend upon in order to generate a real recovery. I am not talking about the sort of recovery that the Prime Minister dreams of—one gets the impression that perhaps he is dreaming on his feet during Question Time at the other end of this building—but the sort of recovery that this nation needs.

I see the discomfort of Senator Collins on the other side of the chamber, because what this Government does not like is the truth—the truth that this recession is still here and has not ended and the truth that thousands and thousands of Australians are living with the long term consequences of this Government's mismanagement.

Yet, in spite of all these things, we hear in this chamber and at the other end of this building day after day Government Ministers fulminating against the Opposition as though it was the Opposition that generated this recession, that was responsible for Australia's foreign debt being $150 billion and that was responsible for introducing a Budget which had a deficit, on the Government's own figures, of $13.4 billion.

How much is a $13.4 billion deficit? Honourable senators might be interested to know that if one paid for this Government's deficit in $1 coins and laid them end to end, they would stretch around the world 8 1/2 times—further even than the dishonesty that the side facing us propagates every single day in Question Time. Imagine our deficit for one year paid for in $1 coins going around the world 8 1/2 times.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to make some points on behalf of my colleague Senator Walters, who is not here. Yesterday in the Senate, Senator Cook attempted to extricate himself from a very deep hole which he had managed to dig for himself in relation to a number of answers he had previously given my colleague Senator Walters regarding the loss of a very important joint venture with the Russians from the Hobart waterfront. As Senator Walters is not here and I am the only other southern-based Tasmanian Liberal senator, I believe I should take a few moments to briefly comment on Senator Cook's additional response to Senator Walters that I missed yesterday.

PARA.TAB: I noted with irony when I perused the Hansard that Senator Cook concluded his answer on 9 September by claiming in respect of Senator Walters:

SPEECH.PARA: I think she ends up with egg all over her face.

That was the initial answer he gave to the first question Senator Walters asked on 9 September. I think it is quite clear to anyone who had a chance to look at Senator Cook's rather pathetic attempts at backtracking yesterday that it was not Senator Walters who ended up with egg on her face but the Minister himself. There is no doubt, if there was any doubt before, that in providing his answer to Senator Walters on 9 September the Minister made a number of comments which were completely and utterly untrue.

PARA.TAB: It is up to us in the Senate to judge for ourselves the motivation for the Minister's action, but surely any Minister of this Government has an obligation to come into this chamber and give answers that can be substantiated. This was not so in Senator Cook's case. Just as importantly, by coming into this chamber and making a number of incorrect and totally unsubstantiated allegations regarding Trident Seafoods, the Minister has damaged the standing in the community of that company. With that in mind, what Senator Walters and Trident Seafoods received from the Minister yesterday was nothing more than very shallow justice indeed. They both deserve—and I believe the Senate deserves—a total and unequivocal apology from the Minister, Senator Cook, for the answer he gave in the Senate on 9 September.
I will quickly illustrate how that comes about and how Senator Cook not only got egg on his face but also was caught with his pants down. On 9 September, Senator Cook said:

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say about that allegation is that I understand there are other reasons as to why this company is facing financial difficulties.
Yesterday in his answer that had become, with great licence and a fair amount of imagination:

I should have referred to the possibility of the joint venture facing difficulties having regard to problems encountered by similar joint venture proposals in other States when apparently the Russian partners had difficulty in meeting their contribution to the venture.
I am sure honourable senators would agree that the Minister's explanation bears no relation to his initial comments. If anyone has any doubts I will read it again. Initially, he said:
All I can say about that allegation is that I understand there are other reasons as to why this company is facing financial difficulties.
Then yesterday he comes out and blames the Russians for it. Further, on 9 September the Minister stated:

The advice I have before me is advice that the company had decided to abandon this enterprise before it had even started to negotiate what the terms and conditions would be for the handling of this fish on the waterfront in Hobart.
Yesterday, Senator Cook said:
I should have said that the negotiations were not concluded before the announced withdrawal of the project, which I indicated in a subsequent answer on 14 September.

The Minister was right about one thing: he should have said a lot of things which he did not say and not said a lot of things which he did say. I believe that the Minister has been guilty of either misleading the Senate or at least of not doing his homework before attempting to answer Senator Walters's question. There is a lesson for the Minister in this: if you do not know the full facts you are better off not saying anything. Under the circumstances, I therefore call upon the Minister to provide a full and unreserved apology to both Senator Walters and Trident Seafoods for the answer he gave on 9 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a number of occasions in adjournment debates I have brought to the Senate cases of Australian citizens being concerned about the use of chemicals in an inappropriate manner in the places in which they live. Tonight I bring yet another example of the concern of Australian citizens about the way chemicals are used.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the widespread use of various chemicals in our society has manifested itself in residues in our soil, air, water, food and animals, residues have now been found in our children. I am referring to a group of seven children from the Coffs Harbour region. Residues in the children affected range from organochlorins and solvents to heavy metals, et cetera. The common link in these children is that they have unexplained health problems as our medical and health authorities have concluded. This is part of a theme I have presented on the several occasions I have raised these sorts of matters in the adjournment debate; that is, our health and medical authorities are unable to deal with the problems that have become associated with the mysteries of how misused chemicals affect our population.

Many of the children I refer to, if not all of them, have been and are being treated by our medical system with no success. Currently, there is little or no research into the health effects of low level residues in children. There is negligible interest being shown, no records being kept and no active research programs established by our health authorities on these children's cases. Indeed, our health authorities ostracised many medical practitioners or specialists who studied these cases and who put forward links between toxic chemical residues and effects on health. I wonder whether that could be described in any way as a scientific approach.

Blood samples from these seven children, from four to eight years of age, were tested in the United States nationally recognised laboratory, ACCU CHEM. The ACCU CHEM laboratories are located at 990 Bowser Street 800, Richardson, Texas. This laboratory is the same one used by the American military for tests on the effects of chemical warfare. This is a credible organisation with a reputation for accurate results. Comparisons were then

SPEECH.PARA: made between the residue levels of the Coffs Harbour children and an American testing laboratory population average, predominantly made up of adults. It should be noted that these American adults had chemical residues higher than normal for them to be tested in the first place, which makes the residue levels in Coffs Harbour children all the more alarming. I seek leave to incorporate a brief table of comparisons.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The table read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [TABLE OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1341]

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of my colleagues in the chamber at the moment, I would like to give just a few examples of the residue levels of 17 toxic chemicals found in the children's blood. Hexachlorobenzene was found to be present at the rate of up to 22 times higher in Coffs Harbour children than in the American testing population average.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, Beta-BHC was up to 22 times higher; Dieldrin up to seven times higher; DDE up to 3.5 times higher; Toluene up to seven times higher; Trichloroethane up to 16.5 times higher; and Benzene up to five times higher. I am sure that you would agree, Mr Acting Deputy President, that these are all formidable sounding residues.

All of these seven children live in the Coffs Harbour residential areas. One of the children is named Andrew Want and I will outline his case history in summary. After a normal birth, young Andrew, at six days, developed rapid breathing at approximately twice the normal rate. At six weeks he was diagnosed with gastric reflux. Not until six months was he breathing at a normal rate. At 18 months he was coughing persistently, and at two years Andrew was diagnosed as asthmatic and put on medication via a nebuliser three times a day.

At three years of age Andrew ceased medication six weeks after the parents bought a water purifier. At four years he experienced periodic headaches and stomach aches. His learning ability regressed, his social development regressed and emotionally he became very delicate. At 4 1/2 years he had intermittent rectal bleeding. After two hospitalisations in a well respected children's hospital in Sydney, no explanation was given other than that Andrew's condition was described as psychological.

His parents then lost faith in the medical system and took the only measures that were left open to them. They modified the total chemical load in the house and school environment. They established a diet of organic food while eliminating all dairy products. As a result of these measures, Andrew's health improved substantially.

At five to six years of age Andrew gradually improved to progress through school at an average to above average ability. Nevertheless, he remains sensitised to many common chemicals, especially solvents in white board markers, textas, car fumes, aerial spray drift, and herbicides applied by local councils to roadsides. When exposed to these toxic substances he suffers the physical and neurological effects all over again.

The plight of Andrew and these other children is frightful. What is also frightening is that they are not isolated cases, as I have demonstrated before when speaking during amendment debates. Many other children from other Australian towns and cities have accumulated heavy metals such as lead well above overseas levels. I have to say `many other' because unfortunately this reflects the lack of attention, research and baseline data that our health authorities should have.

That immediately raises the questions: why are not our scientists in various research units of government departments and universities studying these cases? Why are not our authorities tracking down how, where, when and why these children are accumulating such levels, and why are they not doing something about it? I am afraid that this question remains rhetorical. The answer can be given only when sufficient recognition is given to these problems and they are not considered as problems to be wiped away and beyond understanding. We need to address ourselves to how we can understand these problems.

It would be interesting to see how balanced the National Health and Medical Research Council is in assessing safety and health effects when approving the large number of chemicals for use throughout our community. I will expand on that at another time. But for the moment, I want to state again in this place that we are able to see that chemical residues are accumulating in our children. Clearly, there is a huge gap in a registration system for chemical use where the health of our community is not given sufficient consideration, let alone our top priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to provide some short response to the speech made by Senator Kemp yesterday in the adjournment debate in which he trotted out some figures which sought to juxtapose the number of times the Democrats voted with the Government as against the number of times they voted with the Opposition. Today Senator Kemp took some exception to the name that was given to him by Senator Coulter—namely, the Shadow Minister for Democrat bashing. While I think that was amply justified, I will use his proper title tonight, which is Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I am quite happy to give Senator Kemp that formal and correct title because I want to refer the Senate to an article in the Bulletin dated 13 October that deals with Mr Hewson's master plan. No doubt, as Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader, Senator Kemp thoroughly agrees, actively supports and promotes to the best of his ability Dr Hewson's objective. As this article says, that objective is to obtain control of both Houses. If he does not do so at the 1993 election, then certainly at a subsequent election, which Dr Hewson would no doubt call on the basis of a double dissolution. It is quite clear that Senator Kemp is doing his level best to achieve that objective—namely, to decimate the Democrats to a point where Dr Hewson would be able to control both Houses.

However, I have news for Dr Hewson and Senator Kemp. I am sorry that Senator Kemp is not able to be in the chamber tonight; I advised his office that I would be providing him with a response. No doubt this debate will be continued at another time.

I thought it would be useful and instructive if the Senate were informed briefly of a number of instances where Senator Kemp and his colleagues voted with the Government against initiatives, amendments and other parliamentary actions of the Democrats. This is much more instructive than simply trotting out figures, because figures by themselves do not mean anything. We really need to look at the substance of the motion that is before the Senate and the action that has been taken by Senator Kemp and his colleagues. In view of the advancing hour, I will use only a few examples; I could use many more than I will tonight.

On 14 February 1991, Senator Kemp and his colleagues voted against a Democrat urgency motion calling on the Government to establish a royal commission into bank practices in Australia. We all know that this would have been fully justified. The history of bank practice in Australia is now well and truly on the table. The fact that many people have lost their savings, that the banks have lost a lot of money, that the share price has gone down and that the banks have not fulfilled their duties under the financial system that is operating is clear. I welcome Senator Kemp, who has just walked into the chamber. He will be very pleased to hear once again that he voted on 14 February 1991 against the Democrats' efforts to establish a royal commission into bank practices in Australia.

On 10 April 1991, I moved an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill to close a loophole and to ensure that when bad debts are incurred by foreign operations of Australian money lenders and they are written off, they are not being used for tax avoidance purposes. Senator Kemp did not seem to worry much about the tax avoidance possibilities of that legislation because he voted against that amendment, as did his colleagues.

On the same day, a Democrat amendment was moved to remove tax deductibility for advertising expenditure for alcohol and tobacco. Clearly, Senator Kemp had never read nor heard that the annual expenditure dealing with the consequences of the use of tobacco and alcohol is reaching something like $12 billion. Once again, he did not think that that was a worthwhile amendment to support.

On 15 April, the Democrats opposed the second reading of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) as the Bill reduced sales tax on luxury cars, no doubt Ferraris. We called it an extraordinary decision in a recession. But, once again, Senator Kemp thought that our stance did not merit the support of either him or his colleagues. The list goes on.

On 13 May 1991, a disallowance motion moved by the Democrats to the Austudy scheme which rejected regulations concerning the assets test to the family farm and small business assets, suggesting that they should not be included, was again not supported. Obviously, Senator Kemp and his colleagues are not concerned about the plight of farmers and small business people when they are trying to give their children an education.

On 17 June, the Democrats moved amendments to the Telecommunications Bill to allow individuals or organisations to take direct legal action in the public interest in the event of any breaches in the legal code. It would seem that Senator Kemp and his colleagues did not think it worthy of support that individuals should be able to take legal action in the public interest. I wonder why.

There is more. An amendment was moved on 18 June 1991 to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) to increase the rate of withholding tax on interest earned by non-residents when the arrangement is believed to be for tax avoidance purposes. The losses to public revenue that these arrangements are being put to have been well and truly documented by taxation academic Barbara Smith. A parliamentary committee, which published a report very colourfully named Follow the Yellow Brick Road recommended that this was worthy of further investigation because clearly there were substantial revenue losses. However, once again, Senator Kemp and his colleagues did not seem to worry much about tax avoidance or the losses to public revenue because they chose to vote with the Government against the Democrat amendment.

In deference to the advancing hour, I shall stop at this point. I advise Senator Kemp and his colleagues that I have many more such examples where the evidence of the Opposition voting with the Government against the interests of ordinary Australians, against the public interest and against the Democrats is well and truly on the record. He might like to look at the substance of his voting record rather than at pure numbers, which no doubt take a lot of fine study to accumulate but which mean very little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few remarks in the adjournment debate; they will be fairly brief in view of what Senator Sid Spindler has pointed to as the somewhat late hour. Firstly, I thank Senator Spindler for the courtesy of informing me that he was about to attack me in the Parliament. I appreciate the courtesy, but I am not sure whether I was attacked. Senator Spindler has demonstrated once again that it is always very dangerous in this Parliament to read out a speech which has been prepared by one's research staff without looking closely at it. It is a very dangerous practice and Senator Spindler should have been more careful this evening.

PARA.TAB: I can understand that Senator Spindler is sensitive about this issue. He is sensitive because he has been one of the driving forces in the Democrat party room which has led the Democrats down this dead end. Compared with virtually all his colleagues, it is Senator Spindler who has encouraged the Australian Democrats to adopt consistently these astonishingly Left wing positions.

I have referred to Senator Spindler before. I said that he should be classified by the National Trust as the sole surviving Marxist in any parliament in any country on any continent in this world. I always like to hear Senator Spindler speaking because he is one of the sole survivors of the 1950s and 1960s.

Senator Spindler must bear a very heavy responsibility for the quite dramatic figures which I tabled in the Senate last night. It is not surprising that Senator Spindler came into the chamber this evening to make some comments. I was surprised that Senator Coulter, whom I advised last night that I was about to make some statements on the voting record of the Australian Democrats, did not come in here to defend himself. I do not know why he sent in Senator Spindler but when Senator Coulter reads the Hansard he will undoubtedly feel that he was comparatively ill-served.

Why has this whole thing emerged this evening—on Wednesday night when all of us feel it is appropriate that we leave comparatively early? Last night I tabled some pretty dramatic figures in this chamber. I repeat that in 216 divisions of the thirty-sixth Parliament which have occurred since March 1990 the Australian Democrats have supported the Government. By contrast, on 34 occasions they have supported the coalition. That is a pretty fine record for a Party that wants to portray itself to the community as some sort of centrist party and some sort of honest broker between the major parties. Senator Spindler is acutely sensitive about this. That is why he has come into the Senate this evening and decided to make a bit of a fuss about it. He has made only a bit of a fuss; I do not think he scored too many points.

Another point I wish to make—having pointed to the Australian Democrats' dreadful voting record in divisions—relates to the number of Bills in the last two years that the Australian Democrats have enabled to be forced through this Parliament without any significant debate. Some 111 Bills in all—roughly one-quarter of the legislation which has gone through this Senate—have been forced through with the cooperation of the Australian Democrats. And this is the party that holds itself out as wanting to make governments more accountable to the Parliament! It is a dreadful record and Senator Spindler has cooperated in that rather appalling record.

The final point I wish to make is this: I would have thought that any party that wanted to improve standards in the Parliament and encourage more effective Government accountability to the Parliament would have been one of the strongest supporters of the reforms to Question Time that we proposed as little as three weeks ago—and also of the procedure of moving to take note of Ministers' answers after Question Time to force them to be more accountable. But because Senator Spindler is the sole surviving Marxist in any parliament in any country on any continent in this world, he has convinced his colleagues that somehow because we on the Opposition benches want this accountability, because we want Question Time to function in a more traditional manner, as all other governments have decided, and because we wanted to ensure that Ministers were accountable for their answers through the

SPEECH.PARA: procedure of taking note of the answer, they should block those major reforms.

PARA.TAB: In deference to my colleagues who undoubtedly wish to go home, I will conclude on this point: Senator Spindler will now pay a very heavy price for forsaking his heritage and adopting procedures which do not increase the authority of the Parliament but diminish it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 16 July 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why have definitions of low level and intermediate waste not been included in the 1992 Code and Guidelines on Radioactive Waste Disposal by Shallow Land Burial as was done in the 1990 Code.
(2) Is the method of shallow land burial used to dispose of waste from the processing of monazite sands and ores.
(3) Is this method of waste disposal considered suitable by international standards.
(4) What measures are taken to ensure safety standards during the transportation of this form of waste.
(5) Has consideration been given to the disposal of this type of waste as tailings as described under the Code of Practice for the Disposal of Waste from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive ores.
(6) Why is this form of waste included as a separate category C in the Code and Guidelines.
(7) What proportion of radioactive waste in Australia is currently generated as a result of Commonwealth Government activities.
(8) Do the 1992 Code and Guidelines include the radioactive substance radium brachytherapy needles.
(9) Are radium brachytherapy needles considered safe for disposal under the Code and Guidelines for Shallow Land Burial.
(10) Has consideration been given to their inclusion as Category S waste.
(11) Has consideration been given to the disposal of obsolete reactor components as either low level or intermediate—high level waste.
(12) Are there currently any obsolete reactor components awaiting disposal as a result of activities at the Nuclear Science Reactor located at Lucas Heights.

(13) Is it considered likely that additional nuclear waste will be created as a result of future replacement or refurbishment of the reactor at Lucas Heights; if so, how will such waste be disposed of.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The definitions of low level and intermediate level radioactive waste have not been included in the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) 1992 draft Code of Practice for the Near-Surface Disposal of Radioactive Waste in Australia because the terms are not used in the document. The NHMRC considers that these terms are insufficiently precise to be used in the Code of Practice.

(2) and (3) Yes, this method has been used overseas. The Code could be applied by regulatory bodies to disposal of wastes arising from processing radioactive ores at sites remote from the mine site. The Code could also apply to wastes removed from sites such as Hunter's Hill in NSW and Fisherman's Bend in Victoria which were contaminated by past processing of radioactive materials.

(4) Transport of prescribed radioactive materials in Australia is undertaken in accordance with internationally agreed standards set out in the Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances (1990).
(5) Yes. This is generally appropriate where the wastes are produced close to the mine site.

(6) Category C waste has been included in the Code to allow for the disposal of waste resulting from downstream processing of radioactive materials remote from a mine site and any other bulk waste for which the conditioning criteria of Category B would not be appropriate.
(7) Approximately 90%.

(8) Yes. Radioactive waste arising from the medical use of isotopes such as radium is covered by the Code of Practice. Such waste must meet the quantitative criteria for Category B or else they would be regarded as Category S.

(9) and (10) Yes, providing that they are appropriately conditioned and meet the quantitative criteria for Category B wastes. In practice, it is expected that the majority of waste radium from brachytherapy use will be treated as Category S waste.
(11) Where such components satisfy the radioactivity concentration limits set out in the draft Code they could be disposed of as Category B or C wastes depending on their physical characteristics.

(13) Yes. This waste will be managed and disposed of in accordance with the nature of its radioactivity. Some radioactive components will be suitable for near-surface disposal. Radioactive materials exceeding the concentration limits specified for near-surface disposal will be stored pending deep disposal at a future underground repository.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 19 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What progress is being made by Federal Government departments in the provision of work-based child-care.
(2) How many places have been allocated to be operational by 1995.
(3) How does this compare with the number of work-based child-care places in the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions are:

PARA.TAB: (1) Following the Government's ratification of ILO Convention No. 156 on Workers with Family Responsibilities, policy guidelines for the provision of child-care in the Australian Public Service (APS) were agreed and issued by the Government.
The guidelines enable APS agencies to consider subsidised child-care for their employees, but without budget supplementation.
Provision of work-based child-care in the APS is the responsibility of individual agencies. However, some examples of progress to date are:
the Australian Taxation Officer has priority of access to 20 places in an off-site long day centre near their office at Moonee Ponds;
the Department of Social Security has priority of access to 56 long day care places in the vicinity of their Tuggeranong Offices;
the Department of Veterans' Affairs has a 55 place on-site centre at Repatriation General Hospital, Concord; and
the Department of Defence has established 120 places in 5 on-site child-care centres.

(2) It is not possible to predict with any accuracy the number of employer sponsored places likely to be available in 1995, as APS agencies will continue to make their own arrangements based upon a range of factors. These include needs/demand, benefits likely to accrue to the agency and its employees, availability of suitable premises and the extent of any cost to the agency.

(3) Many employers in Australia are investing in or investigating child-care, however, comprehensive figures on the number of employer sponsored child-care places in Australia, whether in the private or public sector, are not available.

A study completed in June 1990 (Department of Industrial Relations (1991), The Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey, AGPS), at Table A74, page 302 provides some information on facilities employers provided for employees including child-care. Of the employers surveyed (with 20 or more employees) 1% of private sector employers reported that they provided child-care facilities compared with 3% of public sector employers surveyed. The study did not distinguish between federal, state or local government employers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Tribunal: Television Program Standards

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 24 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given that program standards TPS10 of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal state that `explicit depiction of sexual acts' are not suitable for television, why did the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal rule that the program `Sex' hosted by Sophie Lee on Channel 9 on Thursdays at 8.30 p.m., which contains excerpts from `R' or `X'-rated films, naked couples, groups and animals involved in explicit intercourse and a close-up of an erect penis, should be allowed to be shown on television with an `AO' rating.

(2) Given that research commissioned by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in 1988 found that half of all nine-year-old children are still watching television at 8.30 p.m. and that nearly a third of all 11-year-olds are still viewing at 9.30 p.m., why are `AO' programs featuring scenes of violence, sex and foul language, allowed to be screened at these times.

(3) Given that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal reports that it has received a record number of complaints about the `Sex' program on Channel 9 hosted by Sophie Lee, and TV Week (20 June 1992, page 4) reports that Sophie Lee herself is unhappy with the way the program has developed, why has the Tribunal ignored these complaints and does this mean that its complaint monitoring service a mere pretence.

(4) Why has the Tribunal allowed former children's presenter Sophie Lee to be promoted as the presenter for an adult program, thus attracting many children who were `Bugs Bunny' viewers to the 8.30 p.m. time slot for the sexually explicit `Sex' program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The answer to this question requires an understanding of the limits upon the ABT's power to approve individual programs.

The Broadcasting Act, 1942 gives the ABT the power to determine program standards for commercial television. The Act also requires that licensees comply with these standards as a condition of their licence.

The ABT has determined program standards, which require licensees to classify all programs according to the times of the day they may be shown and the audience for which they are suitable. Television Program Standard 10 (TPS 10) sets out the criteria which licensees are to use in classifying programs. The criteria relate to the depictions in programs of violence, sexual activity, drugs and the use of offensive language.

The criteria provide licensees with general guidelines as to the type of content which is acceptable in the classifications—`G', `PGR', `AO' and `Not Suitable For Television'. The criteria are not designed to be an objective list of unacceptable content, but recognise the assessment of content and context involved in classification.

The ABT does not classify or approve programs for broadcast. It is specifically prevented by the Act from requiring licensees to submit programs to it for approval, except in the area of children's television standards. The ABT can, however, investigate compliance with standards once a program has been broadcast.

The ABT has the power to investigate a broadcast and to decide, after holding a comprehensive public inquiry, that the broadcast did not comply with a standard. However, while there are penalties the ABT can impose for non-compliance with a program standard, these penalties do not include the power to require programs not to be broadcast.

In the case of the series `SEX', the ABT reacted to complaints about the first episode by calling for a tape and viewing it. After doing this the ABT decided that the particular episode in question was not inconsistent with the classification standards.
This decision did not amount to an approval for the classification of all future episodes, because that is not a power the ABT possesses.
The ABT has continued to monitor complaints about the series and has viewed all episodes broadcast. It does not propose to take any further action at this stage.

More importantly, the issues surrounding the content of the series have been considered by the ABT in its inquiry into the classification standards. This inquiry commenced some time before `SEX' began to be transmitted and is the first major review of these standards for some decades.

The inquiry has provided for an extensive consideration of the standards and the classification system. It has taken note of considerable public submission on the issues, including all the complaints about the program `SEX'. It has considered whether the current system is meeting community safeguards in this area, including how the licensees have been applying the classification system. The inquiry has also undertaken research into community attitudes towards the matters dealt with by the standards and current community knowledge of the classification system.

The transition of the ABT to the ABA means that this inquiry will not result in the variation of the existing standard. However, the ABT inquiry will provide the ABA and the television industry with considerable information to assist in the development of codes of practice in this area.
(2) The research referred to appears to be a survey by Newspoll, "Study of Children's Viewing 1988", commissioned by the ABT as part of its Children's Television Standards inquiry in 1988.

The research was conducted with children aged between 6 and 13, based on a questionnaire which included the question, "When did you finish watching TV after tea last night?" The children were given 5 options to answer this question:
1. I didn't watch TV
2. Before 8.30
3. Between 8.30 and 9.30
4. Between 9.30 and 10.30
5. After 10.30

The results showed that approximately 50% of children surveyed either did not watch television or finished viewing before 8.30 p.m. Significantly, the wording of the options was such that children who finished viewing at 8.30 p.m. were forced to indicate option 3 above (Between 8.30 p.m. and 9.30 p.m.).

The research actually indicated that at some point between 8.30 p.m. and 9.30 p.m. in Melbourne and Brisbane in 1988, 32.7% and 28.6% respectively of 9 year olds finished viewing. The likelihood is that they finished viewing closer to 8.30 p.m. than 9.30 p.m.
This is supported by ratings data which shows a dramatic decline in viewing by children after 8.30 p.m. In the case of the series `SEX', children aged 5-12 comprised 2-4% of the total audience.

There is no doubt that some children continue to watch television beyond 8.30 p.m., when `AO' programs are more likely to be shown. Whether the level of child viewing at this time and the extent of community concern is sufficient to warrant a change in the `AO' time zones is something the ABT will report upon at the end of its classification inquiry.

(3) The ABT has not "ignored" the complaints it received about the program `SEX'. Each complaint has been acknowledged and the complaints themselves considered in the ABT's classification inquiry. They form part of the ABT's assessment of the effectiveness of the current system.

As indicated in the response to Question 1 there appears to be a mistaken belief amongst complainants that the ABT has wider powers to remove programs from the air. This may be the basis for the impression that the ABT has not responded to the complaints. The ABT has responded, but it has done so within the powers it has available to it under the Act.

Ms Sophie Lee has not complained to the ABT about the program `SEX', nor made a submission to the classification inquiry. Her level of satisfaction with the content of the program, in the absence of any submission or complaint, is not something the ABT needs to consider.

(4) The powers of the ABT do not extend to approving the employment of actors, or other persons, in the presentation of programs. The qualifications and experience of Ms Sophie Lee, her association with other programs and her ability to attract viewers are not matters into which the ABT can legitimately enquire.

PARA.TAB: (1) What action is the Government taking following the recommendation in the Defence Force Structure Review to base Australia's entire minesweeping force in Sydney after the force is at full strength.
