(3) What is the estimated response time in an emergency.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The honourable senator will recall that in announcing the Force Structure Review in May 1991, I noted that the Australian Defence Force would base all mine countermeasures forces in Sydney.

The minesweeping force referred to by the honourable senator is only one component of the ADF's mine countermeasures force. The minesweeping force is already based in Sydney at HMAS Waterhen and has been so based since 1990. It is also at full peacetime strength although the concept allows for additional vessels to be taken up from trade in time of conflict to augment the peacetime force.

The remainder of the mine countermeasures force consists of two Clearance Diving Teams, one based at HMAS Waterhen and the other at HMAS Stirling in Western Australia. These teams have other operational and support functions in addition to mine countermeasures and for this reason they will remain in their present locations as part of the East and West coast basing concept. The Clearance Diving Team deployed to Kuwait during the Gulf War was composed primarily of personnel from these two teams.

The two inshore minehunters currently undertaking comparative sonar trials are also based at HMAS Waterhen and are planned to enter operational service in mid 1993. The larger and more capable coastal minehunters foreshadowed in the Force Structure Review and announced in the current budget will also be based at HMAS Waterhen with the last vessel entering service before the end of the decade.
HMAS Waterhen is being modernised to support the ADF's mine countermeasures force when it reaches full strength.

(2) The minesweepers may either be deployed by sea to Australia's northern and northwestern coastline or local vessels may be taken up from trade and the minesweeping equipment deployed to the area of operations.
Other mine countermeasures units would either deploy by sea, in the case of the inshore or coastal minehunters; or by air in the case of Clearance Diving Teams.
In peacetime, the mine countermeasures force undertakes surveillance activities in these areas.

(3) Response times to the northern and northwestern coastline in an emergency would vary depending on the availability of vessels, transport aircraft and if units were already conducting surveillance in the area.

The Chief of Defence Force Preparedness Directive addresses response times for ADF units. The actual response times are classified. However, there are always some ADF units on very short notice for operations.
To illustrate, the Clearance Diving Team which deployed to the Gulf War was in a position to do so 2 days after receiving notice.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 31 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 extend to open pollinated varieties of pasture grasses, or only genetically engineered or imported varieties.
(2) Does the Act permit licensees of the owner of the rights to the plant variety requiring all seed crops to be resold to the licensee at a price determined by the licensee.
(3) Does such a provision also apply to seed produced by a grower for their own purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Varieties of all plant species are eligible for protection under the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987, including open-pollinated pasture grasses, genetically engineered and all imported varieties.
(2) Section 12 of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 describes the extent of an owner's (breeder's) rights and briefly they can be described as:

ANSWER.PARA: The exclusive right to produce and sell, including the right to license other persons to sell, plants and reproductive material (including seed), of that variety.

PARA.TAB: The granting of a right under this Act is conditional on the grantee using that right commercially. The Act requires the grantees to produce and sell reproductive material or plants, or license someone to do so on their behalf.

Conditions which the grantee imposes in a licence agreement are commercial in nature and largely outside the control of the Plant Variety Rights Act 1987 with the exception that sufficient quantities of reproductive material of the protected variety must be available to meet demand.

The Act does not restrict a grantee from imposing commercial conditions on a licensee or a contract grower. It does not prevent a breeder from negotiating a price and does not force him to set a price. Neither does it force another party to enter into such a contract or agreement.
Growers are free to choose non-protected varieties or to negotiate better contract conditions with competitive suppliers of seed of other varieties.

(3) The general public is protected by section 38(1) which states that notwithstanding that plant variety rights subsist in respect of a plant variety, any person may propagate, grow and use plants for purposes other than commercial purposes.

The commercial grower is, however, subject to section 12(1) giving the grantee (the owner) the exclusive right to sell, or license others to sell or produce propagating material of that variety. Nevertheless, it is possible for as farmer to legitimately retain seed of a protected variety from one season to the next for his own use and so avoid payment of royalties to the breeder.
Supplying seed on contract to growers as part of quality assurance strategies is a legitimate commercial practice designed to retain seed and protect quality to retain or increase market share.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What grants have been made by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) for the year 1991-92 under the Media Monitoring by Aboriginal Resource Groups Program, which is part of the Government's Community Relations Strategy.
(2) What is the amount and proposed program for each grant.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission provided two grants during the 1991-92 financial year. The grants were provided to:
(i)the Western Australian Aboriginal Media Association (WAAMA)
(ii)the Indigenous Information Service Association Inc.

(2) Each grant was for $5000. Both organisations will be required, under the terms of the grant, to monitor the media and, where appropriate, to respond to biased and factually wrong reporting on Aboriginal issues. In addition they will be required to provide details of responses to the Townsville Aboriginal and Islander Media Association (TAIMA) which is establishing a data base of media monitoring activities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Australian Government's assessment of the ongoing conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan.
(2) What is Australia's relationship with the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and its attempts to mediate a peace settlement to the dispute.
(3) Will Australia consider using its position within the United Nations to urge that the Security Council intervene in the dispute.
(4) What is the scale of the refugee problem as a result of the conflict.
(5) Has the Australian Government granted any additional funding to assist the various refugee programs in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia is gravely concerned about the continuing conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan and urges all parties to search for a negotiated peaceful settlement to the dispute.
(2) Australia is not a member of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, but supports the efforts of the CSCE to mediate in the conflict.

(3) In February Australia expressed its concerns in a major address to the United Nations Human Rights Commission. At that time we actively worked towards obtaining a consensus Chairman's statement but this initiative was unsuccessful due to lack of agreement on the terms of the statement. In its latest statement on the issue on 26 August the Security Council expressed its deep concern at the deterioration of the situation in Nagorno-Karabakh and strongly appealed to all parties for an immediate ceasefire and urged positive participation in negotiations to reach a peaceful settlement of the dispute. The Security Council noted that the Secretary-General had despatched a fact-finding mission to the region and was ready to send observers to the CSCE negotiations. It stated that the Council would consider further the role of the United Nations in Nagorno-Karabakh.
(4) It is difficult to establish the precise dimensions of the refugee problem as diverging figures have been reported.
The CSCE mission to Nagorno-Karabakh in February this year reported the following figures:
170,000 from Armenia in Azerbaijan
20,000 from Nagorno-Karabakh in Azerbaijan
350,000 from Azerbaijan (including Nagorno-Karabakh) in Armenia.

(3) Are the chairs to be either replaced or repaired, if so, how many in each category?
(4) What are the likely costs associated with (3)?
(5) Were the chairs specifically designed and built for Parliament House; if so, by whom?
(6) What was the original cost of each chair and how many were purchased?
(7) Are the chairs subject to any warranty arrangement?
(8) What is to be the fate of the defective chairs and if they are to be sold what is the expected return from such sales?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) All 1 348 chairs of this type in Parliament House.
(3) All chairs are to be repaired.
(4) $180 for each chair.
(5) Yes. Designed and manufactured by Sebel Furniture Pty Ltd.
(6) 1 348 were purchased for Parliament House at a cost of $427.17 each.
(7) Chairs were supplied under a 1 year warranty which ended on 23 May 1989.
